refashioned: In a primitive society without any division of labor, where trade is rare and every person provides for all their own needs, there is no need to accumulate savings or stockpile resources in advance to keep society functioning. Each person uses their own effort to meet their needs as they arise. When hungry, they go to the forest to hunt. When their clothing wears out, they make new garments from the hide of whatever large animal they next kill. When their shelter starts falling apart, they patch it up as best they can with whatever trees and turf happen to be nearby.
elegant: In a primitive society without division of labor, where everyone is self-sufficient, there is no need to accumulate stock beforehand. People simply meet each need as it arises -- hunting when hungry, clothing themselves from animal hides, repairing shelters with nearby materials.
summary: In a primitive, self-sufficient society without specialization or trade, people meet their needs directly as they arise, requiring no prior accumulation of resources or savings.
distilled: A society without division of labor requires no accumulated stock because each person directly provides for their own needs as they arise.
notes: Opening premise of Book II -- establishes the baseline condition (no division of labor) to show why capital accumulation becomes necessary. Cross-reference Book I on division of labor. Foundation for the argument that stock accumulation is a prerequisite for economic development.

refashioned: But once the division of labor is fully established, a person's own work can only supply a tiny fraction of their needs. The vast majority of what they need comes from other people's labor, purchased with the products -- or the sale price of the products -- of their own work. However, this exchange cannot happen until their own product has been both completed and sold. Therefore, a reserve of goods must be stored up somewhere, sufficient to sustain the worker and supply them with the materials and tools of their trade, at least until both of these things -- completion and sale -- can be accomplished. A weaver, for example, cannot devote themselves entirely to weaving unless there is already a reserve stored somewhere, whether in their own possession or someone else's, large enough to support them and provide materials and tools until they have not only finished their cloth but also sold it. This accumulation must clearly come before the weaver can commit their labor to such specialized work for any extended period.
elegant: Once labor is divided, a worker's own output covers only a small part of their needs -- the rest must be purchased with the proceeds of their own product. But this requires finishing and selling that product first. So a reserve of goods must already exist to sustain the worker and supply materials and tools in the meantime. A weaver cannot specialize unless such a stock is already accumulated. This accumulation must precede specialization.
summary: Division of labor means workers depend on selling their specialized output to buy what they need, but completing and selling takes time. Therefore, a prior accumulation of stock is essential to sustain workers and supply them with materials and tools during the production cycle.
distilled: Specialization requires a pre-existing stock of goods to sustain workers and supply materials during the gap between production and sale.
notes: Key causal argument: division of labor presupposes capital accumulation. The weaver example illustrates the temporal gap between production and revenue. Cross-reference Book I, Ch. 1--3 on division of labor. Introduces the concept of stock as a prerequisite, not just a result, of economic specialization.

refashioned: Since stock accumulation must by its very nature precede the division of labor, labor can only be further subdivided in proportion to how much stock has already been accumulated. As labor becomes more specialized, the same number of workers can process a far greater quantity of materials. And as each worker's tasks are simplified, new machines are invented to speed up and shorten those tasks. Therefore, as the division of labor advances, sustaining the same number of workers requires the same stock of provisions but a greater stock of materials and tools than would have been needed in a less developed economy. Meanwhile, the number of workers in each branch of business generally grows along with the division of labor in that branch -- or rather, it is the growth in their numbers that allows them to organize and subdivide their work in this way.
elegant: Stock accumulation must precede the division of labor, and further subdivision requires proportionally greater accumulation. As specialization increases, workers process more materials and invent new machines, demanding greater stocks of materials and tools. The growing number of workers in each trade both enables and requires further division of labor.
summary: The division of labor can only advance as fast as stock is accumulated. Greater specialization demands more materials and tools while also increasing the workforce, creating a reinforcing cycle between capital accumulation and productive specialization.
distilled: Labor can only be further divided in proportion to prior capital accumulation, since greater specialization demands ever larger stocks of materials and tools.
notes: Establishes the positive feedback loop between capital accumulation and division of labor. More stock enables more specialization, which requires still more stock. Cross-reference Book I on how division of labor increases productivity and spurs invention of machinery.

refashioned: Just as stock accumulation is a necessary precondition for the great improvement in labor's productive powers, that accumulation naturally drives such improvement forward. The person who invests their stock in employing workers naturally wants to get the greatest possible output from it. They therefore aim to distribute tasks among their workers in the most effective way and to equip them with the best machines they can invent or afford. Their ability to do both generally depends on the size of their stock -- that is, on how many workers it can support. The quantity of industry in every country therefore increases not only with the growth of the stock that employs it, but as a consequence of that growth, the same amount of industry also produces a far greater quantity of output.
elegant: Capital accumulation not only precedes but naturally drives improvements in productivity. The employer who invests stock in labor seeks maximum output, optimizing the division of tasks and investing in better machinery. Their capacity in both respects depends on the size of their stock. Thus, as stock grows, industry expands and the same labor produces vastly more.
summary: Capital accumulation naturally leads to productivity improvements because employers seek to maximize output from their investment by optimizing task distribution and investing in better machinery, with their capacity to do so scaling with the size of their stock.
distilled: The accumulation of capital naturally drives productivity improvements because larger stocks enable better organization of labor and superior machinery.
notes: Completes the virtuous circle: accumulation enables division of labor, which raises productivity, which enables further accumulation. The employer as optimizer -- allocating tasks and investing in technology. Cross-reference Book I on productivity gains from specialization.

refashioned:
Such, in general, are the effects of increasing stock on industry and its productive powers.

In this book, I have set out to explain the nature of stock, the effects of its accumulation into different kinds of capital, and the effects of employing those capitals in different ways. The book is divided into five chapters. In the first chapter, I show how the stock of either an individual or a whole society naturally divides itself into distinct parts or branches. In the second, I explain the nature and workings of money as one particular branch of society's general stock. Capital may be employed either by the person who owns it or lent to someone else. In the third and fourth chapters, I examine how it works in each of these situations. The fifth and final chapter addresses the different effects that different uses of capital have on the quantity of national industry and on the annual output of land and labor.
elegant: These are the general effects of growing stock on industry and productivity. This book explains the nature of stock, how it becomes different kinds of capital, and how those capitals produce different results. Chapter one divides stock into its natural branches. Chapter two examines money as a branch of society's stock. Chapters three and four analyze capital employed by its owner versus capital lent out. Chapter five addresses how different uses of capital affect national industry and annual output.
summary: Smith summarizes Book II's structure: five chapters covering the natural divisions of stock, money as a branch of stock, owner-employed versus lent capital, and the effects of different capital employments on national industry and output.
distilled: Book II examines how stock divides into different capitals and how different uses of capital affect national industry and annual output.
notes: Roadmap for Book II. Five chapters: (1) divisions of stock, (2) money, (3) capital employed by owner, (4) capital lent out, (5) effects of different capital employments. Transitional passage linking Book I's division of labor to Book II's capital theory.

refashioned: When a person's stock is only enough to sustain them for a few days or weeks, they rarely think about earning any revenue from it. They consume it as carefully as possible and try, through their own labor, to acquire something to replace it before it runs out entirely. In this situation, their income comes solely from their labor. This is the condition of the great majority of the laboring poor in every country.
elegant: When a person has only enough stock for days or weeks of survival, they consume it sparingly and rely entirely on their labor for income. This is the condition of most of the laboring poor everywhere.
summary: People with only minimal stock consume it carefully and depend entirely on their labor for income, which describes the situation of the laboring poor in all countries.
distilled: Those with only subsistence-level stock derive their revenue entirely from labor, which is the condition of most working poor.
notes: Opens Chapter 1 by establishing the threshold below which stock cannot function as capital. Distinguishes between stock-for-consumption and stock-as-capital. Sets up the framework for understanding how surplus stock becomes a source of revenue.

refashioned: But when someone has enough stock to sustain them for months or years, they naturally try to earn revenue from most of it, keeping only enough for immediate needs until that revenue starts flowing in. Their total stock therefore divides into two parts. The portion expected to generate revenue is called their capital. The other portion covers immediate consumption, and consists of three things: first, whatever share of total stock was originally set aside for this purpose; second, revenue from any source as it gradually comes in; and third, items previously purchased with either of the first two that have not yet been fully used up, such as clothing, household furniture, and the like. One or more of these three categories makes up the stock that people typically reserve for their own immediate consumption.
elegant: When stock exceeds immediate needs, the owner naturally seeks revenue from the greater part, reserving only enough for consumption until returns begin. Total stock thus divides into two: capital, which is expected to yield revenue, and the consumption reserve -- comprising the original set-aside, incoming revenue, and durable goods not yet consumed.
summary: When people possess more stock than they need for immediate survival, they divide it into capital (the portion meant to generate revenue) and a consumption reserve (covering immediate needs through original savings, incoming revenue, and durable goods not yet used up).
distilled: Surplus stock naturally divides into capital, which generates revenue, and a consumption reserve for immediate needs.
notes: Foundational definition of capital as the revenue-generating portion of stock. The three components of the consumption reserve anticipate modern concepts of savings, income flow, and depreciation of consumer durables. Key distinction: stock vs. capital.

refashioned:
There are two different ways capital can be employed to generate revenue or profit for its owner.

First, it can be used to buy, manufacture, or produce goods and then sell them at a profit. Capital used this way generates no return while it remains in the owner's possession or stays in the same form. A merchant's goods earn no profit until sold for money, and money earns nothing until exchanged again for goods. The capital is constantly leaving the owner in one form and returning in another, and only through this circulation -- these successive transformations -- can it yield any profit. Capital of this kind may therefore quite properly be called circulating capital.
elegant: Capital can yield profit in two ways. First, through buying, manufacturing, or producing goods and selling them at a profit. This type earns nothing while it stays in one form -- goods must be sold for money, money exchanged for goods. Only through this continuous circulation does it generate returns. Such capital is properly called circulating capital.
summary: The first type of capital -- circulating capital -- generates profit only through continuous exchange, as goods are sold for money and money reinvested in goods, with returns depending on this ongoing cycle of transformation.
distilled: Circulating capital generates profit only by continuously changing form -- from goods to money and back -- through successive exchanges.
notes: Introduces the circulating capital concept. Revenue depends on turnover, not possession. The merchant as archetype of circulating capital use. Cross-reference with fixed capital (next entry). Foundation for later analysis of money and banking in Ch. 2.

refashioned:
Second, capital may be invested in improving land, purchasing useful machines and tools, or similar assets that yield revenue or profit without changing owners or circulating further. Capital of this kind may properly be called fixed capital.

Different occupations require very different proportions of fixed and circulating capital.
elegant: Second, capital can be invested in land improvements, machines, or tools that generate returns without changing hands. This is fixed capital. Different occupations require very different ratios of fixed to circulating capital.
summary: Fixed capital -- invested in land improvements, machines, and tools -- generates returns without being exchanged, unlike circulating capital. The proportion between the two varies greatly across occupations.
distilled: Fixed capital yields returns without changing hands, and different industries require different proportions of fixed versus circulating capital.
notes: Completes the fixed vs. circulating capital distinction. Fixed capital: returns come from use, not exchange. Varying ratios across industries foreshadow examples in subsequent entries. Cross-reference 2.1.3 on circulating capital.

refashioned:
A merchant's capital, for example, is entirely circulating capital. They need no machines or tools of trade, unless their shop or warehouse counts as such.

Every master craftsman or manufacturer must have some fixed capital in the form of trade tools. This portion is very small in some trades and very large in others. A master tailor needs nothing more than a set of needles. A master shoemaker's tools are a bit more expensive, though only slightly. A weaver's equipment costs considerably more than a shoemaker's. Nevertheless, the far greater part of every craftsman's capital circulates -- invested in workers' wages and the price of materials, then recovered with a profit through the sale price of the finished work.
elegant: A merchant's capital is entirely circulating -- no machines needed beyond a shop. Craftsmen require some fixed capital in tools, ranging from a tailor's needles to a weaver's more expensive equipment. Yet for all craftsmen, the greater share of capital circulates through wages and materials, recovered with profit from sales.
summary: Merchants use purely circulating capital, while craftsmen need varying amounts of fixed capital for tools -- from cheap needles to costly looms -- though even for craftsmen, most capital circulates through wages and materials.
distilled: Merchants need only circulating capital, while craftsmen require varying amounts of fixed capital in tools, though circulating capital dominates in most trades.
notes: Concrete examples illustrating the fixed-to-circulating ratio across trades. Spectrum from pure circulating (merchant) to mixed (craftsmen). The tailor-shoemaker-weaver progression shows increasing fixed capital requirements. Cross-reference 2.1.4 on varying proportions.

refashioned: In other industries, a much larger fixed capital is required. In a large ironworks, for example, the furnace for smelting ore, the forge, and the slitting mill are tools of trade that cannot be built without enormous expense. In coal mines and mines of every kind, the machinery needed for pumping out water and other operations is frequently even more expensive still.
elegant: Some industries demand far greater fixed capital. An ironworks requires enormously expensive furnaces, forges, and mills. Coal mines and other mining operations need machinery for water drainage and extraction that is often even costlier.
summary: Heavy industries like ironworks and mining require enormous fixed capital investments in furnaces, forges, mills, and drainage machinery, far exceeding what lighter trades need.
distilled: Heavy industries such as ironworks and mining require vastly greater fixed capital than lighter trades.
notes: Extends the spectrum of fixed capital requirements to heavy industry. Ironworks and mining as capital-intensive exemplars. Cross-reference 2.1.5 for lighter trades. Foreshadows discussion of infrastructure investment and returns on fixed capital.

refashioned: The portion of a farmer's capital invested in agricultural tools is fixed capital, while the portion spent on wages and maintenance of laborers is circulating capital. The farmer profits from the tools by keeping them and from the wages by paying them out. The value of working cattle is fixed capital, just like farm implements; their upkeep is circulating capital, like the laborers' wages. The farmer profits by keeping the cattle and by parting with their feed. Cattle bought and fattened not for work but for sale represent circulating capital entirely -- both their purchase price and their feed -- since profit comes from selling them. A flock of sheep or herd of cattle kept in a breeding region not for work or immediate sale, but for profit from their wool, milk, and offspring, is fixed capital. The profit comes from keeping them. Their feed, however, is circulating capital -- the profit comes from spending it, and it returns along with the profit on the animals' full value, in the price of wool, milk, and young stock. Seed is also properly fixed capital. Though it moves back and forth between field and granary, it never changes owners and so does not truly circulate. The farmer profits not from selling the seed but from its increase.
elegant: A farmer's tools are fixed capital; workers' wages are circulating. Working cattle are fixed capital (profit from keeping), their feed circulating (profit from spending). Cattle bought for fattening and resale are entirely circulating capital. Breeding flocks kept for wool, milk, and offspring are fixed capital, though their feed is circulating. Even seed is fixed capital -- it moves between field and granary but never changes hands, yielding profit through its increase, not its sale.
summary: Smith classifies every element of farming capital: tools and working cattle are fixed, wages and feed are circulating, fattening stock is entirely circulating, breeding stock is fixed while its feed is circulating, and seed is fixed because it yields returns through growth rather than sale.
distilled: Farm capital classifies into fixed (tools, working cattle, breeding stock, seed) and circulating (wages, feed, fattening stock) based on whether profit comes from keeping or exchanging.
notes: Detailed taxonomy of agricultural capital applying the fixed/circulating distinction. The seed example is notable -- physically it moves but economically it stays (never changes owner). Breeding stock vs. fattening stock distinction anticipates modern asset classification. Cross-reference 2.1.3--4.

refashioned:
The total stock of any country or society is the sum of the stock held by all its inhabitants, and it naturally divides into the same three portions, each with a distinct function.

The first portion is that reserved for immediate consumption, whose defining feature is that it produces no revenue or profit. It consists of food, clothing, household furniture, and similar goods purchased by consumers but not yet fully consumed. All dwelling houses in the country at any given time also belong to this portion. Stock invested in a house intended as the owner's dwelling ceases from that moment to serve as capital or generate any revenue. A dwelling house contributes nothing to its inhabitant's income. Though certainly very useful, it is useful in the same way that clothes and furniture are useful -- as an expense, not a source of revenue.
elegant: A nation's total stock, like an individual's, divides into three portions. The first is the consumption reserve, which generates no revenue. It includes food, clothing, furniture, and other consumer goods not yet fully used up. Dwelling houses belong here too -- once occupied by the owner, a house ceases to be capital. However useful, it is an expense, not a source of income.
summary: A nation's stock divides into three portions. The first -- the consumption reserve -- includes food, clothing, furniture, and dwelling houses, none of which generate revenue. An owner-occupied house, however useful, functions as an expense rather than capital.
distilled: The first division of national stock is the consumption reserve -- including dwelling houses -- which is useful but generates no revenue.
notes: Begins the three-part taxonomy of national stock. Dwelling houses as consumption, not capital -- a counterintuitive classification Smith defends. Useful vs. productive distinction. Cross-reference 2.1.2 on individual stock divisions. Anticipates modern debates about housing as investment vs. consumption.

refashioned: If a house is rented out to a tenant, the tenant must always pay rent from some other source of income -- whether from labor, stock, or land -- since the house itself produces nothing. So while a house may generate revenue for its owner and thereby function as capital for that individual, it cannot generate any revenue for the public or serve as capital for society as a whole. The total income of the population can never be increased by it even in the slightest degree. Clothing and household furniture can likewise sometimes yield revenue and function as capital for particular individuals. In countries where masquerade balls are common, there is a trade in renting out costume dresses for the night. Upholsterers frequently rent out furniture by the month or year. Undertakers rent funeral furnishings by the day or week. Many people rent out furnished houses, collecting rent not only for the house itself but also for the furniture.
elegant: A rented house yields revenue to its owner, but since the house produces nothing, the tenant pays from other income. The house functions as capital for the individual but not for society -- it adds nothing to total national income. Similarly, clothing and furniture sometimes yield revenue to individuals: costume rentals for masquerades, furniture hired by the month, funeral furnishings by the day, and furnished houses let for combined rent.
summary: Though houses, clothing, and furniture can yield rental income to their owners, they produce nothing themselves -- tenants must pay from other revenue sources. These items function as individual capital but add nothing to society's total income.
distilled: Rental housing and consumer goods can serve as capital for individuals but add nothing to national revenue since they produce nothing -- tenants pay from other income sources.
notes: Distinction between individual capital and social capital. A rented house is a zero-sum transfer, not value creation. Charming historical examples: masquerade costume rental, funeral furniture hire. Anticipates modern debates about rent-seeking vs. productive activity. Cross-reference 2.1.8.

refashioned: However, revenue derived from renting out such things must always ultimately come from some other source of income. Of all stock reserved for immediate consumption, what is invested in houses is consumed most slowly. Clothing may last several years; furniture may last half a century or a century; but well-built and properly maintained houses may last many centuries. Yet despite their much longer lifespan, houses are still just as truly part of the consumption reserve as clothing or household furniture.
elegant: Revenue from renting consumption goods always originates from some other income source. Among consumption goods, houses are simply the most durable -- clothing lasts years, furniture decades, houses centuries -- but all remain part of the consumption reserve regardless of their longevity.
summary: Rental income from consumption goods always derives from other revenue sources. Houses are merely the most durable form of consumption stock -- lasting centuries versus years for clothing or decades for furniture -- but durability does not change their fundamental classification.
distilled: Houses are the most durable consumption stock but remain consumption goods regardless of their longevity, and rental income from them always derives from other sources.
notes: Durability does not transform consumption goods into capital. Interesting hierarchy of durability: clothes (years), furniture (decades), houses (centuries). Reinforces the analytical distinction between consumption reserve and capital. Cross-reference 2.1.8--9.

refashioned:
The second of the three portions into which society's general stock divides itself is fixed capital, whose defining characteristic is that it generates revenue or profit without circulating or changing hands. It consists chiefly of four categories.

First: all useful machines and instruments of trade that make labor easier and more efficient.
elegant: The second portion of national stock is fixed capital, which yields returns without changing hands. Its first component is all useful machines and instruments of trade that facilitate and reduce labor.
summary: Fixed capital -- the second division of national stock -- generates revenue without circulating. Its first component consists of all machines and instruments that make labor more efficient.
distilled: Fixed capital generates revenue without changing hands, beginning with machines and instruments that enhance labor productivity.
notes: Begins enumeration of fixed capital's four components. Machines and tools as the first category. Cross-reference 2.1.4 on fixed capital definition. The four categories will be: (1) machines/tools, (2) commercial buildings, (3) land improvements, (4) human skills.

refashioned: Second: all profitable buildings that serve as a means of generating revenue, not only for the owner who rents them out but also for the person who occupies them and pays that rent -- such as shops, warehouses, workshops, farmhouses, and all their necessary associated structures including stables, granaries, and the like. These are very different from mere dwelling houses. They are a kind of instrument of trade and should be regarded in the same light.
elegant: Second: all profitable buildings that generate revenue for both owner and tenant -- shops, warehouses, workshops, farmhouses, and their associated structures. Unlike dwelling houses, these are instruments of trade.
summary: The second component of fixed capital is commercial buildings -- shops, warehouses, workshops, farmhouses, and associated structures -- which function as instruments of trade, distinct from dwelling houses that merely serve consumption.
distilled: Commercial buildings like shops, warehouses, and farmhouses are fixed capital because they function as productive instruments of trade, unlike dwelling houses.
notes: Key distinction between commercial and residential buildings. Commercial buildings are fixed capital (instruments of trade); dwelling houses are consumption stock (see 2.1.8). Revenue flows to both landlord and tenant, unlike dwelling houses. Cross-reference 2.1.8--9.

refashioned: Third: improvements to land -- what has been profitably spent on clearing, draining, enclosing, manuring, and bringing it into the best condition for farming and cultivation. An improved farm may rightly be seen in the same light as those useful machines that make labor more efficient: with the same circulating capital, it can produce far greater revenue for its operator. An improved farm is just as advantageous as any machine, and more durable, often requiring no other maintenance than the most profitable use of the farmer's capital in cultivating it.
elegant: Third: land improvements -- clearing, draining, enclosing, and manuring that bring land to peak productivity. An improved farm functions like an efficient machine, enabling far greater output from the same circulating capital. It is equally advantageous and more durable than machinery, often needing only continued good cultivation as maintenance.
summary: The third component of fixed capital is land improvements, which function like productive machinery by enabling greater output from the same working capital, while being more durable and requiring less maintenance than mechanical equipment.
distilled: Land improvements are fixed capital that functions like machinery -- boosting output from the same circulating capital while being more durable.
notes: Land improvement as technology -- the farm-as-machine analogy. Improved land amplifies circulating capital's productivity. Durability advantage over mechanical capital. Cross-reference 2.1.11 on machines. Relevant to physiocratic debates about land as the source of wealth.

refashioned: Fourth: the acquired and useful skills of all members of society. Acquiring such abilities through education, study, or apprenticeship always involves a real expense, which becomes a capital fixed and embodied in the person. These skills form part of that person's personal fortune and equally part of the wealth of the society they belong to. A worker's improved skill may be viewed in the same light as a machine or tool that makes labor more efficient: though it costs something to develop, it repays that cost with a profit.
elegant: Fourth: the acquired skills of all members of society. Education, study, and apprenticeship cost real resources, creating capital fixed in the person. These skills are wealth for both the individual and society. Like a machine that costs money to build but repays with profit, improved worker skill is an investment that yields returns.
summary: The fourth component of fixed capital is human skill and knowledge, acquired through education and training at real cost. Like machinery, these abilities represent an investment embodied in the person that repays its cost with profit.
distilled: Acquired human skills are fixed capital embodied in persons, representing investments in education and training that yield returns like machinery.
notes: Remarkably modern concept -- human capital theory 200 years before Becker and Schultz. Skills as capital 'fixed and realized in the person.' The education-as-investment analogy. Cross-reference 2.1.11 on machines. One of Smith's most forward-looking insights.

refashioned:
The third and final portion into which society's general stock naturally divides itself is circulating capital, whose defining characteristic is that it generates revenue only by circulating or changing hands. It likewise consists of four parts.

First: money, the medium through which all the other three parts are circulated and distributed to their proper consumers.
elegant: The third portion of national stock is circulating capital, which yields revenue only by changing hands. Its first component is money -- the medium through which all other parts are circulated and distributed to consumers.
summary: Circulating capital, the third division of national stock, generates revenue only through exchange. Its first of four components is money, which serves as the medium for circulating and distributing all other goods.
distilled: Circulating capital yields revenue only by changing hands, with money as its first component serving to circulate all other goods.
notes: Begins the four-part enumeration of circulating capital: (1) money, (2) provisions, (3) raw/semi-finished materials, (4) finished goods. Money as medium of circulation, not wealth itself -- a theme developed extensively in Ch. 2. Cross-reference 2.1.3 on circulating capital definition.

refashioned:
Second: the stock of provisions held by butchers, cattle dealers, farmers, grain merchants, brewers, and others, from whose sale they expect to earn a profit.

Third: materials in all stages of production -- whether completely raw or partly manufactured -- for clothing, furniture, and buildings that have not yet been made into finished products. These remain in the hands of growers, manufacturers, fabric dealers, drapers, timber merchants, carpenters, joiners, brickmakers, and others.
elegant: Second: provisions held by butchers, farmers, brewers, and other dealers awaiting profitable sale. Third: materials at every stage of processing -- raw or partly manufactured -- for clothing, furniture, and construction, held by growers, manufacturers, and various tradespeople.
summary: The second component of circulating capital is provisions held by various dealers for sale, and the third is materials at all stages of manufacture -- from raw to semi-finished -- still in the hands of producers and merchants.
distilled: Circulating capital includes provisions awaiting sale and materials at every stage of manufacture still held by producers and dealers.
notes: Components two and three of circulating capital. Provisions and materials span the full production chain from raw to semi-finished. Extensive list of trades illustrates how goods pass through many hands. Cross-reference 2.1.15 on circulating capital.

refashioned: Fourth and finally: finished goods that have been completed but are still in the hands of merchants and manufacturers, not yet sold or distributed to final consumers -- such as the ready-made products we commonly find in the shops of blacksmiths, cabinet-makers, goldsmiths, jewelers, china merchants, and others. Circulating capital thus consists of provisions, materials, and finished goods of all kinds in the hands of their respective dealers, plus the money needed to circulate and distribute these goods to those who will ultimately use or consume them.
elegant: Fourth: finished goods still held by merchants and manufacturers awaiting sale -- the ready-made products in every kind of shop. Circulating capital thus comprises provisions, materials, finished goods in dealers' hands, and the money needed to distribute them all to final consumers.
summary: The fourth component of circulating capital is finished goods awaiting sale. Together, circulating capital comprises provisions, materials, finished goods held by dealers, and the money required to distribute everything to final consumers.
distilled: Circulating capital encompasses provisions, materials, finished goods awaiting sale, and the money needed to distribute them to consumers.
notes: Completes the four-part taxonomy of circulating capital. The full cycle: money, provisions, materials, finished goods -- all in motion toward consumers. Cross-reference 2.1.15--16. Sets up the relationship between circulating and fixed capital in subsequent entries.

refashioned:
Of these four components, three -- provisions, materials, and finished goods -- are regularly withdrawn from circulating capital, either annually or over shorter or longer periods, and transferred to either fixed capital or the consumption reserve.

All fixed capital is both originally created from and must be continually maintained by circulating capital. Every useful machine and instrument of trade originally comes from circulating capital, which supplies both the materials they are made from and the maintenance of the workers who make them. These machines and tools also require ongoing circulating capital to keep them in constant repair.
elegant: Three components of circulating capital -- provisions, materials, and finished goods -- are regularly withdrawn and placed into either fixed capital or the consumption reserve. All fixed capital originates from and depends on circulating capital, which supplies both the materials for machines and the workers who build and maintain them.
summary: Provisions, materials, and finished goods flow continuously from circulating capital into fixed capital or consumption. All fixed capital originates from and requires ongoing support by circulating capital, which furnishes both construction materials and worker maintenance.
distilled: Fixed capital both originates from and depends on continuous replenishment by circulating capital for its creation and maintenance.
notes: Critical relationship: circulating capital feeds both fixed capital and consumption. Fixed capital cannot exist or persist without circulating capital. Establishes the dependency hierarchy among the three stock categories. Cross-reference 2.1.11--17.

refashioned: No fixed capital can produce any revenue without the support of circulating capital. The most useful machines and tools will produce nothing without the circulating capital that provides the materials they work on and the maintenance of the workers who operate them. Land, no matter how improved, will yield no revenue without the circulating capital that supports the laborers who cultivate it and harvest its produce.
elegant: Fixed capital is useless without circulating capital. Machines need materials to process and workers to operate them. Improved land needs laborers to cultivate it. In every case, circulating capital supplies these essential inputs.
summary: Fixed capital cannot generate revenue on its own; it always requires circulating capital to supply the materials for processing and the maintenance of workers who operate the machines or cultivate the land.
distilled: Fixed capital is productive only when paired with circulating capital, which supplies materials and sustains the workers who operate it.
notes: Reinforces the dependency of fixed on circulating capital. Machines without inputs and workers are useless. Land without cultivation yields nothing. Complementarity of capital types. Cross-reference 2.1.18.

refashioned: The sole purpose of both fixed and circulating capital is to maintain and increase the stock reserved for immediate consumption. This is the stock that feeds, clothes, and houses people. Whether people are rich or poor depends on whether these two types of capital can supply the consumption reserve abundantly or sparingly.
elegant: Both fixed and circulating capital exist for one purpose: to maintain and grow the consumption reserve that feeds, clothes, and houses people. A society's wealth or poverty depends on how abundantly its capital can supply this reserve.
summary: The ultimate purpose of all capital -- both fixed and circulating -- is to maintain and increase the stock of consumable goods that sustain people. National prosperity depends on how well capital fulfills this purpose.
distilled: All capital exists ultimately to sustain and enlarge the consumption stock that feeds, clothes, and houses people.
notes: Teleological view of capital -- it serves consumption. Wealth is ultimately measured in consumable goods, not in capital itself. Capital is instrumental, not an end. Cross-reference 2.1.8 on consumption reserve. Anticipates modern welfare economics.

refashioned: Since such a large portion of circulating capital is continually being withdrawn and placed into the other two branches of the general stock, it must itself be continually replenished, or it would soon cease to exist. These supplies come primarily from three sources: the produce of land, of mines, and of fisheries. These provide a continuous flow of provisions and materials, part of which is then processed into finished goods, replacing the provisions, materials, and finished goods continually withdrawn from the circulating capital. From mines also comes what is needed to maintain and replenish the money component. Though money, unlike the other three components, is not normally withdrawn to be placed into fixed capital or the consumption reserve, it too wears out, gets lost, or is sent abroad, and therefore requires continuous -- though much smaller -- replenishment.
elegant: Circulating capital, constantly drained into fixed capital and consumption, must be continuously replenished from three sources: land, mines, and fisheries. These supply fresh provisions and materials that are processed into finished goods. Mines also replenish the money supply, which, though not regularly withdrawn like other components, gradually wears out, gets lost, or goes abroad.
summary: Circulating capital requires constant replenishment from land, mines, and fisheries, which supply new provisions, materials, and -- from mines -- monetary metals. Money wears out and leaves the country more slowly than other components but still requires ongoing replacement.
distilled: Land, mines, and fisheries continuously replenish circulating capital with provisions, materials, and monetary metals to replace what is constantly withdrawn.
notes: The three ultimate sources of replenishment: land, mines, fisheries. Money's unique position -- it circulates rather than being consumed, but still degrades. Physical wear and export as drains on money stock. Cross-reference 2.1.18 on withdrawal from circulating capital.

refashioned: Land, mines, and fisheries all require both fixed and circulating capital to work them, and their output replaces not only those capitals but all the other capitals in society as well. The farmer annually replaces the provisions that the manufacturer consumed and the materials that were processed the year before, while the manufacturer replaces the finished goods the farmer wore out in the same period. This is the real exchange that takes place annually between these two groups, though the raw produce of one and the manufactured goods of the other are seldom directly bartered. It rarely happens that the farmer sells grain, cattle, flax, and wool to the same person from whom they buy clothing, furniture, and tools. Instead, the farmer sells raw produce for money and uses that money to purchase manufactured goods wherever they can be found. Land even partially replaces the capital used in fisheries and mining. It is the produce of land that feeds the fisherman who catches fish, and the produce of the earth's surface that sustains the miner who extracts minerals from its depths.
elegant: Land, mines, and fisheries require both types of capital, and their output replenishes all capitals in society. Farmers replace manufacturers' provisions and materials; manufacturers replace farmers' finished goods. This exchange rarely happens through direct barter -- money mediates instead. Land even partially sustains fisheries and mining, since surface produce feeds those who harvest the sea and work below ground.
summary: Land, mines, and fisheries require both fixed and circulating capital, and their produce replenishes all of society's capital through a system of indirect exchange mediated by money, with land ultimately supporting even fishing and mining by feeding those workers.
distilled: The produce of land, mines, and fisheries replenishes all of society's capital, with money mediating the exchanges and land ultimately sustaining all extractive industries.
notes: Circular flow of the economy: agriculture and manufacturing replace each other's inputs. Money as intermediary (not direct barter). Land's primacy -- it even sustains fisheries and mining indirectly. Cross-reference 2.1.21. Echoes physiocratic emphasis on land while broadening it.

refashioned:
When land, mines, and fisheries have equal natural fertility, their output is proportional to the amount and proper application of capital employed on them. When capitals are equal and equally well applied, output is proportional to natural fertility.

In every country with reasonable security, any person of ordinary understanding will try to employ whatever stock they can command -- whether in pursuit of present enjoyment or future profit. If employed for present enjoyment, it becomes part of the consumption reserve. If employed for future profit, it must earn that profit either by staying with the owner or by leaving them. In the first case it is fixed capital; in the second, circulating capital. A person would have to be utterly irrational, in a country with reasonable security, not to employ all the stock at their command -- whether their own or borrowed -- in one of these three ways.
elegant: Output from land, mines, and fisheries depends on capital employed and natural fertility. In any reasonably secure country, every rational person employs their stock in one of three ways: consumption (for present enjoyment), fixed capital (profit from keeping), or circulating capital (profit from exchanging). No rational person leaves stock idle where there is basic security.
summary: Production depends on both capital application and natural fertility. In any reasonably secure society, rational people employ all their stock either for immediate consumption, as fixed capital, or as circulating capital -- leaving nothing idle.
distilled: Rational individuals in secure societies employ all stock as consumption, fixed capital, or circulating capital -- idleness is irrational where property is safe.
notes: Two determinants of output: capital application and natural fertility. The rationality assumption -- all stock is employed in secure societies. The three-way classification is exhaustive: consumption, fixed, or circulating. Security of property as prerequisite for rational capital deployment. Cross-reference 2.1.24 on insecure societies.

refashioned: In those unfortunate countries where people live in constant fear of violence from their rulers, they frequently bury or hide a large portion of their stock, keeping it ready to carry to safety if threatened by the disasters they consider themselves always exposed to. This is said to be common practice in Turkey, India, and most other Asian governments. It seems to have been common among our own ancestors during the violent era of feudal government. Treasure trove -- hidden treasure found in the earth with no identifiable owner -- was considered a significant source of revenue even for the greatest European sovereigns. It was always treated as belonging to the sovereign, not to the finder or the landowner, unless the landowner's charter specifically granted that right. Treasure trove was placed on the same legal footing as gold and silver mines, which were never assumed to be included in a general land grant without a special clause, even though mines of lead, copper, tin, and coal -- being of lesser consequence -- were.
elegant: In despotic countries where people fear their rulers' violence, they bury and hide stock for quick escape. This was common in Turkey, India, and most of Asia, and among Europeans under feudal government. Treasure trove -- found hidden wealth -- was a significant royal revenue source. It belonged to the sovereign by default, like gold and silver mines, which required special charter clauses to pass to landowners, unlike lesser mines of lead, copper, or tin.
summary: In insecure societies where people fear their rulers, wealth is commonly buried rather than invested. Historically, such hidden treasure was significant enough to be claimed as sovereign revenue, treated legally like gold and silver mines requiring special charter grants.
distilled: Political insecurity causes people to hoard and hide wealth instead of investing it, as historically evidenced by buried treasure in despotic and feudal societies.
notes: Property rights and political stability as prerequisites for capital investment. Without security, rational behavior is hoarding, not investing. Treasure trove as historical evidence. Feudal legal distinctions between precious and base metal mines. Cross-reference 2.1.23 on security. Foundation for institutional economics arguments about property rights and growth.

refashioned: As shown in Book I, the price of most commodities breaks down into three components: one pays the wages of labor, another pays the profits on capital, and the third pays the rent of the land used in producing and bringing them to market. Some commodities are priced with only two of these -- wages and profits -- and a very few consist entirely of wages alone. But the price of every commodity necessarily resolves into one, two, or all three of these parts; whatever portion goes neither to rent nor to wages is necessarily profit for someone.
elegant: As Book I showed, most commodity prices consist of three parts: wages, profits, and rent. Some prices include only wages and profits; a few consist of wages alone. But every price necessarily resolves into some combination of these three -- whatever goes to neither rent nor wages is necessarily someone's profit.
summary: Building on Book I, every commodity's price decomposes into wages, profits, and rent, or some subset of these three components, with any portion not attributed to wages or rent necessarily constituting someone's profit.
distilled: Every commodity price resolves into wages, profits, and rent -- or some combination of these three components.
notes: Recapitulates the Book I price theory as foundation for Chapter 2's analysis of national income. The three-component price decomposition: wages, profit, rent. Cross-reference Book I, Chapters 6--7. Sets up the distinction between gross and net revenue.

refashioned: Since this holds true for every individual commodity, it must also hold for all commodities taken together -- that is, for the entire annual output of a country's land and labor. The total price or exchangeable value of that annual output must resolve into the same three parts, distributed among the country's inhabitants as either the wages of their labor, the profits on their capital, or the rent of their land.
elegant: What holds for each commodity individually holds for all combined. The total value of a country's annual output resolves into wages, profits, and rent, distributed among the population accordingly.
summary: The three-part price decomposition of individual commodities scales to the entire economy: a nation's total annual output distributes among its people as wages, profits, and rent.
distilled: A nation's total annual output, like each commodity's price, resolves entirely into wages, profits, and rent distributed among its people.
notes: Aggregation from micro to macro -- what's true of each commodity's price is true of national output. Foundation for national income accounting. The three-way distribution: labor, capital, land. Cross-reference 2.2.1.

refashioned: Although the entire value of a country's annual output is distributed among its inhabitants as revenue, we can distinguish -- just as we distinguish between the gross rent and the net rent of a private estate -- between the gross revenue and the net revenue of a whole country's population.
elegant: Though the entire annual output constitutes revenue for the population, we must distinguish between gross and net revenue -- just as we distinguish between the gross and net rent of a private estate.
summary: Just as a private estate has both gross and net rent, a nation's total revenue must be understood in terms of both gross revenue (total output) and net revenue (what remains after maintaining capital).
distilled: National revenue, like estate rent, must be understood as both gross and net -- the latter being what remains after capital maintenance costs.
notes: Introduces the gross vs. net revenue distinction for the whole economy, using the estate analogy. Key analytical framework for the rest of the chapter. Cross-reference 2.2.4 for the estate analogy developed fully.

refashioned: The gross rent of a private estate includes everything the tenant pays. The net rent is what remains after deducting the costs of management, repairs, and all other necessary charges -- or in other words, what the landlord can afford to put toward consumption without damaging the estate: spending on food, carriages, home decoration, personal enjoyments, and entertainment. The landlord's real wealth is proportional not to gross rent but to net rent.
elegant: An estate's gross rent is everything the tenant pays; net rent is what remains after management, repairs, and necessary expenses. The net rent is what the landlord can spend on consumption without degrading the estate. Real wealth corresponds to net rent, not gross.
summary: Gross rent is total payment from tenants; net rent is what remains after all expenses of maintaining the estate. A landlord's true wealth is measured by net rent -- what can be consumed without diminishing the property.
distilled: Real wealth is measured by net rent -- what can be consumed after deducting all costs of maintaining the productive asset.
notes: The estate analogy for gross vs. net revenue. Net rent = sustainable consumption without depleting capital. Real wealth measured by what can be consumed without degrading productive capacity. Cross-reference 2.2.3 and 2.2.5 for national application.

refashioned: The gross revenue of a great country's entire population encompasses the whole annual output of their land and labor. The net revenue is what remains after deducting the costs of maintaining, first, their fixed capital, and second, their circulating capital -- or what they can place in their consumption reserve, spending on subsistence, comforts, and entertainment, without eating into their capital. Their real wealth, too, is proportional not to their gross but to their net revenue.
elegant: A nation's gross revenue is its total annual output. Net revenue is what remains after maintaining fixed and circulating capital -- what can be consumed without depleting capital. Real national wealth, like personal wealth, is measured by net revenue, not gross.
summary: National gross revenue is total annual output; net revenue is what remains after the costs of maintaining both fixed and circulating capital. A nation's true wealth corresponds to its net revenue -- what it can consume without diminishing its productive capacity.
distilled: National wealth is measured by net revenue -- total output minus the cost of maintaining fixed and circulating capital.
notes: Applies the estate analogy (2.2.4) to the national economy. Net revenue = GDP minus capital depreciation/maintenance, roughly equivalent to modern net national product. Cross-reference 2.2.3--4. Foundation for the rest of the chapter's analysis.

refashioned: The entire cost of maintaining fixed capital must clearly be excluded from society's net revenue. Neither the materials needed to maintain useful machines, buildings, and equipment, nor the labor required to fashion those materials into proper form, can count as part of net revenue. The wages paid for that labor may indeed form part of net revenue, since the workers can spend their entire wages on consumption. But in other kinds of labor, both the wages and the product contribute to the consumption stock -- the wages to the workers' consumption, the product to that of other people whose sustenance, comforts, and entertainment are enhanced by those workers' efforts.
elegant: Fixed capital maintenance costs must be excluded from net revenue -- both materials and labor for upkeep. Workers' wages may count as net revenue (they spend them on consumption), but their output goes to maintaining capital, not to consumable goods. In other trades, both wages and product enhance the consumption stock -- workers consume wages, while others consume the product.
summary: Maintaining fixed capital costs resources that must be deducted from net revenue, though the wages paid to maintenance workers count as part of net revenue since workers spend them on consumption. This contrasts with other labor where both wages and output directly serve consumption.
distilled: Fixed capital maintenance costs reduce net revenue, though the wages paid to maintenance workers still count as their consumable income.
notes: Nuanced treatment of maintenance labor: the output goes to capital upkeep (not net revenue) but the wages go to workers' consumption (net revenue). Distinction between labor that maintains capital and labor that produces consumable goods. Cross-reference 2.2.5.

refashioned: The purpose of fixed capital is to increase the productive powers of labor -- to enable the same number of workers to accomplish far more. On a farm with all necessary buildings, fences, drains, and roads in excellent condition, the same number of workers and draft animals will produce far more than on an equally sized and fertile farm lacking those improvements. In manufacturing, the same number of workers equipped with the best machinery will process far more goods than those using inferior equipment. Money properly spent on fixed capital always repays itself with great profit, increasing annual output by much more than the cost of maintaining those improvements. However, this maintenance still requires a certain portion of output. Materials and labor that could otherwise have been used directly to increase food, clothing, and housing are diverted to this different though highly advantageous purpose. This is why all improvements in mechanics that enable the same number of workers to do equal work with cheaper, simpler machinery are always considered beneficial to society. The materials and labor previously devoted to supporting more complex and expensive machinery can then be applied to increasing the output that the machinery helps produce. A manufacturer spending a thousand pounds a year on machinery maintenance who reduces that cost to five hundred will naturally invest the other five hundred in additional materials and workers, thereby increasing output and the benefits society derives from it.
elegant: Fixed capital's purpose is to multiply labor's output. Better-equipped farms and factories produce far more with the same workers. Investment in fixed capital always repays itself handsomely, increasing output well beyond maintenance costs. Yet maintenance diverts resources from direct consumption. Therefore, any mechanical improvement that achieves equal output with cheaper machinery benefits society -- freed resources expand production. A manufacturer who halves machinery costs from a thousand to five hundred pounds redirects the savings into more materials and workers, increasing output.
summary: Fixed capital amplifies labor productivity, and its maintenance costs are always repaid many times over. Any innovation that reduces these maintenance costs benefits society by freeing resources for additional production -- a manufacturer saving five hundred pounds on machinery can invest that directly in expanding output.
distilled: Fixed capital multiplies labor's productivity, and mechanical improvements that reduce maintenance costs free resources for expanded production, benefiting all of society.
notes: Central argument for technological efficiency. Fixed capital as a productivity multiplier. The savings principle: reducing maintenance costs frees circulating capital for production. The manufacturer example (1000 to 500 pounds) is a precursor to modern concepts of capital efficiency. Cross-reference 2.1.19 on fixed capital needing circulating capital. Sets up the argument for paper money as a cheaper 'machine' of circulation.

refashioned: The cost of maintaining a nation's fixed capital may aptly be compared to the cost of repairs on a private estate. Repair expenses may be necessary to sustain the estate's output, and therefore both its gross and net rent. But when better management can reduce repair costs without reducing output, the gross rent stays the same while the net rent necessarily increases.
elegant: National fixed capital maintenance is like estate repairs -- necessary for sustaining output, but if reduced without cutting production, net revenue rises while gross stays the same.
summary: Like estate repairs, fixed capital maintenance is necessary for production but reducing it without losing output directly increases net revenue.
distilled: Reducing fixed capital maintenance costs without reducing output directly increases net revenue, just as cutting estate repair costs raises net rent.
notes: Returns to the estate analogy (see 2.2.3--4). Efficiency in capital maintenance directly translates to higher net revenue. Sets up the argument that paper money reduces 'maintenance costs' of the monetary system. Cross-reference 2.2.7.

refashioned: But while the entire cost of maintaining fixed capital must be excluded from society's net revenue, the same is not true of maintaining circulating capital. Of circulating capital's four components -- money, provisions, materials, and finished goods -- the last three, as already noted, are regularly withdrawn and placed either in fixed capital or in the consumption reserve. Whatever portion of these consumable goods is not used to maintain fixed capital goes entirely to consumption and becomes part of net revenue. Maintaining these three components of circulating capital therefore withdraws nothing from net revenue beyond what is needed to maintain fixed capital.
elegant: Unlike fixed capital maintenance, circulating capital maintenance need not all be excluded from net revenue. Of its four parts -- money, provisions, materials, finished goods -- the last three flow into either fixed capital or consumption. What does not go to maintaining fixed capital becomes part of net revenue directly.
summary: While all fixed capital maintenance reduces net revenue, three of circulating capital's four components (provisions, materials, finished goods) flow either into fixed capital or directly into consumption, reducing net revenue only to the extent they maintain fixed capital.
distilled: Three parts of circulating capital (provisions, materials, finished goods) reduce net revenue only insofar as they maintain fixed capital -- the rest becomes consumable net revenue.
notes: Asymmetry between fixed and circulating capital maintenance costs. Circulating capital's non-money components are either consumed or absorbed into fixed capital. Only money remains as a pure deduction from net revenue. Cross-reference 2.2.6. Sets up the argument in 2.2.11 about money.

refashioned: In this respect, society's circulating capital differs from an individual's. An individual's circulating capital is entirely excluded from their net revenue, which consists solely of profits. But although every individual's circulating capital is part of society's, it is not on that account entirely excluded from society's net revenue. Though the entire stock in a merchant's shop cannot be counted as part of their own consumption reserve, it can be part of other people's. Those other consumers, with revenue from different sources, regularly replace the value of the merchant's goods along with a profit, without diminishing either the merchant's capital or their own.
elegant: Society's circulating capital differs from an individual's. A merchant's entire stock is excluded from their personal net revenue. But those same goods form part of other people's consumption -- they buy from the merchant using revenue from other sources, replacing the goods' value with profit, without reducing anyone's capital.
summary: While an individual's circulating capital is excluded from their personal net revenue, the same goods can be part of other people's consumption, replacing the merchant's stock with profit from other income sources -- so society's circulating capital partly constitutes collective net revenue.
distilled: An individual's circulating capital excludes from their net revenue but contributes to society's, since other people consume those goods using income from different sources.
notes: Fallacy of composition in reverse -- what's true for the individual is not true for the whole. The merchant's stock is others' consumption. Revenue flows circularly through society. Cross-reference 2.2.9. Important for understanding why circulating capital partly constitutes net revenue at the social level.

refashioned:
Money, therefore, is the only component of society's circulating capital whose maintenance can diminish net revenue.

Fixed capital and the money component of circulating capital strongly resemble each other in their effects on society's revenue.
elegant: Money alone, among all circulating capital components, diminishes net revenue through its maintenance costs. In this respect, money closely resembles fixed capital in its effect on society's revenue.
summary: Money is the only part of circulating capital that reduces society's net revenue through maintenance costs, making it functionally similar to fixed capital in its economic effects.
distilled: Money is the only circulating capital component that reduces net revenue, functioning like fixed capital in this respect.
notes: Pivotal conclusion linking money to fixed capital. Money as a necessary but costly instrument -- like machinery. This parallel sets up the entire argument for paper money as a cost-saving innovation. Cross-reference 2.2.9--10 and 2.2.12--13.

refashioned: First, just as machines and trade instruments require expense to both build and maintain -- expenses that form part of gross revenue but are deductions from net revenue -- so too does the stock of money circulating in any country require expense to both collect and maintain. Both expenses form part of gross revenue but equally represent deductions from net revenue. A certain quantity of very valuable materials -- gold and silver -- and a great deal of skilled labor, instead of adding to the consumption reserve that provides people with subsistence, comforts, and entertainment, is devoted to supporting that great but expensive instrument of commerce through which every person in society receives their proper share of goods.
elegant: Like machines, money costs resources to create and maintain -- costs that are part of gross revenue but deductions from net. Valuable gold and silver, plus the skilled labor of producing coins, support the expensive instrument of commerce rather than adding to consumable goods.
summary: Money, like machinery, requires costly resources to establish and maintain -- gold, silver, and skilled labor that could otherwise produce consumable goods. These costs form part of gross revenue but are deductions from net revenue.
distilled: Money, like machinery, absorbs valuable resources in its creation and maintenance that would otherwise produce consumable goods, reducing net revenue.
notes: First of three parallels between money and fixed capital. Both cost resources to create and maintain. Gold, silver, and minting labor as opportunity costs. Money as 'great but expensive instrument of commerce.' Cross-reference 2.2.11 and 2.2.7 on machinery maintenance costs.

refashioned: Second, just as machines and instruments of trade -- which make up fixed capital -- form no part of either gross or net revenue, neither does money. Money is the means by which society's entire revenue is distributed among its members, but it is itself no part of that revenue. The great wheel of circulation is entirely different from the goods it circulates. Society's revenue consists entirely of those goods, not of the wheel that moves them. When computing either gross or net revenue, we must always deduct the entire value of money from the total annual circulation of money and goods, because not a single penny of it can ever form part of either.
elegant: Like fixed capital instruments, money forms no part of either gross or net revenue. It distributes revenue but is not revenue itself. The wheel of circulation is distinct from the goods it circulates. When computing national revenue, the full value of money must be deducted from total circulation -- not one coin is part of the revenue it distributes.
summary: Money, like machinery, forms no part of national revenue -- it is merely the instrument that distributes revenue. The 'great wheel of circulation' must be deducted entirely when calculating either gross or net national income.
distilled: Money is the wheel of circulation, not the goods it circulates -- it distributes revenue but forms no part of it.
notes: The 'great wheel of circulation' metaphor -- one of Smith's most famous images. Money as medium, not wealth. Second parallel with fixed capital. Anticipates the distinction between real and nominal measures of economic activity. Cross-reference 2.2.12. Critical for understanding Smith's monetary theory.

refashioned:
Only the ambiguity of language makes this seem either doubtful or paradoxical. Properly explained and understood, it is nearly self-evident.

When we speak of a particular sum of money, we sometimes mean only the metal coins themselves, and sometimes we implicitly include the goods that could be obtained in exchange for them -- the purchasing power the money conveys. When we say England's circulating money has been estimated at eighteen million pounds, we refer only to the amount of metal coins various writers have calculated or supposed to be in circulation. But when we say a person is worth fifty or a hundred pounds a year, we usually mean not just the metal coins paid to them annually, but the value of goods they can purchase or consume -- their standard of living, the quantity and quality of necessities and comforts they can properly enjoy.
elegant: Only linguistic ambiguity makes this seem paradoxical. 'Money' sometimes means the metal coins, sometimes the goods they can buy. Saying England's circulation is eighteen million means the physical coins. Saying someone earns a hundred pounds a year means their purchasing power -- their standard of living in real goods and comforts.
summary: The apparent paradox that money is not revenue dissolves when we recognize the ambiguity of language: 'money' can refer either to physical coins or to the purchasing power they represent. Income stated in money terms really describes the goods one can afford.
distilled: The seeming paradox that money is not revenue dissolves once we distinguish between money as physical coins and money as a measure of purchasing power.
notes: Addresses the inevitable objection to 2.2.13. Linguistic analysis of 'money' -- nominal vs. real. Two meanings: physical medium and unit of purchasing power. The eighteen million pounds example (England's estimated circulation). Cross-reference 2.2.13. Foundation for the real vs. nominal distinction in economics.

refashioned: When we use a sum of money to refer not just to the physical coins but to implicitly include the goods obtainable in exchange, the wealth or revenue it denotes equals only one of these two values -- and the latter more properly than the former. It equals the money's worth more properly than the money itself.
elegant: When money implicitly refers to both coins and purchasing power, the true wealth it denotes is the purchasing power, not the coins -- the money's worth, not the money.
summary: When money is used to denote wealth, the real value lies in the purchasing power (what the money can buy), not in the physical coins themselves.
distilled: True wealth is the money's worth -- its purchasing power -- not the money itself.
notes: Concise restatement of the real vs. nominal distinction. 'Money's worth' vs. 'money' -- purchasing power is the true measure of wealth. Cross-reference 2.2.14. Brief but philosophically important.

refashioned: If a guinea is someone's weekly allowance, they can purchase a certain quantity of goods, comforts, and entertainments with it during the week. Their real wealth -- their real weekly income -- depends on how much or how little that quantity is. Their weekly income is certainly not equal to both the guinea and what it can buy, but only to one of these two equal values -- and to the latter more properly than the former: to the guinea's worth rather than to the guinea.
elegant: If a guinea is someone's weekly income, their real wealth is measured by what it buys, not by the coin itself. Weekly revenue equals the purchasing power of the guinea, not both the guinea and its worth combined.
summary: A person's real weekly income from a guinea pension is measured by the goods it can purchase, not by the coin itself -- the guinea's worth, not the guinea.
distilled: Real income is measured by what money buys, not by the money itself -- the guinea's worth, not the guinea.
notes: The guinea example illustrates the general principle from 2.2.15. Real vs. nominal income at the individual level. You cannot count both the money and the goods -- that would be double-counting. Cross-reference 2.2.14--15.

refashioned: If such a person's pension were paid not in gold but in a weekly note for one guinea, their revenue would surely consist not in the piece of paper but in what they could get for it. A guinea itself can be thought of as a note redeemable for a certain quantity of goods and services from all the tradespeople in the neighborhood. The recipient's revenue consists not in the gold coin but in what it can be exchanged for. If it could be exchanged for nothing, it would be worth no more than a check drawn on a bankrupt -- just a useless piece of paper.
elegant: If a pension were paid by a paper note instead of gold, revenue would clearly be what the note buys, not the paper itself. A gold coin is really just a claim on goods from local tradespeople. If it could buy nothing, it would be as worthless as a check drawn on a bankrupt.
summary: Whether income is received as gold or paper, its real value is what can be purchased with it. A gold coin is effectively a claim on goods, and if it could buy nothing, it would be as worthless as a bad check.
distilled: Money -- whether gold or paper -- derives its value entirely from what it can purchase, like a claim on goods that is worthless if it buys nothing.
notes: Gold coin as proto-banknote -- a 'bill for goods upon all tradesmen.' Equivalence of gold and paper when both are redeemable. The bankrupt check analogy. Cross-reference 2.2.16. Foreshadows the paper money discussion in 2.2.24 onward. Money has no intrinsic value beyond exchange.

refashioned: Although the weekly or yearly income of all a country's inhabitants may be paid in money, their real wealth -- their actual combined weekly or yearly income -- must always be greater or smaller in proportion to the quantity of consumable goods they can all purchase with that money. Their total revenue is clearly not equal to both the money and the consumable goods, but only to one or the other of these two values -- and to the latter more properly than to the former.
elegant: Though all incomes may be paid in money, real national wealth is measured by the consumable goods that money can buy. Total revenue equals either the money or the goods -- not both -- and the goods are the truer measure.
summary: National wealth is measured not by the money paid as income but by the total consumable goods that money can purchase, since revenue equals one or the other, not both.
distilled: A nation's real wealth is the consumable goods its money income can buy, not the money itself.
notes: Scales the individual argument (2.2.16--17) to the national level. Real national income = purchasing power in consumable goods. Anti-mercantilist -- wealth is goods, not gold. Cross-reference 2.2.14--17.

refashioned: Though we commonly express a person's income in terms of the coins paid to them annually, this is only because the amount of those coins determines the extent of their purchasing power -- the value of goods they can afford to consume each year. We still consider their revenue to consist of this purchasing power, this capacity to consume, and not of the coins that convey it.
elegant: We express income in money terms only because money measures purchasing power. Revenue truly consists of that purchasing power -- the ability to consume -- not of the coins themselves.
summary: Money is used to express income only because it measures purchasing power. True revenue is the capacity to consume goods, not the coins through which that capacity is conveyed.
distilled: Income is expressed in money only as a measure of purchasing power -- true revenue is the capacity to consume, not the coins.
notes: Summary of the argument from 2.2.14--18. Money as measurement device, not wealth itself. Revenue = purchasing power = consumption capacity. Cross-reference 2.2.15 on money's worth vs. money.

refashioned: If this is clear enough for an individual, it is even more obvious for a society. The total coins paid to an individual often exactly equal their income, making coins the simplest and best expression of its value. But the total coins circulating in a society can never equal the total revenue of all its members. Since the same guinea that pays one person's weekly pension today may pay another's tomorrow and a third person's the day after, the total coins circulating annually must always be far less in value than all the money incomes paid with them. Yet the purchasing power -- the goods that can be successively bought with all these payments as they are made -- must always exactly equal those payments in value, and so must the revenue of all the people receiving them. Revenue, therefore, cannot consist of those coins, whose total value falls so far short of total income, but in the purchasing power -- the goods that can be successively bought as the coins circulate from hand to hand.
elegant: For an individual, coins may equal income. For society, they never can -- the same guinea pays multiple people in succession, so circulating coins are far less than total incomes. Yet the goods successively purchased with those coins exactly equal total income. Revenue therefore consists not in the coins, whose total falls far short, but in the purchasing power they convey as they circulate.
