summary: While coins may equal an individual's income, the same coins circulate to pay many people, so total circulating money is always far less than national income. Revenue consists of the successive purchasing power those coins convey, not the coins themselves.
distilled: The same coins circulate to pay many incomes, so national revenue is the purchasing power they convey through successive exchanges, not the coins themselves.
notes: The velocity of money concept avant la lettre. Same guinea pays multiple people -- circulation multiplies money's effective reach. Money stock << income flow. Cross-reference 2.2.18--19. This is the strongest version of the argument that money is not wealth. Anticipates Fisher's equation of exchange (MV = PT).

refashioned: Money, therefore -- the great wheel of circulation, the great instrument of commerce -- though it forms a valuable part of capital, forms no part of a society's revenue. Though the coins annually distribute to each person the income that properly belongs to them, the coins themselves are no part of that income.
elegant: Money -- the great wheel of circulation -- is valuable capital but no part of society's revenue. The coins distribute income but are not themselves income.
summary: Money serves as the essential instrument of circulation and commerce, but despite its importance as capital, it constitutes no part of society's actual revenue.
distilled: Money is the indispensable wheel of circulation but forms no part of the revenue it distributes.
notes: Concluding statement on money and revenue. 'Great wheel of circulation' metaphor repeated. Money = capital (valuable) but not = revenue. Cross-reference 2.2.13. Transition to the third parallel between money and fixed capital.

refashioned: Third and finally, the machines and instruments that make up fixed capital share one more resemblance with the money portion of circulating capital: just as every saving in the cost of building and maintaining machines -- without reducing labor's productive powers -- improves society's net revenue, so every saving in the cost of collecting and maintaining the money supply is an improvement of exactly the same kind.
elegant: Third parallel: just as savings on machinery costs (without reducing productivity) improve net revenue, so do savings on the cost of maintaining the money supply. Both are improvements of exactly the same kind.
summary: The third parallel between money and fixed capital: reducing the cost of maintaining either one, without diminishing productive capacity, directly increases society's net revenue.
distilled: Savings on money's maintenance costs improve net revenue in exactly the same way as savings on machinery costs.
notes: Third and final parallel between money and fixed capital. Savings on either improve net revenue. This is the key premise for the paper money argument: if money costs less to maintain, net revenue rises. Cross-reference 2.2.7--8 and 2.2.11--12. Bridge to 2.2.24 on paper money.

refashioned: It is obvious enough -- and has partly been explained already -- how savings on fixed capital maintenance improve net revenue. Every business's total capital necessarily divides between fixed and circulating portions. While total capital remains the same, the smaller the one part, the larger the other must be. Since it is circulating capital that supplies materials, pays wages, and drives industry, every saving on fixed capital maintenance that does not reduce productivity must increase the fund that puts industry into motion -- and consequently the annual output of land and labor, the real revenue of every society.
elegant: When total capital is fixed, reducing fixed capital costs enlarges circulating capital. Since circulating capital funds materials, wages, and production, any savings on fixed capital maintenance (without losing productivity) directly increases the fund driving industry and thus national output.
summary: With total capital constant, savings on fixed capital maintenance directly enlarge the circulating capital available for materials, wages, and production, thereby increasing national output and real revenue.
distilled: Savings on fixed capital maintenance free up circulating capital for production, directly increasing national output.
notes: The mechanism explained: fixed capital savings -> more circulating capital -> more production -> more revenue. Zero-sum allocation between fixed and circulating capital. Cross-reference 2.2.7--8 and 2.2.22. Sets up the argument that cheaper money (paper) frees resources for production.

refashioned: Replacing gold and silver money with paper money substitutes a very expensive instrument of commerce with a much cheaper one that is sometimes equally convenient. Commerce comes to be carried on by a new wheel that costs less both to build and to maintain than the old one. But how exactly this works, and how it tends to increase either gross or net revenue, is not entirely obvious and therefore requires some further explanation.
elegant: Paper money replaces the expensive gold and silver wheel of commerce with a far cheaper one, sometimes equally convenient. But how this substitution increases national revenue requires further explanation.
summary: Paper money replaces the costly gold and silver monetary system with a cheaper alternative, potentially increasing national revenue, though the mechanism requires detailed explanation.
distilled: Paper money substitutes a cheaper wheel of circulation for the expensive gold and silver one, potentially increasing national revenue.
notes: Pivotal transition to paper money and banking. Paper as cheaper 'wheel of circulation.' Builds directly on the fixed capital/money parallel (2.2.22--23). The rest of Chapter 2 explores how this substitution works and its limits. Cross-reference 2.2.7 on cheaper machinery.

refashioned:
There are several kinds of paper money, but bank notes -- the circulating notes of banks and bankers -- are the most common and seem best suited for this purpose.

When the public has enough confidence in a particular banker's wealth, integrity, and judgment to believe they will always honor their promissory notes on demand, those notes come to circulate as freely as gold and silver money, precisely because people trust that the metal can be obtained for them at any time.
elegant: Among paper money types, bank notes are most common and best suited for replacing metal currency. When the public trusts a banker's wealth, integrity, and prudence enough to believe their notes will always be redeemed on demand, those notes circulate like gold and silver -- because people know the metal is always available.
summary: Bank notes are the primary form of paper money. They circulate like gold and silver when the public trusts the issuing banker's ability and willingness to redeem them for metal on demand.
distilled: Bank notes circulate as money when the public trusts the issuer will always redeem them for gold and silver on demand.
notes: Trust and confidence as the foundation of paper money. Banker's 'fortune, probity, and prudence' -- the three pillars. Paper money's value derives from convertibility promise. Cross-reference 2.2.24. Foundation for fractional reserve banking discussion in 2.2.26.

refashioned: Suppose a banker lends out a hundred thousand pounds in their own promissory notes. Since these notes serve all the purposes of money, borrowers pay the same interest as if they had received actual cash. This interest is the source of the banker's profit. Although some notes are continually returned for payment, others keep circulating for months and years. So even though the banker generally has a hundred thousand pounds in notes in circulation, twenty thousand pounds in gold and silver may often be sufficient to meet the occasional demands for redemption. Through this arrangement, twenty thousand pounds in gold and silver do the work that a hundred thousand could otherwise perform. The same exchanges can be made, the same quantity of consumable goods circulated and distributed, using promissory notes worth a hundred thousand pounds as would require an equal value in gold and silver. Eighty thousand pounds' worth of gold and silver can thus be freed from the country's circulation. And if many banks and bankers carry on similar operations simultaneously, the entire circulation might be conducted with only a fifth of the gold and silver that would otherwise be needed.
elegant: A banker lending 100,000 pounds in notes earns interest as if lending gold. But with 100,000 in notes circulating, only 20,000 in gold may suffice for redemption demands. Thus 20,000 in metal does the work of 100,000. The same goods circulate with paper as with gold. If many banks operate this way, circulation needs only one-fifth the previous gold and silver.
summary: Banks can circulate far more in promissory notes than they hold in gold reserves, since not all notes are redeemed at once. A banker with 100,000 pounds in notes may need only 20,000 in gold, freeing 80,000 pounds of metal from circulation -- potentially reducing the entire country's gold needs to one-fifth.
distilled: Fractional reserve banking allows paper notes to replace most gold in circulation, potentially reducing the needed metal reserves to one-fifth.
notes: Classic description of fractional reserve banking. The 5:1 ratio (100,000 notes to 20,000 gold reserve). Interest on notes as bank profit. The multiplier effect across many banks. Gold freed from circulation. Cross-reference 2.2.24--25. Foundation for the analysis in 2.2.27 of what happens to the freed gold.

refashioned: Suppose a country's total circulating money amounts to one million pounds in gold and silver, sufficient to circulate its entire annual output. Now suppose various banks issue one million in promissory notes, keeping two hundred thousand in reserves for redemption demands. This puts eight hundred thousand in gold and silver alongside one million in bank notes into circulation -- a total of 1.8 million. But the annual output required only one million to circulate before, and banking has not immediately increased that output. One million is still sufficient. Whatever is poured into this channel beyond that amount must overflow. Of the 1.8 million, eight hundred thousand is excess. It cannot be used in domestic circulation but is too valuable to sit idle. It will therefore be sent abroad to find profitable employment there. However, paper money cannot go abroad -- far from the issuing banks and outside the jurisdiction where it is legally redeemable, no one will accept it for payment. So eight hundred thousand in gold and silver will be exported, and the domestic channel of circulation will be filled with one million in paper instead of the one million in metal that previously filled it.
elegant: If a country needs one million to circulate its output and banks issue one million in notes (keeping 200,000 in reserve), 800,000 in gold becomes surplus. Total circulation would be 1.8 million, but only one million is needed. The excess cannot circulate domestically, and paper cannot go abroad. So 800,000 in gold is exported, and paper fills the domestic channel that metal once occupied.
summary: When banks issue paper money equal to the needed circulation, the gold it replaces becomes surplus. Since paper cannot circulate internationally but gold can, the excess metal is exported abroad, leaving domestic circulation filled entirely by paper money.
distilled: Paper money displaces gold from domestic circulation, and since only gold is accepted internationally, the surplus metal is exported to find profitable use abroad.
notes: The 'channel of circulation' metaphor -- fixed capacity that overflows. Paper displaces gold domestically; gold goes abroad. Key mechanism: paper is local, gold is international. Quantitative example: 1M needed, 1.8M poured in, 800K overflows. Cross-reference 2.2.26. Leads to 2.2.28--31 on what happens to exported gold.

refashioned: But though such a large quantity of gold and silver is sent abroad, we should not imagine it is sent for nothing or given away as a gift to foreign nations. It will be exchanged for foreign goods of some kind, to supply consumption either in some other foreign country or at home.
elegant: The exported gold is not given away -- it is exchanged for foreign goods, supplying consumption either in other countries or at home.
summary: Gold displaced by paper money and sent abroad is not lost but exchanged for foreign goods, serving either foreign trade or domestic consumption.
distilled: Exported gold is exchanged for foreign goods, not given away -- it remains productively employed abroad.
notes: Counters the mercantilist fear that gold exports mean wealth loss. Gold is exchanged, not donated. Cross-reference 2.2.27. Sets up the two possible uses of exported gold in 2.2.29--30.

refashioned: If the exported gold is used to buy goods in one foreign country for sale in another -- the carrying trade -- any profit earned is a net addition to the home country's revenue. It functions like a new fund created for conducting a new trade: domestic business is now handled by paper, while the gold has been converted into capital for this new international commerce.
elegant: If exported gold finances the carrying trade -- buying in one country to sell in another -- the profit is pure addition to national revenue. Paper handles domestic trade; the freed gold becomes capital for new international commerce.
summary: Gold displaced into the carrying trade generates profits that are pure additions to national revenue, as paper money handles domestic circulation while the freed metal finances new international commerce.
distilled: Freed gold employed in the carrying trade adds net new revenue to the national economy.
notes: First of three possible uses for exported gold. Carrying trade profits as net additions. Paper domestically, gold internationally -- a division of monetary labor. Cross-reference 2.2.27--28. The most favorable outcome for exported gold.

refashioned: If the exported gold is used to purchase foreign goods for domestic consumption, there are two possibilities. First, it may buy goods likely to be consumed by idle people who produce nothing -- such as foreign wines, silks, and other luxuries. Or second, it may purchase additional materials, tools, and provisions to employ more productive workers who reproduce the value of what they consume, with a profit.
elegant: If exported gold buys foreign goods for home consumption, it may either purchase luxuries consumed by the idle and unproductive, or it may buy materials, tools, and provisions to employ additional productive workers who reproduce their consumption value with profit.
summary: Gold used to import goods for domestic consumption can either fund luxury consumption by the unproductive or purchase productive inputs -- materials, tools, and provisions -- that employ workers whose output exceeds their consumption.
distilled: Imported goods bought with freed gold either feed unproductive luxury consumption or supply productive industry that generates returns.
notes: The productive vs. unproductive consumption distinction applied to imports. Two possible outcomes: luxury waste or productive investment. Cross-reference 2.2.29. Developed further in 2.2.31. Links to Book II, Ch. 3 on productive vs. unproductive labor.

refashioned:
Insofar as the freed gold is spent on luxuries for idle consumers, it encourages extravagance, increasing consumption without increasing production or establishing any lasting fund to support that consumption. This is harmful to society in every way.

Insofar as it is spent on productive inputs, it promotes industry. Though it increases consumption, it provides a permanent fund to sustain that consumption, since the workers consuming these goods reproduce the full value of what they consume, with a profit. The gross revenue of society increases by the entire value that these workers' labor adds to the materials they work on, and the net revenue increases by whatever remains after deducting the cost of maintaining their tools and instruments.
elegant: Spending freed gold on luxuries for the idle promotes waste without creating any lasting productive capacity -- purely harmful. Spending it on productive inputs promotes industry and, though consumption rises, it is self-sustaining: workers reproduce their consumption's value with profit. Gross revenue grows by the full value added; net revenue grows by what remains after tool maintenance.
summary: Gold spent on luxury imports is purely wasteful, but gold spent on productive materials and labor creates self-sustaining growth: workers reproduce the value of their consumption with profit, increasing both gross and net national revenue.
distilled: Freed gold spent productively creates self-sustaining industry where workers reproduce their consumption with profit, while gold spent on luxury is purely wasteful.
notes: Productive vs. unproductive spending fully developed. Prodigality vs. industry. Self-sustaining production as the key criterion. Gross vs. net revenue increase distinguished. Cross-reference 2.2.30, 2.2.5 on net revenue. Links to Ch. 3 on saving vs. spending.

refashioned: The greater part of gold and silver pushed abroad by banking will most likely be employed in buying productive goods rather than luxuries for domestic consumption -- and this is not merely probable but almost unavoidable. Although some individuals may greatly increase their spending without any increase in income, we can be confident that no class or group of people as a whole does so, because the principles of ordinary prudence, while not always governing every individual, always influence the majority within any class. The income of idle people as a class cannot be increased by banking operations, so their spending as a group will not significantly increase either, even if a few individuals among them spend more. The demand from idle consumers for foreign goods remains about the same as before. Therefore, very little of the gold forced abroad by banking and used to buy imports will go toward luxuries for the idle. The vast majority will naturally be directed toward employing industry, not maintaining idleness.
elegant: Most gold displaced by banking will fund productive imports, not luxury consumption -- this is nearly certain. Though some individuals overspend, no class as a whole does, because prudence governs the majority. Banking does not increase idle people's income as a class, so their luxury demand stays flat. The bulk of exported gold naturally flows toward funding industry.
summary: Gold displaced by banking overwhelmingly funds productive imports rather than luxury consumption, because while individual spending may be imprudent, classes as a whole are governed by prudence, and banking does not increase the income or spending power of idle consumers as a group.
distilled: Gold freed by banking mostly funds productive imports because prudence governs classes even when individuals overspend, and banking does not increase idle consumers' income.
notes: Statistical/behavioral argument: individual imprudence averages out at the class level. The 'principles of common prudence' govern majorities. Idle class income unaffected by banking. Therefore most freed gold goes to productive use. Cross-reference 2.2.30--31. Optimistic view of banking's net effects.

refashioned: When calculating how much industry a society's circulating capital can support, we must count only the portions consisting of provisions, materials, and finished goods -- the money that merely circulates these three must always be deducted. To set industry in motion, three things are needed: materials to work on, tools to work with, and wages as the incentive for work. Money is neither a material to work on nor a tool to work with. And although workers are usually paid in money, their real income -- like everyone else's -- consists not of the money itself but of what it can buy: not the metal coins, but what can be obtained for them.
elegant: Only provisions, materials, and finished goods -- not money -- determine how much industry circulating capital can support. Industry needs materials, tools, and wages. Money is none of these. Workers' real income is what money buys, not the coins themselves.
summary: A society's industrial capacity depends on its circulating capital of provisions, materials, and finished goods -- not on money, which is merely the medium of exchange. Industry requires materials, tools, and wages, and workers' real income is measured in purchasing power, not coins.
distilled: Money does not create industry -- only provisions, materials, and finished goods determine productive capacity, with money serving merely as a medium of exchange.
notes: Restatement of the real vs. nominal principle applied to industrial capacity. Money excluded from productive inputs. Three requirements for industry: materials, tools, wages. Workers' real income = purchasing power. Cross-reference 2.2.13--21. Bridges to the paper money efficiency argument.

refashioned: The amount of industry any capital can support must equal the number of workers it can supply with materials, tools, and appropriate maintenance. Money may be needed to purchase these inputs, but the quantity of industry the whole capital can sustain is certainly not equal to both the money that purchases and the materials, tools, and maintenance purchased with it -- only to one or the other of these two values, and to the latter more properly than to the former.
elegant: Capital supports industry by supplying workers with materials, tools, and maintenance. Money may purchase these, but industrial capacity equals either the money or the real inputs -- not both. It is properly measured by the inputs, not the money.
summary: Industrial capacity is measured by the real inputs capital can provide -- materials, tools, and worker maintenance -- not by the money used to purchase them, since counting both would be double-counting.
distilled: Industrial capacity equals the real inputs (materials, tools, maintenance) that capital provides, not the money used to buy them.
notes: Anti-double-counting principle applied to industrial capacity. Capital's productive capacity = real inputs, not nominal money value. Cross-reference 2.2.33 and 2.2.15--16 on the same logic applied to income. Reinforces the case for paper money substitution.

refashioned: When paper replaces gold and silver money, the quantity of materials, tools, and maintenance that circulating capital can provide may be increased by the entire value of the gold and silver that was previously tied up in purchasing them. The full value of the great wheel of circulation is added to the goods it used to circulate. The effect resembles that of a factory owner who, thanks to some mechanical improvement, replaces old machinery with cheaper equipment and adds the cost difference to their working capital -- the fund used to buy materials and pay workers' wages.
elegant: Paper money frees the full value of displaced gold and silver, adding it to productive circulating capital -- materials, tools, and wages. It is like a factory owner who replaces expensive machinery with cheaper equipment and redirects the savings into working capital.
summary: Substituting paper for gold money releases the metal's entire value into productive use, expanding the real circulating capital available for materials, tools, and wages -- analogous to a manufacturer upgrading to cheaper machinery and investing the savings in production.
distilled: Paper money frees the value of displaced gold for productive use, like a manufacturer redirecting savings from cheaper machinery into working capital.
notes: The core economic benefit of paper money: gold's value freed for production. Factory machinery upgrade analogy from 2.2.7 reprised. The 'wheel added to the goods' formulation. Cross-reference 2.2.24, 2.2.7. One of Smith's strongest arguments for paper money.

refashioned: What proportion a country's circulating money bears to its total annual output is perhaps impossible to determine. Various authors have estimated it at a fifth, a tenth, a twentieth, or a thirtieth of that value. But however small that proportion may be, since only a portion -- often a small one -- of annual output is devoted to maintaining industry, money must always bear a substantial proportion to that maintenance fund. Therefore, when paper money reduces the needed gold and silver to perhaps a fifth of the former amount, if even the greater part of the other four-fifths is added to the fund supporting industry, it must create a very significant addition to the quantity of industry and consequently to the value of annual output.
elegant: Though the exact ratio of circulating money to annual output is uncertain (estimated at 1/5 to 1/30), money is always a significant fraction of the fund maintaining industry. If paper reduces gold needs to one-fifth and most of the freed four-fifths enters productive use, the addition to industry and annual output is very substantial.
summary: Although the ratio of money to annual output is uncertain, money is significant relative to the fund maintaining industry. Replacing four-fifths of gold with paper and redirecting those resources to production substantially increases national industry and output.
distilled: Replacing most gold with paper money and redirecting the freed metal to production significantly increases national industry and output.
notes: Quantitative argument for paper money's benefits. Uncertainty about M/Y ratio (1/5 to 1/30). But money is large relative to the industrial maintenance fund. Four-fifths potentially freed. Cross-reference 2.2.35. Transition to historical evidence in 2.2.37.

refashioned: An operation of this kind has been carried out in Scotland over the past twenty-five to thirty years through the establishment of new banking companies in nearly every considerable town and even some country villages. The effects have been precisely as described above. The country's business is now conducted almost entirely with bank notes, which are used for purchases and payments of all kinds. Silver rarely appears except as change for a twenty-shilling note, and gold even less often. Though not every bank has conducted itself blamelessly -- requiring an Act of Parliament to regulate the industry -- Scotland has clearly derived great benefit from their trade. I have heard it claimed that Glasgow's trade doubled within about fifteen years of its first banks being established, and that Scotland's trade has more than quadrupled since the two public banks were founded in Edinburgh: the Bank of Scotland, established by Act of Parliament in 1695, and the Royal Bank, by royal charter in 1727. Whether trade actually increased to this degree in so short a time I do not presume to know. If it did, the increase seems too great to be attributed solely to banking. That Scotland's trade and industry have increased considerably during this period, however, and that banks have contributed significantly to this growth, cannot be doubted.
elegant: Scotland's experience over twenty-five to thirty years proves the point. New banks established in nearly every town replaced metal with paper for almost all transactions. Despite some banks requiring parliamentary regulation, the country clearly benefited enormously. Glasgow's trade reportedly doubled within fifteen years of its first banks; Scotland's supposedly quadrupled since the Bank of Scotland (1695) and Royal Bank (1727). Whether these exact figures are accurate, Scotland's trade and industry unquestionably grew substantially, with banking contributing significantly.
summary: Scotland's banking revolution over twenty-five to thirty years replaced metal currency with paper notes, and despite some regulatory problems, clearly contributed to substantial growth in trade and industry -- with Glasgow's trade reportedly doubling and Scotland's quadrupling, though Smith notes these figures may be exaggerated.
distilled: Scotland's banking expansion replaced gold with paper money and contributed significantly to trade and industrial growth, though Smith cautiously notes the exact growth figures may be overstated.
notes: Historical case study: Scotland as paper money laboratory. Bank of Scotland (1695) and Royal Bank (1727). Glasgow trade doubling claim. Smith's characteristic empirical caution -- significant growth, but not all attributable to banking. Parliamentary regulation needed. Cross-reference 2.2.24--36 for theory. Links to 2.2.38 for quantitative data.

refashioned: The value of silver money circulating in Scotland before the Union of 1707, which was brought to the Bank of Scotland for recoining immediately afterward, amounted to 411,117 pounds, 10 shillings, and 9 pence sterling. No records exist for gold coin, but ancient mint accounts show that gold coined annually somewhat exceeded silver in value. Many people, distrusting repayment, did not bring their silver in, and some English coin was not recalled. The total pre-Union gold and silver circulation therefore cannot be estimated at less than one million sterling. This appears to have constituted nearly the whole circulation, since the Bank of Scotland's notes, though significant, were only a small fraction of the total. In the present day, Scotland's entire circulation cannot be less than two million, of which the gold and silver portion most probably does not reach half a million. Yet despite this dramatic reduction in metallic money, Scotland's real wealth and prosperity have not suffered. On the contrary, its agriculture, manufactures, and trade -- the annual output of its land and labor -- have clearly expanded.
elegant: Before the 1707 Union, Scotland's metallic circulation was at least one million sterling. Today, total circulation is at least two million, but gold and silver are probably under half a million. Despite this massive reduction in metal, Scotland's agriculture, manufactures, and trade have clearly grown -- real wealth expanded even as gold and silver shrank.
summary: Scotland's gold and silver circulation fell from about one million pounds before 1707 to under half a million, while total circulation doubled through paper money. Despite the dramatic reduction in precious metals, Scotland's real wealth, agriculture, manufactures, and trade all expanded.
distilled: Scotland's gold and silver halved while its economy grew, proving that paper money can replace metal without harming -- and indeed while promoting -- real prosperity.
notes: Quantitative historical evidence for paper money's benefits. Pre-Union metallic circulation: ~1M. Current: <500K gold/silver + paper = 2M total. Real prosperity increased despite metal decline. Cross-reference 2.2.37. Powerful empirical counter to mercantilist gold hoarding.

refashioned: Banks and bankers issue most of their promissory notes by discounting bills of exchange -- that is, by advancing money on them before they come due. They always deduct the legal interest for the period until the bill matures. When the bill is paid at maturity, it repays the bank's advance plus a clear profit from the interest. The banker, who advances not gold and silver but their own promissory notes, gains the advantage of being able to discount a greater total amount -- by the full value of their notes that experience shows typically remain in circulation. This enables them to earn interest on a correspondingly larger sum.
elegant: Banks mainly issue notes by discounting bills of exchange -- advancing money before maturity and deducting interest. At maturity, the bill repays the advance plus profit. By advancing notes instead of gold, bankers can discount far more -- by the full amount of notes in circulation -- earning interest on a much larger sum.
summary: Banks primarily issue notes through bill discounting, advancing paper money before maturity and collecting interest. Using notes instead of gold allows them to lend far more than their metal reserves, earning interest on the full amount of notes in circulation.
distilled: Banks issue notes by discounting bills of exchange, and by lending paper instead of gold, they can lend far more and earn interest on a correspondingly larger sum.
notes: Mechanics of bill discounting -- the primary banking operation. Interest deducted upfront. Self-replenishing: bills mature and repay advances. Notes vs. gold advantage: larger lending capacity. Cross-reference 2.2.26 on fractional reserves. Foundation for Scottish cash accounts discussion in 2.2.40.

refashioned: Scotland's trade, which is not very large now, was even smaller when the first two banking companies were established. They would have had little business if limited to discounting bills of exchange alone. They therefore invented another method of issuing notes: granting what they called cash accounts. This meant extending a line of credit -- say two or three thousand pounds -- to any individual who could provide two persons of undoubted credit and good landed property as guarantors that all advances, within the credit limit, would be repaid on demand with legal interest. Credit facilities of this kind exist in banking systems worldwide, I believe. But the easy repayment terms offered by Scottish banks are, as far as I know, unique to them and have perhaps been the chief reason both for those banks' great volume of business and for the benefit the country has received from it.
elegant: Scotland's early banks lacked sufficient bill-discounting business, so they invented cash accounts -- lines of credit backed by two creditworthy guarantors with landed property. Such facilities exist elsewhere, but Scotland's uniquely easy repayment terms were likely the chief cause of both the banks' success and the country's economic benefit.
summary: Scottish banks, lacking enough bills to discount, invented cash accounts -- guaranteed lines of credit with uniquely flexible repayment terms. This innovation was likely the primary driver of both the banks' commercial success and Scotland's broader economic benefits from banking.
distilled: Scottish banks invented cash accounts with flexible repayment terms, an innovation that drove both banking success and national economic benefit.
notes: Scottish financial innovation: cash accounts (lines of credit). Two guarantors with landed property required. Easy repayment terms as competitive advantage. Unique to Scotland at the time. Cross-reference 2.2.39 on bill discounting. Developed in 2.2.41--42. Precursor to modern lines of credit and overdraft facilities.

refashioned: Anyone with such a cash account who borrows a thousand pounds can repay it in installments -- twenty or thirty pounds at a time -- with the bank reducing the interest proportionally from the date of each partial payment until the whole is repaid. All merchants and nearly all businesspeople therefore find it convenient to maintain such accounts, and they actively support the banks' trade by readily accepting their notes for all payments and encouraging others to do the same. When customers need money, the banks generally advance it in their own promissory notes. Merchants pay these to manufacturers for goods, manufacturers to farmers for materials and provisions, farmers to landlords for rent. Landlords spend them with merchants for conveniences and luxuries, and merchants return them to the banks to settle their cash accounts or repay what they have borrowed. In this way, nearly all the country's monetary business is conducted through bank notes -- hence the banks' great volume of trade.
elegant: Cash account borrowers repay in installments with proportional interest reduction. This makes the accounts so convenient that nearly all businesspeople use them, promoting bank notes throughout the economy. Notes circulate through a complete cycle: banks to merchants to manufacturers to farmers to landlords and back to banks. Thus nearly all monetary business runs on paper -- explaining the banks' enormous trade volume.
summary: Scottish cash accounts allowed installment repayment with proportional interest reduction, making them universally popular among businesspeople. Bank notes circulated through the entire economic chain -- from merchants to manufacturers to farmers to landlords and back -- conducting virtually all the country's monetary business.
distilled: Cash accounts with installment repayment made bank notes universally adopted, circulating through every link in the economic chain from merchants to landlords and back.
notes: The complete circulation loop of bank notes through the economy. Installment repayment as key innovation. Universal adoption by businesspeople. The self-reinforcing cycle: acceptance breeds further acceptance. Cross-reference 2.2.40. Sets up the Edinburgh vs. London comparison in 2.2.42.

refashioned: Through these cash accounts, every merchant can prudently carry on more trade than would otherwise be possible. Consider two merchants with equal capital in the same trade, one in London and one in Edinburgh. The Edinburgh merchant can prudently conduct more business and employ more people. The London merchant must always keep a substantial sum idle in ready cash -- either in their own vault or at their banker's, who pays no interest on it -- to meet the constant demand for payments on goods bought on credit. Suppose this idle reserve averages five hundred pounds. That means the London merchant's warehouse always holds five hundred pounds less in goods than it could, reducing annual sales and profits by that amount, along with the number of people the additional stock could have employed. The Edinburgh merchant, by contrast, keeps no idle cash. When payment demands arise, they draw on their cash account at the bank, gradually repaying from ongoing sales. With the same capital, they can always keep more goods in stock, make greater profits, and give constant employment to more workers. This is the great benefit Scotland has derived from this system.
elegant: Cash accounts let Edinburgh merchants operate more efficiently than London ones. A London merchant must keep, say, 500 pounds idle for payments, reducing stock and profits accordingly. Edinburgh merchants keep nothing idle -- they draw on bank cash accounts when needed and repay gradually from sales. With equal capital, they hold more stock, earn more profit, and employ more workers.
summary: Scottish cash accounts gave Edinburgh merchants a systematic advantage over London counterparts by eliminating the need to keep cash idle for payments, allowing the same capital to support more stock, greater profits, and more employment.
distilled: Cash accounts eliminated idle cash reserves, allowing Scottish merchants to deploy their full capital productively -- more stock, more profit, more employment.
notes: Edinburgh vs. London comparison as natural experiment. Idle cash reserves as deadweight loss. Cash accounts as working capital optimization. More stock -> more sales -> more employment. Cross-reference 2.2.40--41. Quantitative example: 500 pounds freed. One of Smith's strongest arguments for Scottish banking innovation.

refashioned:
It might be argued that English bill discounting gives English merchants an equivalent advantage to Scottish cash accounts. But Scottish merchants can discount bills just as easily as English ones, and they additionally enjoy the convenience of cash accounts.

The total paper money that can easily circulate in any country can never exceed the value of the gold and silver it replaces -- that is, the amount that would circulate if there were no paper money (assuming the same level of commerce). If twenty-shilling notes are the smallest paper denomination in Scotland, then total paper currency cannot exceed the sum of gold and silver needed for all transactions of twenty shillings and above. If circulating paper ever exceeds this amount, the surplus cannot be sent abroad or absorbed domestically. It must immediately return to the banks for redemption. People would realize they held more paper than their business required, and since they cannot export paper, they would demand gold and silver for it -- which they could use abroad. This would create an immediate run on the banks for the full amount of the surplus, and any hint of reluctance to pay would intensify the panic far beyond the actual excess.
elegant: Scottish merchants enjoy both bill discounting and cash accounts -- English merchants have only the former. However, total paper money cannot exceed the gold it replaces. If twenty-shilling notes are the lowest denomination, total paper cannot exceed the gold needed for all transactions at that level and above. Any excess returns immediately to banks for redemption, since surplus paper has no foreign use. People would demand gold they can export, creating a bank run amplified by any sign of payment difficulty.
summary: Scottish merchants have the advantage of both bill discounting and cash accounts. However, paper money has a natural ceiling: it cannot exceed the gold it replaces. Any excess paper returns to banks for redemption, since it cannot be used abroad, potentially triggering bank runs if banks show reluctance to pay.
distilled: Paper money cannot exceed the gold it replaces without the surplus returning to banks for redemption, potentially triggering bank runs.
notes: Two key points: (1) Scotland's double advantage over England, (2) the natural limit on paper money. The self-correcting mechanism: excess paper returns for redemption. Bank run dynamics: reluctance amplifies panic. Twenty-shilling notes as minimum denomination. Cross-reference 2.2.26--27. Critical for understanding banking stability.

refashioned: Beyond the ordinary business expenses common to every trade -- rent, wages for servants, clerks, accountants, and so on -- the costs specific to banking consist chiefly of two items: first, the cost of keeping a large sum of money always on hand in the vaults to meet note holders' occasional redemption demands, on which the bank earns no interest; and second, the cost of replenishing those vaults as fast as they are drained by meeting those demands.
elegant: Banks face two special costs beyond ordinary business expenses: first, maintaining idle cash reserves (losing interest) to meet redemption demands; second, replenishing those reserves as fast as they are drained.
summary: Banking's two distinctive costs are maintaining idle cash reserves for note redemption (forgoing interest income) and continuously replenishing those reserves as they are depleted by redemption demands.
distilled: Banks bear two unique costs: holding idle reserves for redemption demands and continuously replenishing those reserves.
notes: The two fundamental costs of fractional reserve banking. Opportunity cost of idle reserves (lost interest). Replenishment cost. These costs become critical when banks over-issue notes. Cross-reference 2.2.26 on reserve ratios. Sets up analysis of over-issuance costs in 2.2.45--47.

refashioned: A bank that issues more paper than the country's circulation can absorb, with the excess continually returning for redemption, must increase its gold and silver reserves not merely in proportion to the excess circulation but by a much greater proportion, since notes return for payment much faster than the excess ratio would suggest. Such a bank must therefore increase the first of its two special expenses not just proportionally to the forced expansion of its business but by much more than that.
elegant: A bank over-issuing paper finds excess notes returning faster than the over-issuance ratio implies. It must therefore increase reserves disproportionately -- far beyond the simple ratio of over-issuance -- making the first banking cost escalate dramatically.
summary: When a bank issues excess paper, the surplus returns for redemption faster than proportionally, forcing the bank to hold disproportionately larger reserves and dramatically increasing the cost of maintaining its vaults.
distilled: Over-issuing paper forces a bank to hold disproportionately larger reserves because excess notes return for redemption faster than the over-issuance ratio suggests.
notes: Non-linear cost of over-issuance. Reserve requirements escalate disproportionately. Notes return faster than the excess ratio. The first cost (idle reserves) amplified. Cross-reference 2.2.44. Leads to the second cost analysis in 2.2.46.

refashioned: The vaults of such a bank, though they need to be kept much fuller, must also empty much faster than if the bank confined itself to reasonable levels of business. They require not merely greater but more constant and uninterrupted replenishment. Moreover, the coin drawn from these vaults in such large quantities cannot circulate domestically -- it replaces paper that already exceeds what domestic circulation needs, so the coin is equally surplus. Unable to sit idle, it must be exported, and this continuous gold drain further increases the difficulty and expense of finding new gold and silver to refill vaults that empty so rapidly. Such a bank must therefore increase the second of its special expenses even more than the first, in proportion to this forced expansion of business.
elegant: An over-issuing bank's vaults empty far faster, requiring constant, violent replenishment. The drained coin cannot circulate domestically (it too is surplus) and must be exported, further increasing the difficulty and cost of finding replacement gold. The second banking cost -- replenishment -- escalates even more steeply than the first.
summary: Over-issuing banks face rapidly draining vaults that require constant replenishment, while the exported surplus coin drives up the cost of acquiring replacement gold and silver, making the replenishment expense escalate even more steeply than the reserve-holding expense.
distilled: Over-issuance creates a vicious cycle: surplus coin drains abroad, making vault replenishment increasingly expensive and difficult.
notes: The second cost of over-issuance escalates even faster than the first. Vicious cycle: over-issue -> drain -> export -> scarcity -> higher replacement cost. The exported coin is surplus domestically too. Cross-reference 2.2.44--45. Leads to the numerical example in 2.2.47.

refashioned: Suppose a bank can appropriately circulate exactly forty thousand pounds in paper, and must keep ten thousand in gold and silver reserves. If this bank tries to circulate forty-four thousand, the four thousand pounds in excess will return almost as fast as it is issued. To meet redemption demands, the bank must now keep not eleven thousand but fourteen thousand pounds in reserve. It gains nothing from the interest on the four thousand in excess circulation, yet loses the entire expense of continually collecting four thousand pounds in gold and silver that flows out of its vaults as fast as it flows in.
elegant: A bank suited to circulate 40,000 pounds (keeping 10,000 in reserve) that tries to circulate 44,000 finds the excess 4,000 returning immediately. Reserves must rise from 10,000 to 14,000 -- not 11,000. The bank earns nothing on the excess 4,000 while bearing the full cost of continuously replacing gold that drains as fast as it enters.
summary: A bank over-issuing by just 10% (44,000 vs. 40,000) must increase reserves by 40% (14,000 vs. 10,000), earning no interest on the excess while bearing the full cost of continuously replacing gold that drains out immediately.
distilled: Even modest over-issuance forces disproportionate reserve increases and continuous gold replacement costs that eliminate any profit from the excess lending.
notes: Numerical example showing the non-linearity: 10% over-issue requires 40% more reserves. Zero net gain from excess circulation. Continuous replacement cost as pure loss. Cross-reference 2.2.44--46. Demonstrates why prudent banking limits paper issuance. Powerful cost-benefit argument against over-trading.

refashioned:
If every banking company had always understood and attended to its own interests, the circulation would never have been flooded with excess paper money. But not every bank understood or attended to its own interests, and the circulation has frequently been overstocked.

By issuing too much paper, with the excess continually returning for gold redemption, the Bank of England was for many years forced to coin gold at a rate of between eight hundred thousand and one million pounds per year -- averaging about eight hundred and fifty thousand. For this enormous coinage, the bank frequently had to buy gold bullion at the high price of four pounds per ounce, only to issue it as coin at three pounds, seventeen shillings, and ten and a half pence per ounce -- losing between two and a half and three percent on each coinage of this very large sum. Though the bank paid no seigniorage and the government bore the coinage cost, this public generosity did not entirely prevent the bank's losses.
elegant: Had every bank understood its own interest, circulation would never be overstocked. But many did not. The Bank of England, over-issuing for years, was forced to coin 850,000 pounds in gold annually. Buying bullion at 4 pounds per ounce and issuing coins at 3 pounds 17 shillings 10.5 pence, the bank lost 2.5--3% on massive coinages -- despite the government bearing seigniorage costs.
summary: Not all banks acted in their own interest, and the Bank of England's over-issuance forced it to coin roughly 850,000 pounds in gold annually, losing 2.5-3% on each coinage due to the spread between bullion purchase and coin issuance prices, even with government-subsidized minting.
distilled: The Bank of England's over-issuance forced costly annual gold coinages of 850,000 pounds at a 2.5-3% loss per coinage, demonstrating the real costs of imprudent paper money creation.
notes: Historical case study: Bank of England's over-issuance. 850,000 pounds annual coinage. Bullion bought at premium, issued at par -- 2.5-3% loss. Government seigniorage subsidy insufficient. Cross-reference 2.2.45--47 on costs of over-issuance. Paired with Scotch banks in 2.2.49.

refashioned: The Scottish banks, suffering from the same kind of excess, were all forced to employ agents in London to collect gold for them at a cost seldom below one and a half to two percent. This money was shipped north by wagon, insured by the carriers at an additional three-quarters percent, or fifteen shillings per hundred pounds. Even these agents could not always refill their employers' vaults fast enough. In emergencies, the banks' recourse was to draw bills of exchange on their London correspondents for the needed sum. When those correspondents later drew return bills for repayment with interest and commission, some banks -- driven to distress by their excessive circulation -- had no means of paying except by drawing a second set of bills on the same or different London correspondents. The same sum would thus make two or three round trips, with the indebted bank paying accumulated interest and commission each time. Even relatively prudent Scottish banks were sometimes forced into this ruinous practice.
elegant: Scottish banks over-issuing paper had to employ London agents to collect gold at 1.5--2% cost, plus 0.75% for insured wagon transport. When agents could not keep up, banks drew bills on London correspondents, who drew return bills with interest and commission. Desperate banks sometimes paid only by drawing second bills on the same correspondents -- the same sum making multiple costly round trips. Even prudent banks occasionally resorted to this ruinous expedient.
summary: Scottish banks suffering from over-issuance bore heavy costs: London agents at 1.5-2%, insured transport at 0.75%, and when these proved insufficient, increasingly desperate cycles of drawing and redrawing bills on London correspondents, accumulating interest and commission with each round trip.
distilled: Over-issuing Scottish banks faced escalating costs of gold procurement, ultimately resorting to ruinous cycles of drawing and redrawing bills on London correspondents.
notes: Scottish counterpart to the Bank of England story (2.2.48). Multiple cost layers: agents (1.5--2%), transport (0.75%), bill circulation costs. Drawing and redrawing as desperate measure -- foreshadows detailed explanation in 2.2.65--69. Even prudent banks affected. Cross-reference 2.2.44--48.

refashioned: The gold coin paid out by both the Bank of England and the Scottish banks in exchange for their excess paper was itself surplus to domestic needs. It was sometimes sent abroad as coin, sometimes melted down and exported as bullion, and sometimes melted and sold to the Bank of England at the premium price of four pounds per ounce. Only the newest, heaviest, and best coins were carefully selected from the overall stock -- either for export or for melting. Domestically, while they remained as coins, these heavy pieces were worth no more than worn, light ones. But abroad, or melted into bullion, they were worth considerably more.
elegant: Surplus gold redeemed from over-issuing banks was exported as coin, melted into bullion for export, or sold back to the Bank of England at the premium price. Only the newest, heaviest coins were selected -- worth no more than light ones at home, but significantly more abroad or as bullion.
summary: Excess gold redeemed from over-issuing banks was exported or melted, with only the best coins selected since heavy coins were worth more abroad or as bullion than their identical domestic face value to lighter coins.
distilled: Gresham's Law in action: excess gold from over-issuance was culled for its best coins, which were exported or melted because they were worth more as bullion than as currency.
notes: Gresham's Law: bad money drives out good. Heavy coins selected for export/melting while light coins stay domestic. Three fates for surplus gold: export as coin, export as bullion, sold to Bank of England at premium. Arbitrage between face value and metal value. Cross-reference 2.2.48--49.

refashioned: The Bank of England, despite its enormous annual coinage, found to its astonishment that there was the same scarcity of good coin every year as the year before. Despite the great quantity of new, high-quality coin issued annually, the overall state of the coinage kept getting worse, not better. Every year they had to coin nearly the same amount as before, and as the continual wearing and clipping of coins kept pushing up the price of gold bullion, the cost of this great annual coinage grew larger and larger every year.
elegant: Despite massive annual recoinage, the Bank of England found perpetual coin scarcity and deteriorating coin quality. New coins vanished as fast as they were issued, bullion prices rose from continued wear and clipping, and coinage costs escalated year after year.
summary: The Bank of England's enormous annual recoinage efforts were futile: good coins disappeared as fast as they were minted, the overall coin quality kept declining, and rising bullion prices made each year's coinage more expensive than the last.
distilled: The Bank of England's massive annual recoinage was a Sisyphean task -- new coins vanished immediately while deteriorating currency and rising bullion prices made each year's coinage costlier.
notes: Futility of fighting Gresham's Law with recoinage. New good coins immediately selected and removed (see 2.2.50). Rising bullion prices from debasement. Escalating costs. The 'astonishment' of the Bank -- institutions slow to understand systemic dynamics. Cross-reference 2.2.48, 2.2.50.

refashioned: The Bank of England, it should be noted, by supplying its own vaults with coin, was indirectly obliged to supply the entire kingdom. Coin continually flowed from its vaults into the wider economy through many channels. Whatever coin was needed to support the excessive paper circulation of both Scottish and English banks, whatever gaps this excessive circulation created in the kingdom's necessary coin supply, the Bank of England had to fill. The Scottish banks certainly all paid dearly for their own imprudence and carelessness, but the Bank of England paid dearly not only for its own imprudence but for the much greater imprudence of nearly all the Scottish banks as well.
elegant: The Bank of England, supplying its own vaults, effectively supplied the whole kingdom -- coin flowed outward through many channels. Whatever gaps the excessive paper circulation of Scottish and English banks created in the national coin supply, the Bank of England filled. The Scottish banks paid for their own imprudence, but the Bank of England paid for both its own and Scotland's far greater recklessness.
summary: The Bank of England bore the costs not only of its own over-issuance but of the entire kingdom's coin supply, including compensating for the excessive paper circulation of the Scottish banks, making it the ultimate backstop for the system's collective imprudence.
distilled: The Bank of England served as the kingdom's involuntary lender of last resort, bearing the costs of both its own and the Scottish banks' excessive paper circulation.
notes: Bank of England as de facto lender of last resort -- a role it did not choose. Moral hazard: Scottish banks' imprudence imposed costs on the Bank of England. Systemic risk from interconnected banking. Cross-reference 2.2.48--51. Anticipates Bagehot's 'Lombard Street' by a century.

refashioned:
The overtrading of some bold speculators in both parts of the united kingdom was the original cause of this excessive paper circulation.

What a bank can properly advance to a merchant or any business owner is not the whole capital they trade with, nor even a substantial part of it, but only that portion which they would otherwise be forced to keep idle in ready cash for meeting occasional payment demands. If the paper money a bank advances never exceeds this value, it can never exceed the value of gold and silver that would necessarily circulate if there were no paper money -- it can never exceed what the country's circulation can easily absorb and employ.
elegant: Bold speculators' overtrading caused the excessive paper circulation. A bank should advance to any merchant only the cash they would otherwise keep idle for payment demands -- not their whole capital or any large part of it. Paper money kept within this limit can never exceed the gold it replaces or the circulation's natural capacity.
summary: Excessive paper circulation originated from speculators' overtrading. Banks should only advance the amount a merchant would otherwise hold as idle cash reserves, which keeps paper money within the bounds of what the economy can naturally absorb.
distilled: Banks should advance only the idle cash portion of a merchant's capital -- this natural limit prevents paper money from exceeding what circulation can absorb.
notes: Root cause identified: speculative overtrading. The 'real bills' doctrine emerges: lend only against idle cash, not total capital. Natural limit on paper money = gold it replaces. Cross-reference 2.2.43 on circulation limits. Foundation for the real bills vs. fictitious bills distinction in 2.2.54.

refashioned: When a bank discounts a genuine bill of exchange -- drawn by a real creditor on a real debtor, and actually paid by that debtor when due -- it merely advances a portion of value that the merchant would otherwise have to keep on hand in idle cash for meeting occasional demands. The bill's payment at maturity repays the bank's advance plus interest. The bank's vaults, so long as it deals only with such customers, function like a pond that always stays full: though a stream constantly flows out, an equal stream constantly flows in, requiring little or no expense to maintain the water level.
elegant: When a bank discounts a real bill of exchange -- real creditor, real debtor, actually paid at maturity -- it advances only idle cash the merchant would otherwise hold. Maturity repayment plus interest refills the bank. Its vaults resemble a self-replenishing pond: outflow always matched by inflow, requiring minimal maintenance.
summary: Discounting genuine bills of exchange is self-sustaining banking: the bank advances only what the merchant would hold as idle cash, and maturity payments automatically replenish the advance with interest, like a pond with equal inflow and outflow.
distilled: Discounting real bills is self-sustaining banking -- advances equal idle cash, maturity payments replenish reserves, and the bank's vaults stay full like a balanced pond.
notes: The 'real bills doctrine' fully stated. The water-pond metaphor -- one of Smith's most vivid analogies. Self-sustaining banking when restricted to genuine commercial bills. Real creditor, real debtor, real payment. Cross-reference 2.2.53. Contrast with fictitious bills (drawing and redrawing) in subsequent entries. Foundation of classical banking theory.

refashioned: A merchant, without overextending himself, may often need ready cash even when he has no bills to discount. When a bank not only discounts his bills but also advances him money through his cash account -- accepting gradual repayment as sales revenue comes in, on the flexible terms offered by Scottish banks -- it frees him entirely from having to keep any part of his capital sitting idle as cash reserves for unexpected demands. When those demands arise, he can meet them from his cash account. The bank, however, must watch carefully whether, over a short period of four to eight months, the total repayments it receives from a customer roughly equal the total advances it has made. If repayments generally match advances, the bank can safely continue the relationship. Though the outflow from its reserves may be large, the inflow is equally large, keeping the coffers roughly full without any special effort to replenish them. If, on the other hand, a customer's repayments consistently fall well short of the bank's advances, it cannot safely continue lending on those terms. In that case, the outflow far exceeds the inflow, and unless the bank makes extraordinary and continuous efforts to replenish its reserves, they will soon be completely drained.
elegant: A merchant often needs ready cash beyond what bill discounting provides. When a bank also extends cash account advances with flexible repayment terms, it frees the merchant from keeping idle reserves. But the bank must monitor whether each customer's repayments match its advances over short periods. Where they do, the relationship is safe -- outflows and inflows balance, and reserves stay full. Where repayments consistently fall short, the bank must stop lending or face the rapid depletion of its coffers.
summary: Banks can safely extend cash account credit to merchants whose regular repayments match the advances made to them, freeing merchants from holding idle cash reserves. But when repayments consistently fall short of advances, the bank's reserves drain rapidly and the relationship becomes unsustainable.
distilled: A bank can safely lend through cash accounts only when customer repayments consistently match the advances over short periods.
notes: Cash accounts -- a distinctive feature of Scottish banking in Smith's era -- functioned as early revolving credit facilities. -- The metaphor of streams flowing in and out of coffers illustrates what modern banking calls liquidity management. -- This passage develops the principle that sound banking replaces only the idle cash reserves a merchant would otherwise hold, not the merchant's entire working capital. -- Cross-reference: 2.2.56-2.2.60 elaborate on the Scottish banks' enforcement of this principle.

refashioned: The Scottish banking companies, accordingly, were for a long time very careful to require frequent and regular repayments from all their customers. They refused to deal with anyone -- regardless of wealth or creditworthiness -- who did not maintain what they called frequent and regular operations with them. Beyond nearly eliminating the extraordinary cost of replenishing their reserves, this practice gave them two other considerable advantages.
elegant: Scottish banks insisted on frequent, regular repayments from all customers, regardless of their wealth or reputation, refusing to deal with those who did not comply. Besides nearly eliminating the cost of replenishing reserves, this discipline yielded two further advantages.
summary: Scottish banks required all customers to make frequent and regular repayments, regardless of personal fortune, which saved them the cost of replenishing reserves and provided two additional benefits.
distilled: Scottish banks protected themselves by insisting on frequent and regular repayments from every customer without exception.
notes: The Scottish banking system's emphasis on regular operations was an early form of credit risk management through behavioral monitoring. -- This prudential practice distinguished Scottish banks from many English counterparts and contributed to their relative stability. -- Cross-reference: 2.2.57-2.2.58 detail the two advantages gained.

refashioned: First, this practice enabled them to form a reasonable judgment about whether their borrowers were thriving or declining, using no evidence beyond their own account books. People generally make regular or irregular repayments depending on whether their circumstances are improving or deteriorating. A private lender who has lent to perhaps six or twelve borrowers can personally monitor each one's conduct and situation, either directly or through agents. But a banking company that has lent to perhaps five hundred people, and whose attention is constantly occupied by entirely different matters, has no regular way to assess the conduct and circumstances of most of its borrowers beyond what its own records show. In requiring frequent and regular repayments, the Scottish banks probably had this advantage in mind.
elegant: Regular repayments served as an early warning system. People repay reliably when they are thriving and erratically when they are declining. A private lender can personally monitor a handful of borrowers, but a bank with five hundred clients has no practical way to assess most of them beyond its own books. Repayment patterns thus became the bank's best diagnostic tool for borrower health.
summary: By requiring regular repayments, Scottish banks could track whether borrowers were thriving or declining through repayment patterns alone -- a crucial advantage for institutions too large to personally monitor hundreds of individual clients.
distilled: Regular repayment requirements gave banks a simple but effective way to monitor borrower health through their own account records.
notes: This is an early articulation of what modern banking calls credit monitoring through payment behavior analysis. -- Smith recognizes the information asymmetry problem: banks cannot know their borrowers as well as private lenders can, so they need systematic proxies. -- The contrast between a private lender with a dozen borrowers and a bank with five hundred anticipates modern discussions of the monitoring disadvantages of scale in financial intermediation.

refashioned: Second, this practice protected them from issuing more paper money than the country's circulation could easily absorb. When they observed that a particular customer's repayments generally equaled the advances made to him over moderate periods, they could be confident that the paper money advanced to him had never exceeded the amount of gold and silver he would otherwise have needed to keep on hand for meeting occasional demands. It followed that the paper money they had put into circulation through him had never exceeded the gold and silver that would have circulated in the country had there been no paper money at all.
elegant: Regular repayments also prevented over-issuance of paper money. When a customer's repayments matched advances over moderate periods, the bank could be sure its paper had merely replaced the gold and silver the customer would otherwise have held as reserves -- and therefore had not exceeded what the country's circulation could absorb.
summary: By tracking whether repayments matched advances, Scottish banks ensured that their paper money issuance merely replaced the gold and silver that merchants would otherwise have held in reserve, preventing them from flooding the economy with excess currency.
distilled: Matching repayments to advances ensured that paper money issuance did not exceed the gold and silver it replaced in circulation.
notes: This passage articulates what is essentially a commodity-money backing principle -- paper should substitute for, not exceed, the metallic money it displaces. -- Smith is describing an early self-regulating mechanism for monetary supply control, predating formal central banking theory. -- Cross-reference: 2.2.60 explains the consequences when this balance is violated. -- The real bills doctrine, which this reasoning supports, remained influential in monetary theory through the 19th century.

refashioned: The frequency, regularity, and size of a customer's repayments would sufficiently prove that the bank's advances had never exceeded the portion of his capital that he would otherwise have kept idle in ready money for meeting occasional demands -- that is, the portion needed to keep the rest of his capital constantly employed. This is the only part of his capital that, over moderate periods, continually returns to every dealer in the form of money, whether paper or coin, and continually leaves him in the same form.
elegant: A customer's regular repayments demonstrated that the bank's advances had merely replaced the idle cash he would otherwise have held to meet short-term demands. This idle portion is the only part of a dealer's capital that continually cycles back and forth in monetary form over moderate periods.
summary: Regular repayments proved that bank advances had only replaced the cash a merchant would have kept idle for meeting occasional demands -- the one portion of his capital that naturally cycles in and out in monetary form over short periods.
distilled: Steady repayments proved the bank had only replaced the merchant's idle cash reserves, not financed his broader capital needs.
notes: Smith refines the distinction between the cash reserve component of a merchant's capital (which naturally cycles in monetary form) and the rest of his working and fixed capital. -- This is the theoretical justification for banks replacing idle reserves with paper -- the substitution is neutral because it displaces money that was merely waiting to be spent anyway. -- Cross-reference: 2.2.55 introduces the principle; 2.2.60 addresses what happens when advances exceed this limit.

refashioned: If the bank's advances had regularly exceeded this portion of a merchant's capital, his ordinary repayments could not have equaled the bank's ordinary advances within moderate time periods. The stream flowing into the bank's coffers through his dealings could not have matched the stream flowing out. By exceeding the gold and silver the merchant would otherwise have needed on hand, the bank's paper advances could quickly surpass the total amount of gold and silver that would have circulated in the country without paper money -- and therefore exceed what the country's circulation could absorb. The excess paper would immediately return to the bank to be exchanged for gold and silver. This second advantage, though equally real as the first, was perhaps not as well understood by all the different Scottish banking companies.
elegant: Had the bank's advances exceeded a merchant's natural cash reserve needs, repayments would have fallen short of advances. The excess paper, surpassing what circulation could absorb, would have returned immediately to the bank demanding gold and silver. This second advantage of requiring regular repayments -- preventing over-issuance -- was real but perhaps less well understood by all Scottish banks than the first.
summary: When bank advances exceed what a merchant would naturally hold as cash reserves, repayments cannot keep pace, and excess paper money returns to the bank demanding gold and silver conversion. This self-correcting mechanism was not equally understood by all Scottish banks.
distilled: Excess paper money beyond what circulation can absorb inevitably returns to the issuing bank demanding conversion to gold and silver.
notes: Smith describes what is effectively the price-specie flow mechanism applied to banking -- excess paper currency is self-correcting because it returns for redemption. -- The admission that not all Scottish banks understood this principle foreshadows the over-issuance problems described in 2.2.63-2.2.84. -- This passage anticipates the quantity theory of money: there is a natural limit to how much money (paper or metal) an economy can productively employ.

refashioned: When bill discounting and cash accounts together free the creditworthy traders of a country from having to keep any capital idle as cash reserves, they have received all the assistance they can reasonably expect from banks. Banks that have gone this far cannot, consistent with their own interest and safety, go further. A bank cannot safely advance a trader the whole or even the greater part of his circulating capital -- the capital he uses in buying and selling goods. Although that capital continually returns to him as money and leaves again as money, the full cycle of returns takes too long relative to advances for a bank's needs. Even less can a bank advance any significant portion of a trader's fixed capital -- the capital an ironworks owner invests in forges, smelting houses, workshops, warehouses, and workers' housing; or that a mine operator spends on sinking shafts, building drainage engines, and constructing roads; or that a land improver puts into clearing, draining, fencing, fertilizing, and ploughing uncultivated fields, and building farmhouses with their stables and granaries.
elegant: Once bill discounting and cash accounts free traders from holding idle cash reserves, banks have given all the help they safely can. A bank cannot advance a trader's full circulating capital, since the complete cycle of outflows and returns takes too long. Still less can it fund fixed capital -- the forges, mines, drainage works, farmhouses, and land improvements whose returns come only after many years.
summary: Banks can legitimately free merchants from holding idle cash reserves through discounting and cash accounts, but they cannot safely finance a trader's circulating capital or fixed capital investments. The return cycles on these forms of capital are far too slow for banking.
distilled: Banks can replace merchants' idle cash reserves but cannot safely finance their circulating or fixed capital, whose returns take too long.
notes: Smith draws a critical boundary for prudent banking: banks should finance only the idle cash reserve portion of a merchant's capital, not the working or fixed capital. -- The examples of fixed capital (iron forges, mines, land improvement) illustrate investments with multi-year return horizons unsuited to bank lending. -- This distinction between appropriate and inappropriate bank lending anticipates the maturity matching principle in modern banking theory. -- Cross-reference: 2.1.6-2.1.9 on the distinction between fixed and circulating capital; 2.2.62 continues this argument.

refashioned: The returns on fixed capital are, in almost all cases, much slower than those on circulating capital. Such investments, even when made with the greatest prudence, rarely pay back the investor until after many years -- far too long a period for a bank. Traders and entrepreneurs may certainly finance a considerable portion of their projects with borrowed money. But in fairness to their creditors, their own capital should be large enough to insure, so to speak, the capital of those creditors -- making it extremely unlikely that lenders would suffer any loss even if the project falls far short of the entrepreneur's expectations. Even with this safeguard, money that will not be repaid for several years should not be borrowed from a bank. It should be borrowed through bonds or mortgages from private individuals who plan to live off the interest of their money without employing the capital themselves, and who are therefore willing to lend it to creditworthy people for extended periods. A bank that lends without the expense of stamped paper or attorney's fees for drafting bonds, and that accepts repayment on the flexible terms of Scottish banking companies, would certainly be a very convenient creditor for such traders and entrepreneurs.
elegant: Fixed capital returns far too slowly for bank lending. Entrepreneurs may legitimately borrow for long-term projects, but their own capital should be enough to protect their creditors from loss. Long-term borrowing should come not from banks but from private individuals who wish to live on interest income and are willing to commit their capital for years. A bank offering easy terms would certainly be convenient for such borrowers.
summary: Long-term investments in fixed capital should be financed through bonds and mortgages from private lenders, not from banks whose operations require faster repayment. The borrower's own capital should serve as a buffer protecting creditors from loss.
distilled: Long-term capital investments should be financed by private lenders through bonds and mortgages, not by banks that need faster repayment cycles.
notes: Smith articulates the maturity matching principle: short-term bank deposits should fund short-term lending, while long-term investments require long-term funding sources. -- The concept that a borrower's own capital should 'insure' the lender's capital is an early formulation of the equity cushion concept in modern corporate finance. -- The distinction between banks and bondholders as different types of creditors suited to different time horizons anticipates the modern segmentation of financial markets. -- Cross-reference: 2.2.63 delivers the punchline -- such borrowers would be terrible debtors for a bank.

refashioned:
But such traders and entrepreneurs would certainly be the most troublesome debtors a bank could have.

It has now been more than twenty-five years since the paper money issued by Scotland's various banking companies fully equaled -- or rather slightly exceeded -- what the country's circulation could easily absorb and employ. Those companies had therefore long ago provided all the assistance to Scottish traders and entrepreneurs that banks can possibly give while remaining consistent with their own interests. They had even gone somewhat further, having over-traded a little and suffered the losses, or at least the reduced profits, that invariably accompany even the slightest degree of over-trading in this business. Yet having received so much assistance from banks, these traders and entrepreneurs wanted still more.
elegant: Such borrowers would be the worst possible debtors for a bank. For over twenty-five years, Scottish banks had already issued paper money equal to or slightly exceeding what circulation could absorb. They had given all the assistance prudent banking allows -- and even a little more, suffering the inevitable losses from over-trading. Yet the traders they had helped wanted still more.
