summary: Long-term borrowers would be the worst debtors for a bank. Scottish banks had already issued as much paper money as the economy could absorb and had even slightly overextended themselves, yet the traders they assisted demanded even greater credit.
distilled: Scottish banks had already lent to the limit of what was prudent, and even slightly beyond, yet traders demanded still more credit.
notes: Smith dates this passage to roughly 1750, placing it about twenty-five years before the publication of Wealth of Nations (1776). -- The observation that even slight over-trading in banking inevitably produces losses anticipates the modern understanding of how narrow banking profit margins are. -- This sets up the narrative of the Ayr Bank crisis (2.2.78-2.2.84), one of the 18th century's most instructive banking failures. -- Cross-reference: 2.2.64-2.2.65 describe the traders' complaints and their resort to bills of circulation.

refashioned: The banks, these traders seemed to believe, could extend credit to any amount needed at no cost beyond a few reams of paper. They complained about the narrow-mindedness and cowardice of bank directors who refused, they said, to extend credit in proportion to the growth of the country's trade. By the growth of trade, of course, they really meant the expansion of their own projects beyond what they could finance with their own capital or with what they could borrow from private lenders through bonds and mortgages.
elegant: The traders believed banks could extend unlimited credit at the cost of mere paper. They accused directors of narrow-mindedness for not expanding credit to match the country's growing trade -- by which they really meant the expansion of their own projects beyond what their own capital or private borrowing could support.
summary: Overextended traders blamed banks for timidity, believing credit could be expanded limitlessly at trivial cost, when in reality they simply wanted financing beyond what their own capital and private borrowing could provide.
distilled: Overextended traders accused prudent bankers of cowardice, confusing the expansion of their own speculative projects with the growth of national trade.
notes: Smith identifies a recurring pattern in financial crises: speculators blame prudent lenders for economic distress rather than acknowledging their own overextension. -- The belief that banks can create credit at will (the cost of 'a few reams of paper') reflects a misunderstanding of banking that Smith is at pains to correct. -- This passage resonates with modern critiques of easy-money advocates who pressure central banks to maintain loose policy. -- Cross-reference: 2.2.77 describes the same complaint from the speculators' perspective.

refashioned: These traders seemed to believe the banks were honor-bound to make up the shortfall and provide them with all the capital they needed for their ventures. The banks, however, disagreed. When they refused to extend further credit, some of these traders turned to an expedient that served their purpose for a time -- at much greater expense, but just as effectively as the fullest extension of bank credit could have done. This expedient was the well-known device of drawing and redrawing bills of exchange: the last resort of desperate traders on the brink of bankruptcy.
elegant: The traders felt banks were obligated to supply all the capital they needed. When banks refused, some traders turned to an expensive but effective alternative: the well-known device of drawing and redrawing bills of exchange -- the last resort of merchants on the brink of bankruptcy.
summary: When banks refused to extend further credit, desperate traders resorted to the practice of drawing and redrawing fictitious bills of exchange -- an expensive scheme typically used by merchants approaching bankruptcy.
distilled: Refused further bank credit, desperate traders turned to drawing and redrawing fictitious bills of exchange -- a practice associated with impending bankruptcy.
notes: Drawing and redrawing (also called accommodation bills or kite-flying) involves creating fictitious bills of exchange between parties who owe each other nothing, purely to raise cash through discounting. -- Smith characterizes this as a practice of desperation, though it was widely used in 18th-century British commerce. -- This practice is a form of what modern finance would call Ponzi financing -- borrowing to pay off existing debts. -- Cross-reference: 2.2.67-2.2.69 provide a detailed explanation of the mechanics.

refashioned: This method of raising money had long been known in England. During the recent war, when high trading profits tempted many into overextension, it was reportedly practiced on a very large scale. From England it was brought to Scotland, where, relative to the country's much more limited trade and more modest capital, it was soon practiced on a far greater scale than it had ever been in England.
elegant: Drawing and redrawing was long known in England and reportedly became widespread during wartime, when high profits tempted overextension. Imported into Scotland, it was practiced on a proportionally far greater scale, given the country's more limited commerce and capital.
summary: The practice of raising money through fictitious bills of exchange, already common in wartime England, was adopted in Scotland where it reached even greater proportions relative to the country's smaller economy and capital base.
distilled: The practice of drawing and redrawing bills, already widespread in England, spread to Scotland where it became proportionally even more excessive.
notes: The 'late war' refers to the Seven Years' War (1756-1763), which generated high wartime profits that fueled speculation. -- Smith notes that the same financial innovation causes proportionally greater damage in smaller, less capitalized economies -- an observation relevant to modern emerging market financial crises. -- The transmission of speculative practices from larger to smaller financial centers is a recurring pattern in financial history.

refashioned: The practice of drawing and redrawing is so well known to all businesspeople that it might seem unnecessary to explain it. But since this book may reach many readers who are not businesspeople, and since even businesspeople may not fully understand the effects of this practice on banking, I shall try to explain it as clearly as I can.
elegant: Though drawing and redrawing is familiar to businesspeople, its effects on banking are not well understood even by them, so a clear explanation is warranted.
summary: Smith offers to explain the mechanics of drawing and redrawing for general readers, noting that even business professionals may not fully grasp its effects on the banking system.
distilled: Smith provides a detailed explanation of drawing and redrawing because its effects on banking are widely misunderstood.
notes: This transitional passage reveals Smith's pedagogical intent -- the Wealth of Nations was aimed at a broad audience, not just specialists. -- His willingness to explain technical financial practices reflects his belief that public understanding of economics is essential for sound policy. -- Cross-reference: 2.2.68-2.2.69 provide the promised explanation.

refashioned: The customs of merchants, established when Europe's primitive laws did not enforce commercial contracts, and adopted into the laws of all European nations over the past two centuries, have given extraordinary legal privileges to bills of exchange. Money is more readily advanced on a bill of exchange than on any other type of obligation, especially when the bill is payable within two or three months. If the acceptor fails to pay when the bill comes due, he immediately becomes a bankrupt. The bill is protested and falls back on the drawer, who likewise becomes a bankrupt if he does not pay at once. If the bill has passed through the hands of several people who successively advanced its value to one another in money or goods -- each endorsing the bill by writing their name on the back to acknowledge receipt -- then each endorser in turn becomes liable for the full amount, and becomes a bankrupt upon failure to pay. Even when the drawer, acceptor, and all endorsers are persons of doubtful credit, the shortness of the payment term provides some security. They may all be likely to go bankrupt, but the odds are against them all going bankrupt within so short a time. As a weary traveler says to himself: the house is falling apart and will not stand much longer, but it probably will not collapse tonight, so I will risk sleeping in it.
elegant: Merchant custom, now enshrined in law, gives bills of exchange extraordinary legal privileges. Non-payment at maturity immediately makes the acceptor a bankrupt; liability then cascades to the drawer and every endorser in turn. Even when all parties have doubtful credit, the bill's short maturity provides some security: though all may likely go bankrupt eventually, the odds of them all failing within two or three months are slim. As a weary traveler reasons about a crumbling house: it will collapse eventually, but probably not tonight.
summary: Bills of exchange carry exceptional legal privileges: non-payment triggers immediate bankruptcy for the acceptor, drawer, and endorsers in succession. Even among parties of doubtful credit, the short maturity period provides some security, since the odds of all failing within months are low.
distilled: Bills of exchange carry extraordinary legal enforcement -- non-payment triggers cascading bankruptcy -- and their short maturity provides security even among unreliable parties.
notes: Smith traces the legal privileges of bills of exchange to medieval merchant law (lex mercatoria), which developed independently of state law to facilitate international trade. -- The cascading liability structure (acceptor, drawer, endorsers) created multiple layers of credit support, making bills the most trusted commercial instrument of the era. -- The 'crazy house' metaphor vividly captures the logic of short-term lending to risky borrowers -- a logic that recurs in modern money market behavior. -- These legal privileges made bills of exchange the vehicle through which fictitious credit (drawing and redrawing) could be created.

refashioned: Suppose trader A in Edinburgh draws a bill on B in London, payable in two months. In reality, B owes nothing to A, but he agrees to accept A's bill on the condition that, before it comes due, he will draw a new bill on A in Edinburgh for the same amount plus interest and a commission, also payable in two months. Before the first two months expire, B redraws this bill on A, who in turn, before the next two months expire, draws yet another bill on B, also payable in two months -- and so on. This practice sometimes continued not just for months but for years, with each bill returning to A carrying the accumulated interest and commissions of all previous bills. At five percent annual interest and at least half a percent commission per bill, with the cycle repeating more than six times a year, the money A raised this way necessarily cost him upwards of eight percent annually -- and often considerably more when the commission rate rose or when he had to pay compound interest on the accumulated charges from earlier bills. This practice was called raising money by circulation.
elegant: Trader A in Edinburgh draws a bill on B in London, payable in two months. B owes A nothing but accepts, on the condition that B will redraw on A before the due date for the same sum plus interest and commission. This cycle repeats indefinitely, each bill accumulating the charges of all previous ones. At five percent annual interest and at least half a percent commission per cycle -- repeated over six times yearly -- the cost exceeded eight percent, and often far more with compounding. This was called raising money by circulation.
summary: In raising money by circulation, two traders who owe each other nothing exchange fictitious bills every two months, each new bill carrying accumulated interest and commission. The practice cost borrowers over eight percent annually, often much more with compounding.
distilled: Raising money by circulation involved exchanging fictitious bills between two parties at escalating cost, typically exceeding eight percent per year with compounding.
notes: Smith provides one of the clearest 18th-century descriptions of accommodation bill financing. -- The cost structure (5% interest plus compounding commissions) shows how this practice could quickly become ruinous -- anticipating the dynamics of modern payday lending and other expensive short-term credit. -- The term 'raising money by circulation' itself reveals the fictitious nature of the practice -- the 'circulation' is of paper obligations, not genuine trade. -- Cross-reference: 2.2.71-2.2.72 describe even more expensive variants of this practice.

refashioned: In a country where ordinary mercantile profits generally run between six and ten percent, a speculation would have to be extraordinarily fortunate to not only cover the enormous borrowing cost of raising money this way, but also generate a good surplus profit for the speculator. Nevertheless, many vast and ambitious projects were launched and sustained for years on no other funding than what was raised at this ruinous expense. The speculators undoubtedly saw grand profits in their golden dreams. Upon waking, however -- either when their projects ended or when they could no longer sustain them -- they very rarely, I believe, had the good fortune to find those profits.
elegant: With normal mercantile profits running six to ten percent, only an extraordinarily successful venture could cover borrowing costs exceeding eight percent and still yield a surplus. Yet many ambitious projects were sustained for years on nothing but money raised at this ruinous expense. The speculators dreamed of great profits but rarely found them when they finally awoke.
summary: Since ordinary business profits ranged from six to ten percent, very few ventures could generate enough returns to cover the eight-percent-plus cost of raising money by circulation. Yet many ambitious projects were sustained for years on this ruinous financing, and the expected profits almost never materialized.
distilled: Most speculative projects financed through bill circulation could never generate enough profit to cover borrowing costs that exceeded ordinary business returns.
notes: Smith identifies the fundamental arithmetic problem of speculative finance: when borrowing costs exceed normal returns, only exceptional outcomes can justify the risk. -- The 'golden dreams' metaphor captures the psychology of speculative bubbles -- overconfidence in projected returns while ignoring financing costs. -- This analysis anticipates Hyman Minsky's framework of speculative and Ponzi finance, where borrowers depend on ever-rising asset values to service debt. -- Cross-reference: 2.2.82-2.2.83 show the ultimate consequences when these speculations failed.

refashioned: The method described above was by no means the most common or the most expensive way these adventurers raised money by circulation. It frequently happened that A in Edinburgh would enable B in London to pay the first bill of exchange by drawing, a few days before it came due, a second bill at three months on the same B in London. This bill, payable to A's own order, was sold in Edinburgh at par, and the proceeds were used to buy bills on London payable at sight to B's order, which were sent to B by post. Toward the end of the recent war, the exchange between Edinburgh and London frequently ran at three percent against Edinburgh, making these sight bills cost A that premium. This transaction, repeated at least four times a year and loaded with at least half a percent commission each time, must have cost A at least fourteen percent annually. At other times, A would enable B to discharge the first bill by drawing, a few days before it came due, a second bill at two months -- not on B, but on some third person, C, in London. This bill was made payable to B's order. Upon its acceptance by C, B discounted it with a London banker. A then enabled C to discharge it by drawing, a few days before maturity, a third bill at two months, sometimes on B again and sometimes on a fourth or fifth person, D or E. This third bill was made payable to C's order, who discounted it in the same manner with a London banker as soon as it was accepted.
elegant: The method described was not the most common or costly variant. A might draw a second bill on B a few days before the first came due, sell it at par in Edinburgh, and use the proceeds to buy London sight bills for B -- paying a three percent exchange premium each time. Repeated four times yearly with commissions, this cost at least fourteen percent annually. Alternatively, A might draw on a third party C instead of B, with C discounting the bill in London, and A then drawing further bills on D or E to cover C -- creating a widening circle of fictitious obligations.
summary: More expensive variants of bill circulation involved buying sight bills at an exchange premium or routing obligations through networks of third parties. The sight-bill method cost at least fourteen percent annually, while the multi-party method spread fictitious obligations across an ever-widening circle.
distilled: More complex variants of bill circulation involved exchange premiums and widening circles of third-party obligations, sometimes costing fourteen percent annually or more.
notes: This is presented as an editorial footnote in the original text, indicated by the curly braces. -- The three percent exchange differential between Edinburgh and London reflects the relative weakness of Scottish credit during wartime. -- The multi-party variant (drawing on C, D, E) shows how financial complexity was used to obscure the fictitious nature of the transactions -- a pattern recurring in modern structured finance. -- Cross-reference: 2.2.75 describes how these circular networks made it difficult for bankers to detect fictitious bills.

refashioned: Such operations, repeated at least six times a year and loaded with at least half a percent commission on each repetition, plus the legal interest of five percent, must have cost A something over eight percent by this method as well. However, by avoiding the exchange between Edinburgh and London, it was less expensive than the method described in the preceding note. But it required an established credit relationship with more than one house in London -- an advantage that many of these adventurers could not always easily obtain.
elegant: This multi-party method, repeated six times yearly with commissions and five percent interest, cost over eight percent annually. Though cheaper than the sight-bill method because it avoided exchange premiums, it required credit relationships with multiple London houses -- not always easy for these adventurers to obtain.
summary: The multi-party method of bill circulation cost over eight percent annually but was cheaper than the sight-bill variant because it avoided exchange premiums. However, it required the adventurer to maintain credit with multiple London firms.
distilled: The multi-party circulation method cost over eight percent annually and required credit relationships with multiple London houses.
notes: This continues the editorial footnote from 2.2.71. -- The tradeoff between cost and complexity is noteworthy: cheaper methods required wider networks of complicit partners. -- The difficulty of obtaining credit with multiple London houses served as a natural constraint on the practice -- an informal market discipline.

refashioned: The bills that A in Edinburgh drew on B in London were regularly discounted two months before maturity with some bank or banker in Edinburgh. The bills that B in London redrew on A in Edinburgh were likewise discounted, either with the Bank of England or with some other London banker. Whatever was advanced on these circulating bills was advanced in Edinburgh as Scottish bank notes and in London as Bank of England notes. Although the bills on which this paper had been advanced were all individually repaid when they came due, the value originally advanced on the first bill was never truly returned to the banks. Before each bill matured, another was always drawn for a somewhat larger amount, and the discounting of this new bill was essential to paying the one about to come due. These payments were therefore entirely fictitious. The stream that had been made to flow out of the banks' coffers through these circulating bills was never replaced by any stream that truly flowed back in.
elegant: A discounted his bills with Edinburgh banks; B discounted his with the Bank of England or London bankers. Although each individual bill was repaid at maturity, the underlying value was never truly returned -- because before each bill came due, a new, larger bill was drawn, and discounting it was essential to paying the old one. The repayments were therefore entirely fictitious. The money that flowed out of the banks' coffers through these circulating bills never truly flowed back.
summary: Though each individual circulating bill was technically repaid at maturity, the repayment came from discounting a new, larger bill -- making the payments entirely fictitious. The banks that advanced the money never received genuine repayment; the outflow from their coffers was never matched by a real inflow.
distilled: Repayments on circulating bills were fictitious because each was funded by discounting a new, larger bill -- the banks never received genuine repayment.
notes: Smith reveals the Ponzi-like structure at the heart of bill circulation: each 'repayment' is actually funded by new borrowing, with increasing amounts required each cycle. -- The involvement of both Scottish banks and the Bank of England shows how the practice transmitted risk across the entire British financial system. -- The stream metaphor recurs from 2.2.55-2.2.60, but here the stream running in is revealed as illusory. -- This is one of the earliest clear analyses of what modern finance calls a rollover risk or refinancing spiral.

refashioned: The paper money issued against these circulating bills often amounted to the entire fund intended for some vast project of agriculture, commerce, or manufacturing -- not merely the portion the speculator would have needed to keep as idle cash reserves. The greater part of this paper therefore exceeded the gold and silver that would have circulated without paper money. It exceeded what the country's circulation could absorb, and immediately returned to the banks to be exchanged for gold and silver, which the banks then had to find however they could. This was capital that the speculators had very cleverly extracted from the banks, not only without their knowledge or deliberate consent, but for some time perhaps without their having the slightest suspicion that they had actually advanced it.
elegant: The paper issued on circulating bills often financed entire speculative projects, not just the idle reserves that paper was meant to replace. This excess paper inevitably returned to the banks demanding gold and silver. The speculators had cleverly extracted capital from the banks without their knowledge, consent, or even suspicion.
summary: Paper money issued against circulating bills often financed entire speculative ventures rather than merely replacing idle reserves, creating excess currency that returned to banks demanding gold and silver. The speculators had effectively extracted bank capital without the banks' knowledge or consent.
distilled: Circulating bills allowed speculators to extract entire project funding from unsuspecting banks, far exceeding the idle reserves paper money was meant to replace.
notes: This passage identifies what modern finance calls an agency problem: speculators used the banking system's mechanisms to extract capital for purposes the banks never intended to finance. -- The distinction between replacing idle reserves (legitimate) and financing entire projects (illegitimate) is the crux of Smith's banking theory. -- The banks' lack of awareness anticipates modern concerns about information asymmetry and the difficulty of monitoring complex financial instruments. -- Cross-reference: 2.2.55-2.2.58 established the principle that paper should only replace idle reserves.

refashioned: When two people who are continually drawing and redrawing on each other always discount their bills with the same banker, he must immediately detect what they are doing and see clearly that they are trading not with their own capital but with capital he has advanced to them. But this discovery is much harder when they discount bills with different bankers at different times, and when the same two people do not always draw and redraw on each other but instead rotate through a large circle of speculators. These speculators find it in their interest to assist one another in this method of raising money and to make it as difficult as possible to distinguish between a real and a fictitious bill of exchange -- between a bill drawn by a genuine creditor on a genuine debtor, and a bill for which the only real creditor is the discounting bank and the only real debtor is the speculator who uses the money.
elegant: When two people always discount their circulating bills with the same banker, the scheme is immediately obvious. But when they rotate among different bankers and cycle through a wide network of speculators who assist each other, it becomes nearly impossible to distinguish real from fictitious bills -- between a genuine commercial obligation and one where the only real creditor is the discounting bank and the only real debtor is the speculator.
summary: While a single banker can easily detect two clients drawing and redrawing on each other, speculators obscured their activities by rotating among multiple bankers and using networks of accomplices, making it nearly impossible to distinguish fictitious bills from genuine commercial obligations.
distilled: Speculators used networks of accomplices and rotated among bankers to disguise fictitious bills as genuine commercial obligations.
notes: Smith describes what modern finance calls obfuscation through complexity -- using networks and rotation to defeat monitoring. -- The distinction between real and fictitious bills (real bills doctrine) is central to Smith's banking theory and influenced British monetary policy debates for over a century. -- The circle of projectors cooperating to disguise fictitious paper anticipates modern concerns about collusion and interconnected counterparty risk in financial networks. -- Cross-reference: 2.2.76 describes the dilemma facing bankers who discover the scheme too late.

refashioned: Even when a banker did make this discovery, he might make it too late. He might find he had already discounted these speculators' bills to such an extent that refusing to discount any more would necessarily bankrupt them all -- and by ruining them, might perhaps ruin himself. For his own interest and safety, therefore, he might find it necessary in this extremely dangerous situation to continue for a while, though trying to withdraw gradually. He would make greater and greater difficulties about discounting in order to force these speculators, step by step, to turn to other bankers or other methods of raising money -- so that he himself could escape the circle as soon as possible.
elegant: Even after discovering the scheme, a banker might find he was already too deeply entangled to stop. Refusing further discounts would bankrupt the speculators -- and possibly himself. His only option was to gradually tighten terms, forcing the speculators toward other bankers or funding sources, while trying to extricate himself from the circle.
summary: Bankers who discovered the circulation scheme were often too deeply involved to stop abruptly, since cutting off credit would bankrupt the speculators and potentially the bank itself. Their only recourse was to gradually tighten terms while trying to escape the entanglement.
distilled: Bankers who discovered fictitious bill schemes were often too deeply entangled to stop, forced to gradually withdraw rather than risk mutual ruin.
notes: Smith describes what modern finance calls the 'too interconnected to fail' problem -- a banker trapped by his own exposure to a network of risky borrowers. -- The gradual withdrawal strategy is an early description of managed deleveraging. -- This passage illustrates systemic risk: the banker's individual rational choice (to withdraw slowly rather than abruptly) has the effect of passing the risk to other bankers and prolonging the crisis. -- Cross-reference: 2.2.77 describes what happened when banks collectively began to tighten.

refashioned: The difficulties that the Bank of England, the principal London bankers, and even the more prudent Scottish banks began to impose on discounting -- after all of them had already gone too far -- not only alarmed but enraged these speculators. Their own distress, of which the banks' prudent and necessary caution was undoubtedly the immediate trigger, they called the distress of the country. This national distress, they declared, was entirely due to the ignorance, cowardice, and mismanagement of the banks, which failed to give sufficiently generous support to the spirited entrepreneurs who were working to beautify, improve, and enrich the country. The banks, these speculators seemed to believe, had a duty to lend for as long and in as large amounts as the borrowers wished.
elegant: When the Bank of England, London bankers, and prudent Scottish banks -- all having already gone too far -- began tightening their discounting, the speculators were not just alarmed but enraged. They rebranded their own distress as national distress, blamed the banks' ignorance and cowardice, and insisted that banks had a duty to lend whatever borrowers wanted for as long as they wanted it.
summary: When banks began to tighten lending standards, overextended speculators accused them of causing a national crisis through cowardice and ignorance, insisting that banks were obligated to lend on whatever terms borrowers demanded.
distilled: Overextended speculators blamed prudent bank tightening for their distress, recasting their personal overreach as a national crisis caused by timid banking.
notes: Smith's account of speculators reframing their private overextension as a public crisis is a pattern repeated in virtually every financial crisis since. -- The accusation of 'pusillanimity' (cowardice) against prudent bankers echoes across centuries, from the South Sea Bubble to the 2008 financial crisis. -- The speculators' demand that banks lend 'for as long a time and to as great an extent as they might wish to borrow' is the antithesis of Smith's prudent banking principles. -- Cross-reference: 2.2.64 makes the same point from a different angle; 2.2.78 describes the establishment of a new bank in response to this clamor.

refashioned:
The banks, however, by refusing to extend more credit to those they had already lent far too much, took the only action that could now save either their own credit or the public credit of the country.

In the midst of this uproar and distress, a new bank was established in Scotland expressly to relieve the country's difficulties. The intention was generous, but the execution was reckless, and the nature and causes of the distress it meant to address were perhaps not well understood. This bank was more liberal than any before it, both in granting cash accounts and in discounting bills of exchange. In discounting, it appears to have made virtually no distinction between genuine commercial bills and fictitious circulating bills, discounting both equally. Its declared principle was to advance, against any reasonable security, the entire capital needed for investments with the slowest and most distant returns, such as land improvements. Promoting such improvements was said to be the chief public-spirited purpose for which it was founded. Through its generous cash accounts and bill discounting, it undoubtedly issued enormous quantities of bank notes.
elegant: By refusing further credit, the existing banks took the only step that could save their credit and the country's. But amid the outcry, a new bank was established in Scotland to relieve the distress. Well-intentioned but reckless, it lent more liberally than any predecessor -- discounting genuine and fictitious bills alike, and openly committing to finance the slowest-returning investments, especially land improvements. It issued enormous quantities of bank notes.
summary: While existing banks correctly refused to extend further credit, a new Scottish bank was founded to relieve the distress. It lent indiscriminately on both genuine and fictitious bills and openly committed to financing long-term investments like land improvements, issuing vast quantities of bank notes.
distilled: A new Scottish bank, founded to relieve distress, lent recklessly by discounting all bills indiscriminately and financing long-term investments with short-term bank notes.
notes: This is the Ayr Bank (Douglas, Heron and Company), established in 1769 and failed in 1772 -- one of the most important banking failures of the 18th century. -- Smith's analysis identifies the fundamental error: financing long-term, illiquid investments (land improvements) with short-term, liquid liabilities (bank notes). -- The failure to distinguish real from circulating bills violated the core principle of prudent banking that Smith has been developing since 2.2.55. -- This case study is one of the most detailed and insightful analyses of a bank failure in classical economics. -- Cross-reference: 2.2.79-2.2.84 detail the consequences.

refashioned: But since most of these bank notes exceeded what the country's circulation could absorb, they returned to the bank for exchange into gold and silver as fast as they were issued. Its coffers were never well stocked. The capital subscribed to this bank in two rounds amounted to one hundred and sixty thousand pounds, of which only eighty percent was actually paid in. This sum was supposed to be paid in several installments. But a large number of the bank's proprietors, upon paying their first installment, opened cash accounts with the bank. The directors, feeling obliged to treat their own proprietors as liberally as they treated everyone else, allowed many of them to borrow against their cash accounts the amounts they owed on all subsequent installments.
elegant: Most of the bank's notes exceeded what circulation could absorb and returned immediately for gold and silver. Its capital of one hundred and sixty thousand pounds was only eighty percent paid in, and even that was undermined: proprietors who opened cash accounts were allowed to borrow back what they owed on subsequent installments. The coffers were never properly filled.
summary: The new bank's notes immediately returned for gold and silver conversion because they exceeded what the economy could absorb. Its already inadequate capital was further hollowed out when directors allowed proprietors to borrow back their installment payments through cash accounts.
distilled: The bank's excessive note issuance returned immediately for gold and silver, while its capital was hollowed out by allowing proprietors to borrow back their own subscriptions.
notes: The practice of allowing proprietors to borrow back their own capital subscriptions is a form of what modern corporate governance calls self-dealing -- it made the bank's capital base illusory. -- The eighty percent capital call rate, further undermined by this practice, meant the bank was severely undercapitalized from inception. -- This is an early example of what would later be called 'fictitious capital' -- capital that exists on paper but has no real economic substance. -- Cross-reference: 2.2.80 describes how quickly this undercapitalization led to crisis.

refashioned: These payments, therefore, merely moved money from one coffer to another. But even if the bank's coffers had been well stocked, its excessive note circulation would have drained them faster than any expedient could replenish them -- except the ruinous practice of drawing bills on London and, when those came due, paying them with further drafts on London plus interest and commission. Since its coffers were in fact so poorly filled, the bank is said to have been driven to this resort within just a few months of opening for business.
elegant: Capital payments simply circulated from one coffer to another. Even well-filled coffers would have been drained by the excessive note circulation -- only the ruinous practice of drawing and redrawing on London could keep pace. With coffers so poorly filled, the bank resorted to this within months of opening.
summary: The bank's capital payments were circular and meaningless. Its excessive note issuance drained reserves faster than anything could replenish them, except the ruinous practice of drawing bills on London -- to which it was driven within months of opening.
distilled: Within months of opening, the bank was forced into the ruinous practice of drawing bills on London to cover the constant drain of its excessive note circulation.
notes: The circular movement of capital ('one coffer to another') illustrates the illusory nature of the bank's capital base. -- Being forced to draw on London within months demonstrates how quickly the fundamental mismatch between assets and liabilities manifested. -- The 'ruinous expedient' of drawing on London was the same practice Smith condemned in 2.2.65-2.2.70, now being employed by the bank itself rather than by individual traders. -- Cross-reference: 2.2.81 details the scale of the resulting obligations.

refashioned: The estates of this bank's proprietors were worth several millions, and their subscription to the original contract pledged these estates as security for all the bank's obligations. The enormous credit that such a guarantee naturally provided enabled the bank, despite its reckless lending, to operate for more than two years. When it was finally forced to stop, it had about two hundred thousand pounds in bank notes in circulation. To support those notes -- which returned for redemption as fast as they were issued -- it had been constantly drawing bills of exchange on London, in ever-increasing number and value, which at the time it stopped amounted to over six hundred thousand pounds. In just over two years, therefore, this bank had advanced to various people upwards of eight hundred thousand pounds at five percent interest. On the two hundred thousand pounds circulated as bank notes, this five percent could perhaps be considered a clear profit, after deducting only the cost of management.
elegant: The proprietors' estates, worth millions, were pledged as security, giving the bank enough credit to operate for over two years despite its reckless lending. When it stopped, it had two hundred thousand pounds in circulating notes and over six hundred thousand pounds in bills drawn on London -- eight hundred thousand pounds advanced in total at five percent. Only on the two hundred thousand in notes could the interest be considered a clear profit.
summary: Backed by proprietors' estates worth millions, the Ayr Bank survived over two years of reckless lending before failing. It had advanced over eight hundred thousand pounds -- two hundred thousand in circulating notes and over six hundred thousand through bills on London. Only the interest on the circulating notes represented any possible profit.
distilled: The Ayr Bank, backed by its proprietors' vast estates, advanced over eight hundred thousand pounds in two years before being forced to stop -- only a quarter of which could have generated any profit.
notes: The Ayr Bank's total advances of eight hundred thousand pounds were enormous for 18th-century Scotland. -- The proprietors' personal liability (unlimited liability) was the only thing sustaining the bank's credit -- an early illustration of why bank capital and governance structures matter. -- The breakdown between profitable lending (the circulating notes) and unprofitable lending (the London bills) shows the arithmetic of banking failure. -- Cross-reference: 2.2.82 completes the financial analysis by showing the losses.

refashioned:
But on the more than six hundred thousand pounds for which it was constantly drawing bills of exchange on London, it was paying upwards of eight percent in interest and commission -- and was therefore losing more than three percent on more than three-quarters of all its business.

The operations of this bank produced effects quite opposite to what its founders intended. They had meant to support the ambitious enterprises being carried out across the country, and simultaneously to draw all banking business to themselves, supplanting the other Scottish banks -- particularly the Edinburgh banks whose reluctance to discount bills had caused some resentment. The new bank undoubtedly gave some temporary relief to the speculators, enabling them to continue their projects for about two years longer than they otherwise could have. But it only enabled them to sink that much deeper into debt, so that when ruin came, it fell all the harder on both them and their creditors. In the long run, this bank's operations actually worsened the distress they were meant to relieve. It would have been far better for the speculators, their creditors, and the country if most of them had been forced to stop two years earlier. The temporary relief this bank provided to speculators, however, proved a real and lasting benefit to the other Scottish banks. All the dealers in circulating bills, which the other banks had become reluctant to discount, flocked to this new bank, where they were welcomed with open arms. The other banks were thereby able to escape easily from the dangerous entanglement they could not otherwise have exited without considerable loss and some discredit.
elegant: On over six hundred thousand pounds in London bills, the bank paid over eight percent while earning only five -- losing more than three percent on three-quarters of its business. Its operations achieved the opposite of their aims: instead of supporting ambitious enterprises and supplanting rival banks, it merely allowed speculators to accumulate two more years of debt before a harder collapse. The only beneficiaries were the rival banks, which escaped their own entanglement with circulating bills once the speculators moved to the new bank.
summary: The Ayr Bank lost more than three percent on three-quarters of its dealings. Rather than supporting national enterprise and displacing rival banks as intended, it merely prolonged speculative projects by two years, making the eventual collapse worse. Ironically, the only lasting beneficiaries were the rival banks it meant to supplant, which escaped their own dangerous exposure to circulating bills.
distilled: The Ayr Bank lost money on three-quarters of its business, prolonged rather than prevented the speculative collapse, and inadvertently rescued the rival banks it meant to destroy.
notes: The irony of the Ayr Bank rescuing its rivals is one of Smith's most pointed observations about unintended consequences in banking. -- The analysis that extending credit to failing enterprises merely deepens eventual losses is a foundational insight for modern bankruptcy and restructuring policy. -- Smith's argument that the speculators would have been better off failing sooner anticipates the modern 'extend and pretend' critique of forbearance policies. -- The three percent loss on three-quarters of business demonstrates a classic banking death spiral: income on performing assets cannot cover losses on non-performing ones.

refashioned:
In the long run, therefore, this bank's operations increased the real distress of the country it meant to relieve, and effectively rescued the rival banks it meant to supplant.

When this bank first opened, some people believed that however fast its coffers might empty, it could easily refill them by raising money against the securities of those to whom it had advanced its paper. Experience, I believe, quickly convinced them that this method was far too slow. Coffers that had been so poorly filled from the start and that drained so fast could be replenished by no means other than the ruinous practice of drawing bills on London -- and when those came due, paying them with new drafts carrying accumulated interest and commission. But even if they had been able to raise money fast enough this way, they would have suffered a loss on every such transaction, and would eventually have ruined themselves as a commercial enterprise -- though perhaps not as quickly as through the even more expensive direct drawing and redrawing. They could never have profited from the interest on their paper, which -- being in excess of what circulation could absorb -- returned for gold and silver as fast as it was issued, forcing them to borrow continuously just to meet redemptions. All the costs of this borrowing -- hiring agents to find lenders, negotiating terms, and drafting legal documents -- fell entirely on them as pure loss. Their plan to replenish their coffers this way may be compared to a man whose pond has a stream constantly flowing out but none flowing in, who proposes to keep it full by employing people to carry water in buckets from a well several miles away.
elegant: This bank worsened the distress it meant to relieve and rescued the rivals it meant to destroy. Its plan to raise money against borrowers' securities was far too slow. Drawing on London was its only recourse, but every such transaction produced a loss. Its paper returned for redemption as fast as it was issued, forcing constant borrowing just to meet conversions. The entire scheme was like trying to keep a draining pond full by hiring people to carry buckets of water from a distant well.
summary: The Ayr Bank's operations worsened the country's distress while saving its rivals. Every method of replenishing its coffers -- whether raising money on securities or drawing on London -- produced losses. Smith compares the futile effort to a man trying to fill a constantly draining pond by carrying buckets from a distant well.
distilled: The Ayr Bank worsened the very distress it aimed to relieve, and every method of sustaining its operations produced losses -- like carrying buckets to fill a draining pond.
notes: The draining pond metaphor is one of Smith's most vivid illustrations of unsustainable banking. -- The analysis shows three layers of impossibility: the paper was excessive (it returned immediately), the refinancing was costly (every transaction lost money), and the alternative of raising money on securities was too slow. -- Smith's conclusion that the bank would have ruined itself under any strategy demonstrates that the fundamental business model was flawed, not merely the execution. -- This passage is a masterclass in analyzing the economics of an insolvent institution.

refashioned: But even if this operation had proven not only feasible but profitable for the bank as a commercial enterprise, the country could have derived no benefit from it -- and would in fact have suffered considerable harm. This operation could not have increased the total amount of money available for lending by even the smallest degree. It would only have turned this bank into a sort of general loan office for the whole country. Those wanting to borrow would have had to apply to this bank instead of to the private lenders who had lent it their money. But a bank that lends to perhaps five hundred people, most of whom its directors know little about, is unlikely to choose its borrowers more wisely than a private lender who lends to a few people he knows personally and in whose sober and frugal habits he has good reason to trust. The borrowers of a bank like the one I have been describing were likely to be mostly fantasists and speculators -- the drawers and redrawers of circulating bills -- who would invest the money in extravagant undertakings they would probably never complete, and which, even if completed, would never repay their true cost or sustain as much employment as had gone into them. The sober and frugal borrowers of private lenders, by contrast, would be more likely to invest in modest ventures proportionate to their capital -- ventures that, though lacking grandeur, would be solid and profitable, would repay with large returns whatever had been invested, and would therefore sustain far more employment than what had been used to create them. The success of this operation, therefore, without increasing the country's capital by the smallest amount, would only have transferred a large share of it from prudent and profitable uses to reckless and unprofitable ones.
elegant: Even if the bank had been profitable, the country would have suffered. It could not have increased total lending -- only redirected it through itself. But a bank lending to five hundred strangers chooses borrowers less wisely than a private lender who knows his few clients personally. The bank's borrowers would have been speculators pursuing grandiose failures; private lenders' borrowers would have pursued modest, profitable ventures. The net effect: capital transferred from prudent to imprudent hands, with no increase in total lending.
summary: Even a profitable Ayr Bank would have harmed the country by acting as an inefficient intermediary that redirected capital from prudent private lending to reckless speculation. A bank lending to hundreds of strangers cannot match the judgment of private lenders who personally know their borrowers.
distilled: Even a successful Ayr Bank would have merely redirected capital from prudent private lending to reckless speculation, since banks choose borrowers less wisely than private lenders who know their clients personally.
notes: Smith makes a powerful case for the superior information and monitoring advantages of private (relationship) lending over institutional (arm's-length) lending. -- The contrast between 'grand and marvellous' projects and 'solid and profitable' ones reflects Smith's consistent preference for incremental, well-capitalized enterprise over speculative ambition. -- This passage anticipates the modern debate about financial disintermediation and whether banks allocate capital more or less efficiently than direct lending relationships. -- The observation that the operation would not increase total capital but merely redistribute it is a key insight about the limits of financial intermediation. -- Cross-reference: 2.2.57 makes the same point about banks' informational disadvantage relative to private lenders.

refashioned: The famous John Law held the opinion that Scottish industry languished for want of money to employ it. By establishing a special kind of bank, which he seems to have imagined could issue paper money equal to the total value of all the land in the country, he proposed to remedy this shortage. The Scottish Parliament, when he first proposed his project, declined to adopt it. It was later adopted, with some modifications, by the Duke of Orleans, then regent of France. The belief that paper money could be multiplied almost without limit was the real foundation of what became known as the Mississippi Scheme -- perhaps the most extravagant project of banking and stock speculation the world has ever seen. The workings of this scheme are explained so fully and clearly by Mr. Du Verney, in his Examination of the Political Reflections upon Commerce and Finances of Mr. Du Tot, that I shall not describe them here. The principles on which it was founded are explained by Law himself in a treatise on money and trade that he published in Scotland when he first proposed his project. The brilliant but visionary ideas in that and other works based on the same principles continue to impress many people, and have perhaps contributed in part to the banking excesses that have recently been complained of in Scotland and elsewhere.
elegant: John Law believed Scottish industry languished for want of money and proposed a bank that could issue paper equal to all the country's land values. Scotland's Parliament rejected it, but the Duke of Orleans adopted a version for France -- the Mississippi Scheme, perhaps the most extravagant banking and stock speculation the world has seen. Law's brilliant but visionary ideas continue to influence people and have perhaps contributed to the banking excesses recently complained of in Scotland and elsewhere.
summary: John Law's belief that paper money could be multiplied almost without limit inspired the Mississippi Scheme in France -- history's most extravagant banking and stock speculation. Though Scotland's Parliament rejected his proposal, Law's visionary ideas continued to influence banking practices and may have contributed to recent excesses.
distilled: John Law's belief in virtually unlimited paper money creation inspired the Mississippi Scheme and continued to fuel banking excesses long afterward.
notes: John Law (1671-1729) was a Scottish economist whose Mississippi Company scheme in France (1716-1720) produced one of history's most spectacular financial bubbles. -- Smith's reference to 'the famous Mr Law' carries irony -- Law was both famous and infamous. -- The Mississippi Scheme inflated and collapsed French government finances, destroying the savings of countless investors. -- Smith draws a direct line from Law's monetary theories to the contemporary Scottish banking excesses he has been analyzing, suggesting that bad monetary theory has persistent real-world consequences. -- Du Verney and Du Tot were French economists who analyzed the Mississippi Scheme from opposing perspectives.

refashioned: The Bank of England is the largest bank of circulation in Europe. It was incorporated by a charter under the Great Seal, dated July 27, 1694, pursuant to an act of Parliament. It initially advanced to the government the sum of 1,200,000 pounds for an annuity of 100,000 pounds -- that is, 96,000 pounds per year in interest at eight percent, plus 4,000 pounds per year for management expenses. The credit of the new government, established by the Glorious Revolution, must have been very low indeed if it was forced to borrow at such a high rate of interest.
elegant: The Bank of England, Europe's greatest bank of circulation, was chartered in 1694 and advanced 1,200,000 pounds to the government at eight percent interest plus management fees. That the new post-Revolution government had to borrow at so high a rate reveals how low its credit stood.
summary: The Bank of England was chartered in 1694 and made its first loan to the government of 1,200,000 pounds at eight percent interest. The high rate reflected the very low credit of the newly established post-Revolution government.
distilled: The Bank of England was founded in 1694, lending 1,200,000 pounds to the government at eight percent -- a rate reflecting the new government's poor credit.
notes: The Bank of England was founded primarily to finance government debt following the Glorious Revolution of 1688, making it from inception both a commercial bank and an instrument of state finance. -- The eight percent rate was high by the standards of established governments but reflected the genuine uncertainty about the new constitutional settlement's permanence. -- Smith begins a detailed chronological account of the Bank of England's capital and lending history (2.2.86-2.2.91) that demonstrates the evolution of government creditworthiness and interest rates. -- Cross-reference: 2.2.91 discusses the bank's stability as tied to government credit.

refashioned: In 1697, the bank was allowed to enlarge its capital stock by an addition of 1,001,171 pounds 10 shillings, bringing its total capital to 2,201,171 pounds 10 shillings. This enlargement was said to be for the support of public credit. In 1696, government tallies had been trading at forty, fifty, and even sixty percent discount, and bank notes at twenty percent discount. During the great silver recoinage then underway, the bank had decided to stop paying its notes in coin, which inevitably damaged their value.
elegant: In 1697, the bank enlarged its capital to 2,201,171 pounds to support public credit. Government tallies had fallen to forty-to-sixty percent discount and bank notes to twenty percent. The bank's decision to suspend note payments during the silver recoinage had inevitably damaged confidence.
summary: The Bank of England enlarged its capital in 1697 to support public credit, which had deteriorated severely -- government tallies traded at up to sixty percent discount and bank notes at twenty percent, worsened by the bank's suspension of payments during the silver recoinage.
distilled: The Bank of England's 1697 capital increase aimed to restore public credit that had collapsed during the silver recoinage crisis.
notes: The Great Recoinage of 1696 was one of England's worst monetary crises -- old, clipped silver coins were withdrawn and replaced, causing severe cash shortages. -- Government tallies were wooden sticks used as receipts for government borrowing; their deep discount reflected near-total loss of confidence in government finances. -- The bank's decision to suspend note payments was an early precedent for what would later become a recurring feature of banking crises. -- Cross-reference: 2.2.86 on the bank's founding; 2.2.88 continues the capital history.

refashioned: Under the 7th Anne, chapter 7, the bank advanced and paid into the exchequer 400,000 pounds, bringing its total government advances to 1,600,000 pounds, upon which it received 96,000 pounds interest and 4,000 pounds for management. By 1708, therefore, the government's credit was as good as that of private borrowers, since it could borrow at six percent -- the standard legal and market rate of the time. Under the same act, the bank cancelled exchequer bills amounting to 1,775,027 pounds 17 shillings 10.5 pence at six percent interest, and was simultaneously allowed to double its capital through new subscriptions. By 1708, the bank's capital therefore amounted to 4,402,343 pounds, and it had advanced to the government 3,375,027 pounds 17 shillings 10.5 pence.
elegant: By 1708, the bank had advanced 1,600,000 pounds to government and cancelled exchequer bills worth 1,775,027 pounds. Government credit had improved enough to borrow at six percent -- the standard market rate. The bank's capital doubled to 4,402,343 pounds, with total government advances of 3,375,027 pounds.
summary: By 1708, government credit had improved to match private borrowers, with the Bank of England advancing over 3.3 million pounds at six percent. The bank doubled its capital through new subscriptions to fund these operations.
distilled: By 1708, government credit had recovered to borrow at the standard six percent rate, with the Bank of England's capital and advances both roughly doubling.
notes: The decline in government borrowing rates from eight percent (1694) to six percent (1708) within fourteen years demonstrates how quickly the post-Revolution constitutional settlement gained financial credibility. -- The intertwining of bank capital expansion with government debt financing shows the symbiotic relationship between the Bank of England and the state from the earliest period. -- Smith's note that the dates contain a minor inconsistency (the text says 1703 for the doubling, but the act is from Queen Anne's reign around 1708) reflects the complexity of the bank's financial history.

refashioned:
A capital call of fifteen percent in 1709 brought in 656,204 pounds 1 shilling 9 pence, and another of ten percent in 1710 brought in 501,448 pounds 12 shillings 11 pence. The bank's capital thus rose to 5,559,995 pounds 14 shillings 8 pence.

Under the 3rd George I, chapter 8, the bank surrendered two million pounds of exchequer bills for cancellation. Its total advances to government at that point stood at 5,375,027 pounds 17 shillings 10.5 pence. Under the 8th George I, chapter 21, the bank purchased four million pounds of South Sea Company stock, and in 1722, having taken in subscriptions for this purpose, increased its capital stock by 3,400,000 pounds. By this time, the bank had advanced 9,375,027 pounds 17 shillings 10.5 pence to the public, while its capital stock stood at only 8,959,995 pounds 14 shillings 8 pence. This was the first time the bank's advances to the public exceeded its capital stock -- in other words, the first time it had an undivided capital above and beyond its divided capital, and it has maintained such an undivided capital ever since. By 1746, the bank had advanced 11,686,800 pounds to the public, and its divided capital had risen to 10,780,000 pounds. Both figures have remained the same since then. Under the 4th George III, chapter 25, the bank agreed to pay the government 110,000 pounds for the renewal of its charter, without interest or repayment. This sum did not increase either of the other two amounts.
elegant: Capital calls in 1709-1710 raised the bank's capital to nearly 5.6 million pounds. It then cancelled two million in exchequer bills and purchased four million in South Sea Company stock, raising capital to nearly nine million while government advances reached 9.375 million. This was the first time advances exceeded capital -- creating an undivided capital above the divided capital. By 1746, advances stood at 11.687 million and divided capital at 10.78 million, where both have remained. A charter renewal payment of 110,000 pounds did not alter either figure.
summary: Through capital calls, exchequer bill cancellations, and the purchase of South Sea Company stock, the Bank of England's government advances grew to exceed its capital stock by the 1720s -- creating an undivided capital for the first time. By 1746, advances reached 11.687 million and capital 10.78 million pounds.
distilled: The Bank of England's government advances first exceeded its capital stock in the 1720s, creating an undivided capital that persisted as both figures stabilized by 1746.
notes: The purchase of South Sea Company stock reflects the Bank of England's role in cleaning up after the South Sea Bubble of 1720 -- one of history's most famous speculative manias. -- The concept of 'undivided capital' (advances exceeding shareholder capital) is an early version of what modern finance would call leverage beyond equity. -- Smith's meticulous accounting demonstrates the progressive entanglement of the Bank of England with government finance. -- The stability of both figures after 1746 suggests a mature equilibrium in the bank-government relationship during Smith's era.

refashioned: The bank's dividend has varied according to changes in the interest rate it has received on its advances to the government, as well as other circumstances. This interest rate has gradually fallen from eight to three percent. For some years now, the bank dividend has been at five and a half percent.
elegant: The bank's dividend has fluctuated with the interest rate on government advances, which has fallen from eight to three percent. Recently, the dividend has been five and a half percent.
summary: The Bank of England's dividend has varied with the declining interest rate on government loans, which fell from eight to three percent. The current dividend stands at five and a half percent.
distilled: The Bank of England's dividend has tracked the declining interest rate on government debt, recently standing at five and a half percent.
notes: The decline in government borrowing rates from eight percent to three percent over roughly seventy years reflects both the growing stability of British government credit and the general decline in interest rates across Europe during this period. -- The bank dividend of five and a half percent exceeding the three percent government rate indicates the bank earned additional income from its commercial operations (bill discounting, etc.). -- Cross-reference: 2.2.86 gives the original eight percent rate.

refashioned: The stability of the Bank of England is equal to that of the British government itself. Everything the bank has advanced to the government would have to be lost before its creditors could suffer any loss. No other banking company in England can be established by act of Parliament or consist of more than six members. The Bank of England serves not only as an ordinary bank but as a great engine of state. It receives and pays most of the annuities owed to government creditors; it circulates exchequer bills; and it advances to the government the annual land and malt taxes, which are frequently not collected until years later. In performing these public duties, it may sometimes have been forced, through no fault of its directors, to flood the circulation with too much paper money. It also discounts merchant bills and has on several occasions supported the credit of leading financial houses not only in England but in Hamburg and Holland. On one occasion in 1763, it reportedly advanced about 1,600,000 pounds for this purpose in a single week, much of it in bullion -- though I do not vouch for the exact sum or the time frame. On other occasions, this great institution has been reduced to paying out in sixpences.
elegant: The Bank of England is as stable as the British government -- its entire public advances would have to be lost before creditors could suffer. No rival bank can exceed six partners. It serves as both a commercial bank and an engine of state: paying government annuities, circulating exchequer bills, and advancing tax revenues years before they are collected. These duties may sometimes force excessive note issuance. It has also acted as lender of last resort, reportedly advancing 1,600,000 pounds in one week in 1763 -- though it has also been reduced to paying in sixpences.
summary: The Bank of England's stability matches the British government's. It functions as both a commercial bank and an instrument of state finance, sometimes being forced to over-issue notes in fulfilling public duties. It has acted as lender of last resort to major financial houses across Europe, while at times being reduced to paying in small coins.
distilled: The Bank of England serves as both commercial bank and state engine, its stability guaranteed by government credit, though its public duties sometimes force excessive note issuance.
notes: Smith's description of the Bank of England as a 'great engine of state' captures its dual nature -- a private corporation performing public functions -- that would define central banking for centuries. -- The 1763 intervention (during a pan-European financial crisis triggered by the end of the Seven Years' War) is an early instance of lender-of-last-resort activity, anticipating Walter Bagehot's codification of this principle in Lombard Street (1873). -- The monopoly restriction (no other bank could have more than six partners) persisted until 1826 and severely limited English banking development. -- The detail about paying in sixpences shows even the Bank of England faced liquidity crises -- an honest admission that undermines idealization of the gold standard era.

refashioned: The most judicious banking operations increase a country's industry not by augmenting its capital, but by making a greater portion of that capital active and productive. The cash reserves a dealer must keep on hand for meeting unexpected demands represent dead stock that produces nothing for him or his country as long as it sits idle. Good banking enables him to convert this dead stock into active and productive capital: into materials to work on, tools to work with, and provisions to sustain those who work -- into stock that generates returns for both the dealer and the country.
elegant: Sound banking increases industry not by creating new capital but by activating what would otherwise lie idle. A dealer's cash reserves are dead stock, producing nothing. Banking converts this dead stock into productive capital -- materials, tools, and provisions that generate returns for both the individual and the nation.
summary: Banking's true contribution is not creating new capital but activating idle capital. By replacing the dead stock of cash reserves with productive materials, tools, and provisions, sound banking makes existing capital work for both individuals and the country.
distilled: Banking increases economic activity not by creating capital but by converting idle cash reserves into productive materials, tools, and provisions.
notes: This is one of Smith's most important theoretical statements about banking: it creates no new wealth but unlocks existing wealth that would otherwise sit idle. -- The 'dead stock' concept anticipates Keynes's liquidity preference theory -- money held as reserves earns nothing but provides security. -- Smith's formulation limits the proper scope of banking to the activation of idle reserves, consistent with his earlier arguments about the limits of prudent bank lending (2.2.55-2.2.62). -- Cross-reference: 2.2.93-2.2.94 extend this analysis from individual dealers to the nation as a whole.

refashioned: The gold and silver money circulating in any country, through which the produce of its land and labor is distributed annually to consumers, is -- just like a dealer's cash reserves -- entirely dead stock. It is a very valuable part of the country's capital, but it produces nothing. Sound banking, by substituting paper for a large portion of this gold and silver, enables the country to convert much of this dead stock into active and productive capital -- capital that actually generates returns for the nation.
elegant: A nation's circulating gold and silver, like a dealer's cash reserves, is dead stock -- valuable but unproductive. Sound banking substitutes paper for much of this metal, converting dead stock into productive capital that generates real returns.
summary: A nation's gold and silver coinage, while valuable, is dead stock that produces nothing. By substituting paper money for much of this metal, sound banking converts a significant portion of a country's idle capital into productive, wealth-generating assets.
distilled: Paper money substituted for gold and silver converts a nation's dead metallic stock into productive capital.
notes: Smith extends the dead-stock argument from individual cash reserves (2.2.92) to the nation's entire monetary base. -- This is a sophisticated argument for paper money: gold and silver used as currency are economically sterile, representing a massive national investment earning zero return. -- The freed-up gold and silver could be exported to purchase productive imports, effectively converting sterile domestic metal into productive foreign capital. -- This analysis influenced the Banking School/Currency School debate of the 19th century.

refashioned: A country's gold and silver money may aptly be compared to a highway: while it carries all the country's produce to market, it does not itself produce a single bushel of grain or blade of grass. Sound banking, by providing -- if I may use so dramatic a metaphor -- a sort of aerial highway, enables the country to convert much of its roads into good pastures and cropland, thereby considerably increasing its annual output. Yet it must be acknowledged that a country's commerce and industry, though they may be somewhat expanded, cannot be quite as secure when suspended on the Daedalian wings of paper money as when traveling on the solid ground of gold and silver. Beyond the risks created by the incompetence of those who manage the paper money, there are additional dangers against which no amount of skill or prudence on their part can protect.
elegant: Gold and silver money is like a highway: it carries produce to market but grows nothing itself. Banking provides an aerial highway, freeing the land beneath for productive use. But commerce suspended on the Daedalian wings of paper money is less secure than commerce grounded on gold and silver. Beyond the risks of mismanagement, paper money carries dangers that no skill can entirely prevent.
summary: Smith compares gold and silver to a highway that carries goods but produces nothing. Paper money is like an aerial highway that frees the ground for productive use. But he warns that an economy suspended on paper money, like Daedalus on his waxen wings, is inherently less secure than one grounded in precious metals.
distilled: Paper money is like an aerial highway that frees resources for production, but an economy built on it is less secure than one grounded in gold and silver.
notes: The highway metaphor and the 'waggon-way through the air' are among Smith's most celebrated economic images. -- The Daedalian wings allusion (from Greek mythology, where Daedalus flew on wax wings that melted near the sun) captures both the brilliance and the danger of paper money -- it enables flight but invites catastrophe. -- Smith's balanced position acknowledges paper money's genuine economic benefits while insisting on its risks -- a nuance often lost by both gold-standard advocates and paper-money enthusiasts who selectively cite him. -- Cross-reference: 2.2.95 develops the vulnerability argument with the example of wartime.

refashioned: An unsuccessful war, for example, in which the enemy captured the capital city and consequently the treasure backing the paper money, would cause far greater disruption in a country whose circulation was entirely paper-based than in one that relied mostly on gold and silver. With the usual medium of exchange rendered worthless, trade could proceed only through barter or credit. Since taxes had been paid in paper money, the ruler would have no means to pay his troops or stock his arsenals, and the country's situation would be far more desperate than if most of its circulation had been in gold and silver. A ruler who wishes to keep his realm in the most defensible condition at all times should therefore guard not only against the excessive multiplication of paper money that destroys the banks that issue it, but even against any expansion that allows paper to fill the greater part of the country's circulation.
elegant: If an enemy captured the capital and the treasure backing paper money, a paper-dependent economy would face far worse disruption than one using gold and silver. Trade would collapse into barter, the government could not pay troops or maintain arsenals, and recovery would be far harder. A prudent ruler should guard not only against paper money excesses that ruin banks, but even against allowing paper to dominate circulation.
summary: A country dependent on paper money is far more vulnerable in wartime: if the enemy captures the capital and its treasure, the entire medium of exchange becomes worthless. Smith argues that rulers should prevent paper money from dominating national circulation, even when managed prudently.
distilled: Paper-dependent economies are dangerously vulnerable in wartime, so rulers should prevent paper money from dominating national circulation even under sound management.
notes: Smith introduces a national security dimension to monetary policy -- an argument that goes beyond purely economic considerations. -- This warning proved prescient during the Napoleonic Wars when Britain suspended gold convertibility (1797-1821). -- The argument that even well-managed paper money poses systemic risks distinguishes Smith from pure advocates of paper currency. -- Smith's position here is notably conservative: he favors paper money for dealer-to-dealer transactions but wants gold and silver to remain the backbone of consumer circulation. -- Cross-reference: 2.2.96-2.2.97 develop the distinction between wholesale and retail circulation.

refashioned: A country's monetary circulation can be thought of as having two branches: the circulation among dealers, and the circulation between dealers and consumers. Though the same money -- whether paper or metal -- may pass through both branches, each constantly requires its own stock of money to keep it running. The value of goods circulated among dealers can never exceed that circulated between dealers and consumers, since everything dealers buy is ultimately destined for sale to consumers. Dealer-to-dealer circulation, being wholesale, generally requires large sums for each transaction. Dealer-to-consumer circulation, being retail, frequently requires very small sums -- a shilling or even a halfpenny is often enough. But small sums circulate much faster than large ones. A shilling changes hands more often than a guinea, and a halfpenny more often than a shilling. Although consumers' total annual purchases are at least equal in value to those of all the dealers, they can generally be handled with a much smaller stock of money, since the same coins serve as the instrument of far more transactions through their more rapid circulation.
elegant: Monetary circulation has two branches: dealer-to-dealer (wholesale) and dealer-to-consumer (retail). Wholesale transactions require large sums; retail ones need only small amounts. Small denominations circulate far faster than large ones -- a shilling changes hands more often than a guinea. So although consumer spending matches dealer spending in total value, it requires a much smaller stock of money thanks to faster turnover.
summary: Smith divides monetary circulation into wholesale (dealer-to-dealer) and retail (dealer-to-consumer) branches. Though equal in total value, retail transactions require less money because small denominations circulate far more rapidly than large ones.
distilled: Monetary circulation divides into wholesale and retail branches, with retail requiring less money because small denominations circulate faster.
notes: Smith anticipates the modern concept of the velocity of money -- the same stock of money can facilitate more transactions when it turns over faster. -- The distinction between wholesale and retail circulation underpins his argument for restricting paper money to large-denomination, dealer-to-dealer transactions. -- The observation that small coins circulate faster is an early insight into monetary velocity as a function of denomination. -- Cross-reference: 2.2.97 applies this framework to paper money regulation.

refashioned: Paper money can be regulated to confine itself largely to the circulation among dealers, or it can extend into the circulation between dealers and consumers. In London, where no bank notes circulate below ten pounds, paper money is mostly confined to dealer-to-dealer circulation. When a consumer receives a ten-pound note, he generally must break it at the first shop where he buys five shillings' worth of goods, so the note often returns to a dealer before the consumer has spent a fortieth of it. In Scotland, where notes are issued for as little as twenty shillings, paper money extends considerably into the dealer-consumer circulation. Before Parliament prohibited ten-shilling and five-shilling notes, paper filled an even larger share of that circulation. In North America, paper was commonly issued for as little as a shilling and filled almost the entire circulation. In some Yorkshire paper currencies, notes were issued for amounts as small as sixpence.
