elegant: Paper money can be confined to wholesale circulation or extended into retail. In London, with a ten-pound minimum, notes mostly circulate among dealers -- consumers quickly break them into coin. In Scotland, twenty-shilling notes extend paper into retail circulation. In North America, shilling notes filled almost all circulation. In Yorkshire, notes went as low as sixpence.
summary: The minimum denomination of bank notes determines whether paper money stays in wholesale circulation or penetrates retail transactions. London's ten-pound minimum kept paper among dealers, while Scotland's lower minimum and North America's shilling notes extended paper throughout the entire economy.
distilled: The minimum denomination of bank notes determines whether paper money stays within wholesale dealer circulation or extends into everyday retail transactions.
notes: Smith uses comparative evidence across London, Scotland, North America, and Yorkshire to demonstrate how denomination floors shape monetary systems. -- This empirical approach to monetary policy was innovative for the time. -- The contrast between London's relative monetary stability and Scotland's and North America's problems reinforces Smith's argument for higher minimum denominations. -- Cross-reference: 2.2.98-2.2.99 argue for a five-pound minimum; 2.2.100 describes the effects on gold and silver availability.

refashioned: Where the issuance of bank notes for very small sums is permitted and commonly practiced, many people of modest means are both enabled and encouraged to set up as bankers. A person whose promissory note for five pounds, or even twenty shillings, would be rejected by everyone, can get his note accepted without hesitation when it is issued for as little as sixpence. But the frequent bankruptcies to which such undercapitalized bankers are inevitably subject may cause very considerable inconvenience, and sometimes genuine calamity, to the many poor people who had accepted their notes as payment.
elegant: Very small denomination notes enable people of little means to become bankers -- their sixpenny notes are accepted where their five-pound notes would be refused. But the frequent bankruptcies of such undercapitalized bankers cause serious harm to the poor people who hold their worthless notes.
summary: Allowing very small denomination bank notes encourages undercapitalized people to become bankers. Their frequent failures cause serious harm to the poor who accepted their notes, since the poorest people are most likely to hold the smallest denominations.
distilled: Small-denomination bank notes enable undercapitalized bankers whose inevitable failures harm the poor people who hold their worthless notes.
notes: Smith identifies a regressive distributional consequence of lax banking regulation: the poorest people hold the smallest notes and are therefore most exposed to the failures of the weakest banks. -- The term 'beggarly bankers' captures the absurdity of nearly insolvent people issuing money that others are expected to trust. -- This argument for minimum denomination requirements is fundamentally about consumer protection for the most vulnerable. -- Cross-reference: 2.2.99 proposes the five-pound minimum as the solution.

refashioned: It would perhaps be better if no bank notes were issued anywhere in the kingdom for less than five pounds. Paper money would then probably confine itself throughout the country to the circulation among dealers, as it currently does in London, where no notes circulate below ten pounds. Five pounds, in most of the country, is a sum that -- though it buys perhaps only half as much as ten pounds -- is regarded with equal seriousness and is just as rarely spent all at once as ten pounds is amid London's more lavish spending habits.
elegant: A five-pound minimum for bank notes would confine paper money to dealer circulation throughout the country, as the ten-pound minimum already does in London. Five pounds in the provinces commands the same respect and is spent as carefully as ten pounds in London.
summary: Smith proposes a five-pound minimum denomination for bank notes, which would confine paper money to wholesale circulation nationwide, just as London's ten-pound minimum already does there.
distilled: A five-pound minimum for bank notes would confine paper money to dealer-to-dealer circulation throughout the country.
notes: This is Smith's concrete policy recommendation for banking regulation -- one of the few instances where he advocates explicit government restriction of market activity. -- The proposal was influential: the Bank Restriction Act of 1826 eventually imposed similar minimum denomination requirements. -- Smith's reasoning balances the efficiency gains of paper money against the risks to the poor from small-denomination notes issued by weak banks. -- The regional price-level comparison between London and the provinces shows Smith's awareness of geographic variation in purchasing power.

refashioned: It should be noted that where paper money is largely confined to dealer-to-dealer circulation, as in London, gold and silver are always plentiful. Where it extends into dealer-to-consumer circulation, as in Scotland, and even more so in North America, it drives gold and silver almost entirely out of the country, with nearly all domestic commerce conducted in paper. The suppression of ten-shilling and five-shilling notes somewhat relieved the scarcity of gold and silver in Scotland, and the suppression of twenty-shilling notes will probably relieve it further. These metals are said to have become more abundant in America since some of their paper currencies were suppressed, and they are also said to have been more abundant before those currencies were introduced.
elegant: Where paper money stays in wholesale circulation, as in London, gold and silver remain plentiful. Where it extends into retail, as in Scotland and especially North America, it drives metal money almost entirely out. Suppressing small-denomination notes in Scotland restored some gold and silver, and similar suppression in America reportedly had the same effect.
summary: Paper money confined to wholesale circulation coexists with plentiful gold and silver, but when it extends into retail circulation, it drives precious metals out of the country. Suppressing small-denomination notes in both Scotland and North America helped restore metallic currency.
distilled: Paper money confined to wholesale circulation preserves gold and silver, but paper extending into retail circulation drives precious metals out of the country.
notes: Smith describes Gresham's Law in action: bad money (small-denomination paper of uncertain value) drives out good money (gold and silver). -- The empirical evidence from Scotland and North America strengthens his case for minimum denomination requirements. -- The observation that metals returned after paper was suppressed confirms the displacement mechanism. -- Cross-reference: 2.2.97 explains the wholesale/retail distinction; 2.2.99 proposes the five-pound remedy.

refashioned: Even if paper money were largely confined to the circulation among dealers, banks could still provide nearly the same assistance to industry and commerce as when paper filled almost the entire circulation. The cash reserves a dealer must keep on hand are used entirely for transactions with other dealers from whom he buys goods. He has no need to keep cash for transactions with consumers, who bring ready money to him rather than taking it from him. Therefore, even if paper money were restricted to denominations that kept it within the dealer-to-dealer circulation, banks could still -- through discounting genuine bills of exchange and lending on cash accounts -- relieve most dealers of the need to keep significant idle cash reserves. They could still provide the fullest assistance that banks can properly give to traders of every kind.
elegant: Even confined to wholesale circulation, paper money could still deliver nearly all of banking's benefits. Dealers need cash reserves only for transactions with other dealers, not with consumers who bring cash to them. Through bill discounting and cash account lending, banks could still free dealers from holding idle reserves -- the fullest assistance banking can properly provide.
summary: Restricting paper money to wholesale circulation would not significantly reduce banking's benefits, since dealers' cash reserve needs arise from transactions with other dealers, not consumers. Banks could still free merchants from idle reserves through bill discounting and cash accounts.
distilled: Confining paper money to wholesale circulation would preserve nearly all of banking's benefits, since dealers need cash reserves only for transactions with other dealers.
notes: This is a crucial argument: Smith shows that his proposed denomination restrictions would not reduce banking's economic contribution, addressing the most likely objection to his policy. -- The insight that consumer transactions bring money in rather than requiring it out explains why retail paper money is unnecessary for banking's core function. -- This completes Smith's banking theory: paper should replace only the idle cash reserves that dealers hold for wholesale transactions. -- Cross-reference: 2.2.92 established that banking's value lies in activating idle reserves; this passage shows that value is preserved under Smith's proposed restrictions.

refashioned: It may be objected that restraining private individuals from accepting a banker's promissory notes for any amount when they are willing to do so, or restraining a banker from issuing such notes when all his neighbors are willing to accept them, is a clear violation of natural liberty -- which it is the law's proper business to protect, not infringe. Such regulations may indeed be considered a violation of natural liberty in some respect. But those exercises of individual natural liberty that might endanger the security of the whole society are, and ought to be, restrained by the laws of all governments, whether the most free or the most despotic. The requirement to build fire walls between adjoining buildings to prevent the spread of fire is a violation of natural liberty of exactly the same kind as the banking regulations proposed here.
elegant: Restricting note denominations may seem to violate natural liberty. It does, in a sense. But individual liberties that endanger the security of the whole society must be restrained by all governments, free or despotic alike. Requiring fire walls between buildings is the same kind of restriction as the banking regulations proposed here.
summary: Smith acknowledges that banking regulations restrict natural liberty but argues this is justified when individual actions endanger society. He compares banking regulation to fire-wall requirements between buildings -- both necessary restraints on individual freedom for collective safety.
distilled: Individual liberty must be restrained when it endangers society, making banking regulation as justified as building fire-wall requirements.
notes: This is one of Smith's most important passages on the limits of laissez-faire -- often overlooked by those who portray him as an unqualified free-market advocate. -- The fire-wall analogy is brilliant: just as one person's building practices can burn down the neighborhood, one banker's reckless note issuance can damage the entire monetary system. -- Smith explicitly accepts the 'violation of natural liberty' label but argues that systemic risk justifies it -- an argument that resonates directly with modern financial regulation debates. -- This passage is frequently cited in discussions of Smith's views on regulation, externalities, and the proper scope of government.

refashioned: Paper money consisting of bank notes issued by people of unquestioned credit, payable on demand without any conditions, and in practice always paid immediately upon presentation, is in every respect equal in value to gold and silver money -- since gold and silver can be obtained for it at any time. Whatever is bought or sold for such paper must necessarily be bought or sold at the same price as it would be for gold and silver.
elegant: Bank notes issued by creditworthy parties, payable unconditionally on demand and always honored immediately, are equal in value to gold and silver -- since they can always be exchanged for metal. Prices paid in such paper are identical to prices paid in coin.
summary: Paper money issued by creditworthy banks, payable on demand without conditions and always honored, is equal in value to gold and silver because it can always be converted. Prices are unaffected by the use of such paper.
distilled: Unconditional, immediately redeemable bank notes issued by creditworthy banks are perfectly equivalent in value to gold and silver.
notes: Smith defines the conditions under which paper money achieves perfect parity with metal: undoubted credit, unconditional demand payment, and actual immediate redemption. -- This sets the standard against which all inferior forms of paper money (2.2.105-2.2.112) will be measured. -- The emphasis on 'in fact always readily paid' distinguishes between the legal promise and the practical reality -- both must hold for parity. -- Cross-reference: 2.2.105-2.2.106 describe what happens when these conditions are compromised.

refashioned: It has been argued that the increase of paper money, by expanding the total quantity and thereby reducing the value of the currency, necessarily raises the money price of goods. But since the quantity of gold and silver removed from circulation always equals the quantity of paper added to it, paper money does not necessarily increase the total currency. From the beginning of the last century to the present, provisions were never cheaper in Scotland than in 1759, even though there was more paper money in circulation then than now, thanks to ten-shilling and five-shilling notes. The ratio of Scottish to English provision prices is the same now as it was before the great multiplication of Scottish banks. Corn is generally as cheap in England as in France, despite England having much paper money and France almost none. The noticeable rise in Scottish provision prices in 1751 and 1752, when Hume published his Political Discourses and shortly after the great expansion of paper money in Scotland, was probably caused by bad harvests rather than by the increase in paper money.
elegant: Paper money does not necessarily raise prices, because it replaces rather than adds to the existing gold and silver. Provisions in Scotland were cheapest in 1759 despite maximum paper circulation. Scottish-English price ratios remain unchanged since before Scotland's banking expansion. English corn is as cheap as French despite more paper. The 1751-1752 price rise coincided with bad harvests, not paper money expansion.
summary: Smith argues that paper money does not raise prices because it merely replaces gold and silver rather than adding to total currency. He cites evidence from Scotland, England, and France showing no correlation between paper money and provision prices, attributing a 1751-1752 price rise to bad harvests rather than monetary expansion.
distilled: Paper money that merely replaces gold and silver does not increase total currency and therefore does not raise prices.
notes: Smith disputes Hume's quantity theory argument from the Political Discourses (1752), which suggested that increases in money supply raise prices. -- Smith's counter-argument relies on the displacement thesis: paper replaces metal rather than adding to the total stock. -- The empirical evidence marshaled (Scotland 1759, Scotland-England price ratios, England-France comparison) represents an early attempt at econometric reasoning. -- Modern monetary economists would note that Smith's displacement argument holds only if the displaced gold and silver are exported rather than hoarded. -- Cross-reference: 2.2.93 explains the displacement mechanism.

refashioned: The situation would be different, however, with paper money consisting of promissory notes whose immediate payment depended on the goodwill of the issuers, or on a condition that the holder might not always be able to meet, or for which payment was not due until some years later and which bore no interest in the meantime. Such paper money would inevitably fall below the value of gold and silver, to a greater or lesser extent depending on how difficult or uncertain immediate payment was believed to be, or how distant the date at which payment could be demanded.
elegant: Paper money falls below the value of gold and silver whenever its payment depends on the issuer's goodwill, on conditions the holder may not meet, or on a distant future date without interest. The discount reflects the degree of difficulty, uncertainty, or delay in obtaining payment.
summary: Paper money whose redemption is conditional, uncertain, or deferred inevitably trades below the value of gold and silver. The degree of discount reflects the difficulty of obtaining payment.
distilled: Paper money trades below gold and silver value whenever redemption is conditional, uncertain, or delayed without interest.
notes: This passage establishes the spectrum of paper money quality: from perfect equivalence (2.2.103) to discounted value, depending on the conditions of redemption. -- Smith identifies three sources of discount: issuer discretion, holder conditions, and time delay without interest. -- This analysis anticipates the modern concept of credit risk pricing -- the discount reflects the probability-weighted expected loss from non-payment or delayed payment. -- Cross-reference: 2.2.106-2.2.112 provide specific historical examples of each type of defective paper.

refashioned: Some years ago, the various Scottish banking companies inserted what they called an optional clause into their bank notes. This clause promised payment to the bearer either immediately upon presentation or, at the directors' option, six months after presentation together with the legal interest for those six months. Directors of some of these banks sometimes invoked this clause, and sometimes threatened those who demanded gold and silver for large quantities of notes that they would invoke it, unless the demanders accepted only a portion of what they were owed. Since these notes constituted the greater part of Scotland's currency at the time, this uncertainty of payment inevitably depressed their value below that of gold and silver. During the period when this abuse was most prevalent -- chiefly in 1762, 1763, and 1764 -- while the exchange between London and Carlisle stood at par, the exchange between London and Dumfries was sometimes four percent against Dumfries, despite Dumfries being less than thirty miles from Carlisle. The difference was simple: at Carlisle, bills were paid in gold and silver, while at Dumfries they were paid in Scottish bank notes whose convertibility was uncertain. The same act of Parliament that suppressed ten-shilling and five-shilling notes also abolished this optional clause, thereby restoring the exchange between England and Scotland to its natural rate.
elegant: Scottish banks once inserted 'optional clauses' allowing them to delay note payment by six months with interest. Directors sometimes invoked this -- or threatened to -- when holders demanded gold and silver. Since these notes dominated Scotland's currency, the uncertainty depressed them four percent below gold and silver. Dumfries notes traded at a four percent discount to Carlisle, just thirty miles away, because Carlisle paid in metal. Parliament's abolition of the optional clause restored the exchange to its natural rate.
summary: Scottish banks' 'optional clause' allowed them to delay note redemption by six months, creating uncertainty that depressed the currency four percent below gold and silver value. Parliament's abolition of this clause restored proper exchange rates between England and Scotland.
distilled: Scottish banks' optional clause, which allowed six-month payment delays, depressed note values four percent below metal -- corrected only by parliamentary prohibition.
notes: The optional clause is a vivid example of how issuer discretion over payment terms damages currency value -- even when interest is paid for the delay. -- The Carlisle-Dumfries comparison (four percent differential across thirty miles) dramatically illustrates how monetary regimes, not geography, determine exchange rates. -- The parliamentary intervention aligns with Smith's broader argument (2.2.102) that banking regulation is justified when individual liberties endanger the monetary system. -- This episode occurred during Smith's adult life in Scotland and was therefore firsthand observation.

refashioned: In the paper currencies of Yorkshire, payment of a sum as small as sixpence sometimes depended on the condition that the note holder bring the change of a guinea to the person who issued it -- a condition that holders of such notes might frequently find very difficult to meet. This condition must have depressed the value of this currency below that of gold and silver. An act of Parliament accordingly declared all such conditions unlawful and suppressed, as in Scotland, all promissory notes payable to the bearer for less than twenty shillings.
elegant: Yorkshire paper currency sometimes required the holder to provide change for a guinea before receiving payment of a sixpenny note -- a condition often impossible to meet, which necessarily depressed the currency's value. Parliament outlawed such conditions and suppressed all bearer notes under twenty shillings.
summary: Yorkshire paper notes sometimes imposed impossible conditions on redemption, such as requiring the holder to bring change for a guinea. Parliament banned such conditions and all small-denomination bearer notes.
distilled: Yorkshire's conditional redemption clauses depressed paper currency values, prompting Parliament to ban such conditions and small-denomination notes.
notes: The absurdity of requiring the holder to bring change for a guinea to redeem a sixpenny note illustrates how small-denomination issuers could effectively make their notes irredeemable through impractical conditions. -- This is another example of the power asymmetry between note issuers and holders that justified regulation. -- The parliamentary response (banning notes under twenty shillings) applied the same minimum-denomination principle Smith advocates. -- Cross-reference: 2.2.98-2.2.99 on the problems with very small denomination notes.

refashioned: The paper currencies of North America consisted not of bank notes payable on demand to the bearer, but of government paper that could not be redeemed for several years after issue. Although the colonial governments paid no interest to holders, they declared this paper to be -- and in practice made it -- legal tender at its full face value. But even assuming the colonial government's credit was perfectly good, 100 pounds payable fifteen years hence, in a country where interest runs at six percent, is worth little more than 40 pounds in ready money. Forcing a creditor to accept this as full payment for a debt of 100 pounds actually paid in cash was an act of such violent injustice as has scarcely been attempted by any government claiming to be free. It bears the obvious marks of being, as the honest and forthright Doctor Douglas assures us, a scheme of fraudulent debtors to cheat their creditors.
elegant: North American paper currencies were not bank notes but government paper redeemable only years later, with no interest. Even with perfect government credit, 100 pounds payable in fifteen years at six percent interest is worth barely 40 pounds today. Forcing creditors to accept this as full payment for debts paid in cash was an act of violent injustice -- a scheme, as Doctor Douglas bluntly called it, of fraudulent debtors cheating their creditors.
summary: Colonial American paper money was government-issued, non-interest-bearing, and redeemable only years later. Making it legal tender at face value forced creditors to accept what was worth far less than ready money -- an act of injustice Smith calls a scheme to defraud creditors.
distilled: Colonial American paper money, redeemable only years later without interest, was legal tender at face value -- effectively a scheme to defraud creditors.
notes: Smith applies time-value-of-money reasoning: 100 pounds payable in fifteen years at six percent is worth roughly 40 pounds today (the present value calculation). -- His characterization of legal tender laws as 'violent injustice' and 'a scheme of fraudulent debtors' is unusually strong language, reflecting deep opposition to forced currency acceptance. -- Doctor Douglas refers to William Douglass, whose Summary, Historical and Political (1749-1752) criticized colonial paper money. -- This passage contributed to the Constitutional Convention's decision to restrict states from issuing paper money (Article I, Section 10). -- Cross-reference: 2.2.109 describes Pennsylvania's attempt to enforce parity through penalties.

refashioned: Pennsylvania, when it first issued paper money in 1722, attempted to make its paper equal in value to gold and silver by imposing penalties on anyone who charged different prices depending on whether payment was in colonial paper or in metal. This regulation was equally tyrannical but far less effective than the legal tender law it was meant to support. A positive law can make a shilling legal tender for a guinea, since courts can be directed to discharge a debtor who offers that tender. But no positive law can force a seller -- who is free to sell or not sell as he pleases -- to accept a shilling as equivalent to a guinea in the price of his goods. Despite such regulations, the exchange rate with Great Britain showed that 100 pounds sterling was sometimes considered equivalent to 130 pounds, and in some colonies to as much as 1,100 pounds, in colonial currency. This variation in value reflected differences in the quantity of paper issued by different colonies and in the perceived distance and probability of eventual redemption.
elegant: Pennsylvania tried to enforce paper-metal parity in 1722 by penalizing anyone who priced goods differently for paper versus gold. But while law can force courts to accept a shilling as a guinea, it cannot force sellers to price their goods accordingly. Exchange rates revealed the truth: 100 pounds sterling equaled 130 pounds in some colonies and up to 1,100 pounds in others -- varying with how much paper each colony had issued and how likely redemption seemed.
summary: Pennsylvania's attempt to enforce paper-metal parity through price controls failed because law cannot compel sellers to accept paper at face value. Exchange rates revealed that colonial currencies traded at steep discounts to sterling, ranging from 30 percent to over 1,000 percent, depending on each colony's issuance and redemption prospects.
distilled: Pennsylvania's attempt to enforce paper-metal parity through penalties failed because no law can compel sellers to accept overvalued currency in voluntary transactions.
notes: Smith distinguishes between legal tender power (courts must accept the tender) and market value (sellers set their own prices) -- a fundamental insight about the limits of monetary legislation. -- The enormous range of colonial currency values (from 130 to 1,100 per 100 sterling) demonstrates how dramatically different monetary policies produced different outcomes. -- This passage is one of Smith's strongest arguments against price controls and forced currency acceptance. -- Cross-reference: 2.2.110 concludes with Smith's endorsement of Parliament's legal tender prohibition.

refashioned:
No law, therefore, could be more fair than the act of Parliament -- so unjustly complained of in the colonies -- which declared that no paper currency issued in the colonies henceforth should be legal tender.

Pennsylvania was always more restrained in its paper money issuance than any other colony. Its paper currency reportedly never fell below the value of the gold and silver circulating in the colony before its first paper emission. Before that emission, the colony had already inflated the denomination of its coinage, ordering by legislative act that 5 shillings sterling should pass for 6 shillings 3 pence, and later for 6 shillings 8 pence. A pound in colonial currency, therefore -- even when that currency was gold and silver -- was already more than thirty percent below the value of one pound sterling; and when the currency became paper, it was seldom much more than thirty percent below that value. The stated reason for inflating coin denominations was to prevent the export of gold and silver by making equal quantities of metal pass for larger sums in the colony than in the mother country. But the price of all imported goods rose in exact proportion to the denomination increase, so gold and silver were exported just as fast as before.
elegant: Parliament's act prohibiting colonial paper from being legal tender was entirely just. Pennsylvania, the most restrained colony, never let its paper fall below pre-existing coin values -- but those coins had already been inflated thirty percent above sterling by legislative fiat. The nominal increase was meant to prevent metal exports, but import prices rose in exact proportion, and gold and silver flowed out as fast as ever.
summary: Smith endorses Parliament's prohibition of colonial legal tender as entirely fair. Even Pennsylvania, the most restrained colony, had already inflated its coin denominations thirty percent above sterling -- a measure intended to prevent metal exports that failed because import prices rose proportionally.
distilled: Parliament justly prohibited colonial legal tender; even Pennsylvania's restrained approach failed to prevent gold and silver exports because prices adjusted to offset denomination inflation.
notes: Smith endorses parliamentary authority over colonial monetary policy -- a politically charged position given American resistance to such oversight. -- The failure of denomination inflation to prevent metal exports illustrates the neutrality-of-money principle: nominal changes do not alter real trade flows. -- Pennsylvania's relative prudence (paper never falling below pre-existing coin values) shows that responsible paper money management was possible, even if rare. -- This analysis directly contributed to American constitutional debates about state paper money and legal tender.

refashioned: Because each colony's paper was accepted at full face value for the payment of provincial taxes, it necessarily gained some additional value beyond what its perceived redemption timeline alone would have given it. This additional value was greater or lesser depending on whether the quantity of paper issued was more or less above what could actually be used for tax payments in that particular colony. In all the colonies, the amount of paper issued far exceeded what could be employed for this purpose.
elegant: Colonial paper derived additional value from being accepted at face value for provincial taxes. The degree of additional value depended on how much paper exceeded what tax payments actually required -- and in all colonies, issuance far exceeded this amount.
summary: Colonial paper money gained value from its acceptance for tax payments at face value, but all colonies issued far more paper than could be absorbed through taxation, limiting this support for the currency's value.
distilled: Colonial paper gained value from tax acceptability but was always issued in quantities far exceeding what tax payments could absorb.
notes: Smith identifies what modern monetary theory calls 'tax-driven demand' for money -- currency derives value partly from being the medium in which taxes must be paid. -- This is a proto-chartalist insight: the state creates demand for its currency by requiring taxes to be paid in it. -- However, Smith shows the limits of this mechanism: when issuance vastly exceeds tax demand, the additional value is marginal. -- Cross-reference: 2.2.112 generalizes this principle to hypothetical cases.

refashioned: A prince who required that a certain proportion of his taxes be paid in a particular kind of paper money could thereby give that paper money a certain value, even if the timing of its final redemption depended entirely on his will. If the issuing bank kept the quantity of paper always somewhat below what could easily be used for this purpose, the demand for it could even make it trade at a premium -- selling for more in the market than the gold or silver for which it was issued. Some people explain in this way the so-called agio of the Bank of Amsterdam -- the premium that bank money commanded over current money -- even though bank money supposedly could not be withdrawn at the owner's will. Since the greater part of foreign bills of exchange had to be paid in bank money through transfers in the bank's books, and since the directors allegedly kept the supply of bank money below what this use demanded, the bank money supposedly sold at a premium of four or five percent above the equivalent amount in the country's gold and silver currency. This account of the Bank of Amsterdam, however, as will appear later, is largely fanciful.
elegant: A prince could give paper money value by requiring taxes in it, even without guaranteed redemption. If supply were kept below tax demand, the paper could even trade at a premium. Some explain the Bank of Amsterdam's four-to-five percent agio this way: foreign bills had to be paid in bank money, and directors allegedly restricted supply below demand. But this account, as Smith will show later, is largely fanciful.
summary: Paper money can gain value if taxes must be paid in it, and can even trade at a premium if supply is restricted below demand. Smith applies this principle to the Bank of Amsterdam's agio but signals that the standard explanation is largely incorrect.
distilled: Paper money can trade at a premium over metal if its supply is kept below the demand created by tax and payment obligations, though the standard explanation of Amsterdam's agio is flawed.
notes: The Bank of Amsterdam (Wisselbank, founded 1609) was the most important European financial institution of the early modern period. -- Its 'agio' (the premium of bank money over current money) was a central puzzle of 18th-century monetary theory. -- Smith's promise to debunk the standard explanation foreshadows his detailed treatment of the Bank of Amsterdam later in the Wealth of Nations. -- The principle that restricted supply plus mandatory demand creates value anticipates modern understanding of how central bank operations affect interest rates and currency values.

refashioned: A paper currency that falls below the value of gold and silver coin does not thereby reduce the value of those metals or cause equal quantities of them to exchange for fewer goods. The relationship between the value of gold and silver and the value of other goods depends in all cases not on the nature or quantity of any particular country's paper money, but on the richness or poverty of the mines that at any given time supply the world's commercial markets with those metals. It depends on the ratio between the labor required to bring a certain quantity of gold and silver to market and the labor required to bring a certain quantity of any other goods to market.
elegant: Depreciated paper does not drag down the value of gold and silver. The value of those metals depends not on any country's paper money but on the productivity of the world's mines -- specifically, on the ratio of labor needed to produce gold and silver versus the labor needed to produce other goods.
summary: Depreciated paper money does not reduce the value of gold and silver. Metal values are determined by global mine productivity and the labor required to extract them, not by any particular country's paper money situation.
distilled: Depreciated paper money does not reduce the value of gold and silver, which is determined by global mine productivity and labor costs.
notes: Smith distinguishes between the relative value of paper versus metal (determined locally by monetary policy) and the absolute value of metal versus goods (determined globally by mining costs). -- This is a labor theory of value applied to precious metals: their value depends on the labor required to produce them. -- The global scope of the argument is important: no single country's paper money can affect the world price of gold and silver. -- Cross-reference: Book I's discussion of the labor theory of value; 2.2.104 on paper money and prices.

refashioned: If bankers are prohibited from issuing circulating bank notes for less than a certain minimum amount, and if they are required to pay their notes immediately and unconditionally upon presentation, then their business may safely be left entirely free in all other respects. The recent multiplication of banking companies throughout the United Kingdom, which has alarmed many people, actually increases rather than decreases public security. It forces all banks to be more careful in their conduct and, by keeping their note circulation in proper proportion to their cash reserves, to protect themselves against the hostile runs that so many competitors are always ready to launch against them. It confines each bank's circulation to a narrower area and reduces its notes to a smaller quantity. By dividing the total circulation among a greater number of participants, the failure of any one bank -- an event that must occasionally occur -- becomes less consequential to the public. This free competition also forces all bankers to deal more generously with their customers, lest rivals steal them away. In general, in any branch of trade or division of labor that benefits the public, the freer and more widespread the competition, the greater the benefit will always be.
elegant: With two restrictions -- a minimum denomination and unconditional on-demand payment -- banking can safely be left entirely free. The multiplication of banks actually increases security by forcing each to be more prudent, confining circulation to narrower circles, and making any single failure less consequential. Free competition also forces better service. In general, the freer the competition in any beneficial trade, the greater the public benefit.
summary: Smith argues that with just two regulations -- minimum note denominations and unconditional on-demand payment -- banking should be completely free. More banks mean more competition, greater prudence, narrower circulation, smaller systemic risk from individual failures, and better customer service.
distilled: With minimum denominations and unconditional payment enforced, free banking competition increases public security by making banks more prudent and individual failures less consequential.
notes: This is Smith's definitive statement on banking regulation: two simple rules (minimum denominations and unconditional payment) are sufficient, and all other banking activity should be free. -- The argument that more competitors increase stability by diversifying risk is remarkably modern -- it anticipates the 'too big to fail' critique and arguments for diversified banking systems. -- Smith's reasoning that competition forces prudence contrasts sharply with the later argument that competition drives risk-taking (the 'competition-fragility' view). -- This passage completes Smith's banking chapter by synthesizing his case for free competition within a minimal regulatory framework. -- Cross-reference: 2.2.102 on the justification for the two regulations.

refashioned: There is one kind of labor that adds to the value of the thing it is applied to, and another kind that does not. The first may be called productive labor, since it creates value; the second, unproductive labor. The labor of a manufacturer generally adds to the value of his materials both the cost of his own wages and his master's profit. The labor of a household servant, by contrast, adds value to nothing. Although the manufacturer receives his wages from his employer in advance, he actually costs his employer nothing, since the value of those wages is restored -- with a profit -- in the improved value of the product. But the cost of maintaining a household servant is never recovered. A man grows rich by employing many manufacturers; he grows poor by maintaining many servants. The labor of servants is not without value and deserves its reward just as much as the manufacturer's. But the manufacturer's labor is embodied in some particular object or sellable commodity that endures at least for some time after the work is done. It is, so to speak, a quantity of labor stored up to be deployed on some future occasion. That object, or its price, can afterward set in motion a quantity of labor equal to what originally produced it. The labor of a household servant, by contrast, is not embodied in any object or commodity. His services generally perish the instant they are performed, rarely leaving any trace of value for which an equivalent service could be obtained.
elegant: Labor that adds value to its material -- embodying itself in a durable, sellable product -- is productive. Labor whose services perish instantly -- like that of a household servant -- is unproductive, though equally deserving of its wages. A manufacturer's wages are recovered with profit in the improved value of his product; a servant's wages are never recovered. A man grows rich by employing manufacturers and poor by maintaining servants. Productive labor stores up value in commodities that can later command equivalent labor.
summary: Smith distinguishes productive labor, which adds value to materials and is embodied in durable, sellable goods, from unproductive labor, whose services perish the moment they are performed. A manufacturer's wages are recovered through the improved value of his product, while a servant's wages are never recovered.
distilled: Productive labor adds value embodied in durable goods; unproductive labor provides services that perish instantly, regardless of their social worth.
notes: Smith's productive/unproductive distinction became one of the most debated concepts in classical economics. -- Marx adopted and expanded this distinction, while later marginalist economists largely rejected it. -- The footnote reference to 'some French authors' means the Physiocrats (Quesnay, Turgot), who defined only agricultural labor as truly productive. -- Smith's criterion is durability of output: productive labor produces vendible commodities, while unproductive labor produces ephemeral services. -- Modern economics largely rejects this distinction, treating all labor that satisfies demand as productive. -- Cross-reference: 2.3.2 extends the classification to include soldiers, lawyers, clergy, and artists.

refashioned: The labor of some of society's most respected groups is, like that of household servants, unproductive -- it does not embed itself in any permanent object or sellable commodity that endures beyond the performance itself. The sovereign and all the officers of justice and war who serve under him, the entire army and navy, are unproductive laborers. They are servants of the public, maintained by a portion of the annual product of other people's industry. Their service, however honorable, useful, or necessary, produces nothing for which an equivalent amount of service could later be obtained. The protection, security, and defense that their labor provides this year will not purchase the country's protection, security, and defense for next year. In the same category belong some of the most serious and important professions, as well as some of the most frivolous: clergy, lawyers, physicians, men of letters of all kinds, actors, jesters, musicians, opera singers, and dancers. The labor of the humblest among them has a value determined by the same principles that govern all other labor, and that of the noblest and most useful produces nothing that could afterward purchase or procure an equal amount of labor. Like the actor's performance, the orator's speech, or the musician's melody, the work of all of them perishes in the very instant of its creation.
elegant: The sovereign, the military, judges, clergy, lawyers, physicians, men of letters, actors, and musicians are all unproductive laborers by this definition. However honorable or necessary their work, it produces no durable commodity. This year's national defense cannot purchase next year's. Like the actor's performance, their work perishes the instant it is created. Their labor has value and deserves reward, but it leaves behind nothing that could command equivalent labor in the future.
summary: Smith classifies many respected professions -- from the military and judiciary to clergy, physicians, and performers -- as unproductive because their work, however valuable, produces no durable commodity. Like an actor's performance, their contributions perish the moment they are created.
distilled: Soldiers, judges, clergy, lawyers, physicians, and performers are all unproductive laborers because their valuable services perish instantly rather than embedding in durable goods.
notes: Smith's inclusion of kings, soldiers, lawyers, clergy, and entertainers in the same 'unproductive' category was deliberately provocative. -- He is careful to note that unproductive labor 'has its value and deserves its reward' -- the distinction is economic, not moral. -- The observation that this year's defense cannot purchase next year's captures a real economic property of services versus goods. -- This classification influenced the Soviet-era distinction between 'productive' and 'non-productive' sectors in national income accounting. -- Cross-reference: 2.3.1 establishes the theoretical basis; 2.3.3 explains why the proportion between productive and unproductive labor matters.

refashioned: Both productive and unproductive workers, and those who do not work at all, are equally maintained by the annual produce of the country's land and labor. This produce, however great, can never be infinite and must have certain limits. The larger the proportion devoted in any year to maintaining unproductive workers, the less remains for productive workers, and next year's produce will be correspondingly smaller -- since the entire annual product, apart from the earth's spontaneous yield, is the result of productive labor.
elegant: All people -- productive workers, unproductive workers, and the idle -- are maintained by the same finite annual produce. The more that goes to unproductive hands, the less remains for productive ones, and next year's output shrinks accordingly. All annual produce, beyond nature's spontaneous yield, results from productive labor.
summary: A country's finite annual produce maintains everyone -- productive workers, unproductive workers, and the idle. The more devoted to unproductive hands, the less supports productive labor, reducing the following year's output.
distilled: The proportion of annual produce devoted to unproductive labor directly reduces the productive labor available to generate next year's output.
notes: This is the macroeconomic consequence of the productive/unproductive distinction: the allocation of output between the two types of labor determines the trajectory of future output. -- The logic is essentially a growth model: output depends on productive labor, so diverting resources to unproductive uses reduces the growth rate. -- The qualification about 'spontaneous productions of the earth' acknowledges that nature contributes independently of human labor. -- This passage influenced the Physiocratic net-product concept and later classical growth theory. -- Cross-reference: 2.3.7 extends this analysis to the determinants of a country's productive character.

refashioned: Although the entire annual produce of every country's land and labor is ultimately destined to supply its inhabitants' consumption and provide them with revenue, when it first emerges -- either from the ground or from the hands of productive workers -- it naturally divides into two parts. One part, often the largest, is destined first to replace a capital: to renew the provisions, materials, and finished goods that had been drawn from that capital. The other part goes to constitute a revenue, either to the capital's owner as profit on his stock, or to some other person as rent on his land. Thus, from the produce of farmland, one part replaces the farmer's capital while the other pays his profit and the landlord's rent, constituting revenue for both. From the output of a large factory, similarly, one part -- always the largest -- replaces the entrepreneur's capital, while the other constitutes his profit.
elegant: Annual produce divides naturally into two parts when it first emerges: one to replace capital (provisions, materials, and finished goods consumed in production), and one to constitute revenue (profit for the capital owner, rent for the landlord). In farming, one part replaces the farmer's capital while the other pays his profit and the landlord's rent. In manufacturing, the larger part replaces the entrepreneur's capital; the remainder is his profit.
summary: The annual produce of land and labor divides naturally into two parts: one that replaces the capital consumed in production (provisions, materials, finished goods), and one that constitutes revenue as profit or rent. In both farming and manufacturing, capital replacement typically claims the larger share.
distilled: Annual produce divides into capital replacement (the larger share) and revenue (profit and rent), with capital replacement funding productive labor and revenue funding either productive or unproductive hands.
notes: This is Smith's version of the fundamental accounting identity in national income: output equals capital consumption plus net income (profit and rent). -- The observation that capital replacement usually claims the largest share emphasizes how much of economic activity is merely maintaining the existing stock, not creating new wealth. -- Smith's two-part division anticipates the Marxian distinction between constant capital (replaced) and surplus value (profit and rent). -- Cross-reference: 2.3.5 explains who is maintained by each part.

refashioned:
The portion of annual produce that replaces a capital is never immediately used to maintain anyone but productive workers. It pays the wages of productive labor only. The portion that constitutes revenue -- whether as profit or rent -- may maintain either productive or unproductive workers indifferently.

Whatever part of his stock a man employs as capital, he always expects it to be returned to him with a profit. He therefore employs it only to maintain productive workers, and after serving as capital for him, it becomes revenue for them. Whenever he uses any part of it to maintain unproductive workers, that part is immediately withdrawn from his capital and placed in his stock reserved for immediate consumption.
elegant: Capital replacement funds pay only productive workers. Revenue (profit and rent) may support either productive or unproductive hands. A man employs his capital to maintain productive workers, expecting a profitable return. Any amount diverted to unproductive workers is instantly transferred from capital to consumption.
summary: Capital replacement exclusively funds productive labor, while revenue from profit and rent can support either productive or unproductive workers. Any capital diverted to maintain unproductive workers ceases to be capital and becomes consumption.
distilled: Capital replacement funds only productive workers; revenue may fund either -- and any capital diverted to unproductive hands ceases to function as capital.
notes: Smith establishes the flow of funds: capital naturally cycles through productive workers, while revenue can go either way. -- The key insight is that diverting capital to unproductive uses is a one-way valve -- it cannot return to the capital stock. -- This creates an asymmetry: frugality (saving revenue into capital) builds the economy, while prodigality (consuming capital) shrinks it. -- Cross-reference: 2.3.6 details the sources of maintenance for unproductive laborers; 2.3.17-2.3.21 develop the frugality vs. prodigality theme.

refashioned: Unproductive workers, and those who do not work at all, are all maintained by revenue. This comes from two sources: first, from the portion of annual produce originally intended as revenue for particular persons, whether as land rent or as profits on stock; and second, from the portion originally intended to replace capital and maintain productive workers alone, but which, once it reaches their hands, can be spent beyond their necessary subsistence on maintaining either productive or unproductive people. Thus not only the great landlord or the rich merchant, but even an ordinary worker whose wages are substantial, may keep a household servant, attend a play or puppet show -- thereby helping to support one set of unproductive workers -- or pay taxes, thereby helping to support another set that is more honorable and useful but equally unproductive. However, no portion of annual produce originally destined to replace capital is ever directed toward maintaining unproductive workers until after it has set in motion its full complement of productive labor. The worker must have earned his wages through work done before he can spend any part of them this way, and that part is generally small. It is only his surplus revenue, of which productive workers seldom have a great deal -- though they usually have some, and the sheer number of them paying taxes can partly compensate for the smallness of each contribution. Land rent and profits on stock are therefore everywhere the main sources from which unproductive workers draw their subsistence. Owners of these two types of revenue generally have the most to spare, and they might support either productive or unproductive workers with it. They seem, however, to have some preference for the latter. The spending of a great lord generally feeds more idle than industrious people. A rich merchant, though his capital maintains only industrious people, tends in his personal spending -- that is, in his use of revenue -- to support the same idle sort as the great lord.
elegant: Unproductive workers are maintained by revenue from two sources: the portion of produce intended as rent and profit, and the surplus wages of productive workers beyond their subsistence. But no capital-replacement funds reach unproductive hands until productive labor is fully employed. Workers must earn their wages first, and their surplus is small -- though their numbers compensate in taxes. Rent and profit are therefore the main support of unproductive hands. The rich, who could support either type of worker, tend to prefer the unproductive: great lords feed the idle, and rich merchants spend their personal revenue in the same manner.
summary: Unproductive workers are supported by rent, profit, and the small surplus wages of productive workers. Capital never supports unproductive hands until all productive labor is employed. Rent and profit are the primary sources, and their owners tend to spend disproportionately on maintaining idle rather than industrious people.
distilled: Unproductive labor is sustained mainly by rent and profit, with wealthy owners tending to spend their revenue on maintaining the idle rather than the industrious.
notes: Smith identifies a structural tendency: owners of rent and profit tend to prefer spending on unproductive labor (servants, entertainment, display). -- The distinction between how the rich employ their capital (productively) and how they spend their revenue (unproductively) is important -- the merchant maintains industrious workers through his business but idle ones through his personal spending. -- The observation that workers' surplus revenue is small but their aggregate tax contribution is significant anticipates the concept of the broad tax base. -- Cross-reference: 2.3.7 explains how the capital/revenue ratio determines a country's productive character.

refashioned: The ratio of productive to unproductive workers in every country therefore depends largely on the ratio between the portion of annual produce that, as soon as it comes from the ground or from the hands of productive workers, is destined to replace capital, and the portion destined to constitute revenue as rent or profit. This ratio is very different in rich countries compared to poor ones.
elegant: The ratio of productive to unproductive workers depends on how much annual produce goes to replacing capital versus how much becomes revenue as rent or profit. This ratio differs greatly between rich and poor countries.
summary: A country's balance between productive and unproductive labor depends on how much of its annual output replaces capital versus how much becomes revenue. Rich and poor countries differ significantly in this ratio.
distilled: The productive/unproductive labor ratio in any country is determined by the share of annual produce devoted to capital replacement versus revenue.
notes: This is the key structural variable in Smith's growth theory: the capital-to-revenue ratio determines the productive character of the economy. -- Rich countries have a higher capital-to-revenue ratio, meaning more of their output replaces capital (and thus maintains productive labor). -- This anticipates the modern emphasis on savings rates and capital accumulation as determinants of economic growth. -- Cross-reference: 2.3.8-2.3.10 develop the historical comparison between medieval and modern Europe.

refashioned: In today's wealthy European countries, a very large share of agricultural output -- often the largest -- goes to replacing the capital of the prosperous independent farmer, with the remainder paying his profits and the landlord's rent. But in ancient times, under feudalism, only a tiny fraction of produce was needed to replace the capital used in cultivation. That capital typically consisted of a few miserable cattle fed entirely on the natural produce of uncultivated land, and could therefore be considered part of that natural produce. It usually belonged to the landlord and was advanced by him to those who worked the land. All the rest of the produce also belonged to the landlord, whether as rent for his land or as profit on this meager capital. The cultivators were generally serfs whose persons and possessions alike were his property. Those who were not serfs were tenants at will; though the rent they paid was often nominally little more than a token, it effectively amounted to the whole produce of the land. Their lord could command their labor in peace and their military service in war at any time. Though they lived far from his house, they were as dependent on him as the retainers who lived in it. The entire produce of the land undoubtedly belongs to whoever can dispose of the labor and service of all those it maintains. In modern Europe, the landlord's share seldom exceeds a third, sometimes not a quarter, of the total produce. Yet land rents in all improved areas have tripled or quadrupled since those ancient times; so this third or quarter of today's produce appears to be three or four times greater than the entire produce was then. As improvement progresses, rent increases in proportion to the land's extent but decreases in proportion to its produce.
elegant: In modern Europe, the largest share of agricultural output replaces the farmer's capital, with the rest paying profit and rent. Under feudalism, almost no capital was needed -- just a few wretched cattle grazing uncultivated land. The landlord owned virtually everything: the capital, the produce, and often the cultivators themselves. In modern Europe, the landlord takes only a third or quarter of output -- yet this fraction is three or four times larger than the entire medieval output. As improvement advances, rent rises absolutely but falls as a share of production.
summary: Under feudalism, nearly all agricultural produce accrued to the landlord as rent or profit on minimal capital, with cultivators having little independence. In modern Europe, the landlord's share has fallen to a third or less, yet this fraction exceeds the entire medieval output because productivity has increased so dramatically.
distilled: The shift from feudalism to modern farming dramatically increased the share of output devoted to capital replacement, leaving landlords a smaller but absolutely larger share of vastly greater total production.
notes: Smith contrasts the feudal economy (nearly all output = revenue/rent, almost nothing for capital replacement) with the modern economy (most output replaces capital, leaving a smaller but absolutely larger revenue). -- The observation that rent increases absolutely but decreases as a percentage of output is a key insight about economic development. -- The description of feudal cultivators as serfs or tenants at will illustrates how economic dependency and political subjection were intertwined. -- Cross-reference: Book III provides Smith's full account of the transition from feudalism to commercial society.

refashioned: In the wealthy countries of Europe today, great amounts of capital are employed in trade and manufacturing. In earlier times, the little trade that existed and the few crude manufactures that were carried on required only very small capitals. These must, however, have yielded very large profits. The interest rate was nowhere below ten percent, and profits must have been high enough to support this great interest. Today, in the advanced parts of Europe, the interest rate is nowhere above six percent, and in the most advanced regions it runs as low as four, three, or even two percent. Although the total profit income of a rich country's inhabitants is always much greater than that of a poor country, this is because the stock of capital is so much larger; relative to the stock, the profit rate is generally much lower.
elegant: Modern Europe employs vast capital in trade and manufacturing, earning lower profit rates. Medieval trade required tiny capitals but yielded enormous profits -- interest was never below ten percent. Today, interest ranges from two to six percent. Rich countries earn more total profit than poor ones, but only because they have so much more capital -- the rate of return is much lower.
summary: Modern economies employ far more capital in trade and manufacturing than medieval ones did, but at much lower rates of profit. Interest rates have fallen from over ten percent to as low as two percent. Rich countries earn more total profit only because they deploy much more capital, not because their returns are higher.
distilled: Economic development greatly increases the stock of capital employed while reducing the rate of profit -- total profit income rises only because capital grows faster than margins shrink.
notes: Smith identifies the inverse relationship between the accumulation of capital and the rate of return -- one of the most important regularities in classical economics. -- The decline in interest rates from ten percent to two-to-six percent over several centuries is used as a proxy for the decline in profit rates. -- This observation anticipates both Ricardo's falling rate of profit and Piketty's analysis of returns to capital versus growth. -- Cross-reference: 2.3.10 draws the macroeconomic implications for the productive character of rich versus poor countries.

refashioned: The portion of annual produce destined to replace capital is therefore not only much larger in rich countries than in poor ones, but also represents a much greater share relative to the portion going to revenue as rent or profit. The funds available for maintaining productive labor are not only much larger in rich countries but bear a much greater proportion to those funds which, though available for maintaining either productive or unproductive workers, tend to favor the latter.
elegant: In rich countries, capital replacement claims not only a larger absolute amount but a larger share of annual produce relative to revenue. The funds for productive labor vastly exceed -- proportionally and absolutely -- those available for revenue spending, which tends toward unproductive uses.
summary: Rich countries devote a larger absolute amount and a larger proportion of their annual produce to capital replacement compared to poor countries, leaving proportionally less for revenue spending that tends to support unproductive labor.
distilled: Rich countries devote both more capital and a higher share of output to capital replacement, structurally favoring productive over unproductive labor.
notes: This is the structural conclusion of Smith's growth theory: development increases both the level and the share of output devoted to capital replacement. -- The compounding effect (larger capital stock producing more output, more of which replaces capital) explains why rich countries tend to grow richer. -- The 'predilection for the latter' (revenue owners favoring unproductive labor) is a structural drag on growth that is overcome in rich countries by the dominance of capital. -- Cross-reference: 2.3.11 applies this framework to explain national character differences.

refashioned: The ratio between these different funds necessarily determines the general character of a country's inhabitants regarding industry or idleness. We are more industrious than our ancestors because the funds devoted to maintaining industry are now far greater, relative to those likely to support idleness, than they were two or three centuries ago. Our ancestors were idle for lack of sufficient incentive to work. As the proverb says: it is better to play for nothing than to work for nothing. In commercial and manufacturing towns, where the lower ranks are mainly supported by the employment of capital, people are generally industrious, sober, and prosperous -- as in many English and most Dutch towns. In towns supported mainly by the constant or occasional presence of a royal court, where the lower ranks are chiefly maintained by the spending of revenue, people are generally idle, dissolute, and poor -- as in Rome, Versailles, Compiegne, and Fontainebleau.
elegant: The capital-to-revenue ratio determines whether a population is industrious or idle. We are more industrious than our ancestors because more funds now support industry relative to idleness. Commercial towns supported by capital produce industrious, sober, thriving people -- as in English and Dutch towns. Court towns supported by revenue produce idle, dissolute, poor people -- as in Rome, Versailles, Compiegne, and Fontainebleau.
summary: The ratio of capital-funded to revenue-funded activity shapes a population's character. Commercial towns where people are maintained by capital employment tend to be industrious and prosperous, while court towns where people are maintained by revenue spending tend to be idle and poor.
distilled: Capital-based economies produce industrious populations; revenue-based economies produce idle ones -- as illustrated by the contrast between commercial and court towns.
notes: Smith moves from economic theory to social analysis: the structure of economic activity shapes the character of the population. -- The contrast between commercial towns (London, Amsterdam) and court towns (Rome, Versailles) is empirically grounded in Smith's observations during his European travels. -- The proverb 'it is better to play for nothing than to work for nothing' captures the rational response to an economy where effort brings no reward. -- This anticipates Max Weber's thesis about the relationship between economic structures and cultural values. -- Cross-reference: 2.3.12-2.3.15 develop specific European examples.

refashioned: With the exception of Rouen and Bordeaux, there is little trade or industry in any of the French parliament towns. The lower ranks of people, being mainly supported by the spending of court of justice members and those who come to plead before them, are generally idle and poor. The great trade of Rouen and Bordeaux seems entirely due to their geographic positions. Rouen is necessarily the distribution point for almost all goods brought from foreign countries or from France's maritime provinces for consumption in Paris. Bordeaux similarly serves as the distribution point for wines grown along the Garonne and its tributaries -- one of the richest wine regions in the world, producing wines seemingly best suited for export and most appealing to foreign tastes.
elegant: Except for Rouen and Bordeaux, French parliament towns have little trade, and their populations -- maintained by judicial spending -- are idle and poor. Rouen's and Bordeaux's commerce stems from geographic advantage: Rouen as the gateway for goods destined for Paris, and Bordeaux as the export hub for the Garonne's world-class wines.
summary: Most French parliament towns are idle and poor because their populations depend on judicial spending rather than trade. Rouen and Bordeaux are exceptions only because their geographic positions make them natural trade hubs -- for Paris-bound goods and Garonne valley wines respectively.
distilled: French parliament towns are generally idle because they depend on judicial revenue, while Rouen and Bordeaux thrive only thanks to their geographic advantages as trade hubs.
notes: The 'parliament towns' are cities with parlements -- France's regional appeal courts under the ancien regime. -- Smith's observation that geographic advantage creates trade independent of institutional structures anticipates modern economic geography. -- Bordeaux's wine trade was already internationally important in the 18th century, with strong English demand for claret. -- Cross-reference: 2.3.13 compares these cities with Paris, Madrid, Vienna, London, Lisbon, and Copenhagen.

refashioned: Such advantageous positions naturally attract large amounts of capital through the employment opportunities they provide, and it is this employment of capital that drives the industry of these two cities. In the other French parliament towns, little more capital is employed than what is needed to supply their own consumption -- barely the minimum amount possible. The same can be said of Paris, Madrid, and Vienna. Of these three, Paris is by far the most industrious, but it is chiefly the market for its own manufactures and the main consumer of its own trade. London, Lisbon, and Copenhagen are perhaps the only three European cities that are both permanent seats of a royal court and genuine trading cities -- cities that trade not only for their own consumption but for that of other cities and countries.
elegant: Geographic advantage attracts capital to Rouen and Bordeaux, driving their industry. Other French parliament towns employ only enough capital for their own consumption. Similarly, Paris, Madrid, and Vienna mainly serve themselves. Only London, Lisbon, and Copenhagen combine being court cities with being genuine trading centers that serve external markets.
summary: While Rouen and Bordeaux attract capital through geographic advantage, most court and parliament cities employ only enough capital for local consumption. London, Lisbon, and Copenhagen are unique in Europe as cities that combine a permanent royal court with genuine external trade.
distilled: Only London, Lisbon, and Copenhagen among European capitals successfully combine being court cities with being genuine trading centers serving external markets.
notes: Smith's comparative urban analysis is remarkably sophisticated, distinguishing between cities that attract capital through natural advantage, those that serve only local consumption, and the rare cases combining court and trade functions. -- The observation about Paris being primarily self-serving contradicts the common view of Paris as a great commercial center. -- London's success in combining court and trade functions is attributed to its geographic situation (2.3.14), not to any inherent superiority of British institutions. -- Cross-reference: 2.3.14-2.3.15 explain why geographic advantage matters.

refashioned: The geographic position of all three -- London, Lisbon, and Copenhagen -- is extremely advantageous and naturally suits them to serve as distribution points for a great volume of goods destined for distant consumers. In a city where a large revenue is spent, it is probably harder to employ capital profitably for purposes other than supplying that city's own consumption than it is in a city where the lower ranks have no support except what comes from the employment of capital. The idleness of most people maintained by revenue spending probably corrupts the industry of those who should be maintained by capital employment, making it less profitable to invest capital there than elsewhere. There was little trade or industry in Edinburgh before the Union.
elegant: London, Lisbon, and Copenhagen owe their trading success to geographic positions that make them natural distribution hubs. In court cities where revenue maintains the population, the prevailing idleness corrupts the industriousness of those who should be maintained by capital, making investment less profitable. Edinburgh had little trade before the Union of 1707.
summary: London, Lisbon, and Copenhagen thrive as trading cities because of their geographic advantages as distribution hubs. In court cities, the idleness of revenue-maintained populations corrupts the industry of capital-maintained workers, discouraging productive investment. Edinburgh exemplifies this before the 1707 Union.
distilled: Court city idleness corrupts productive industry by cultural contagion, making capital investment less profitable and requiring exceptional geographic advantage to overcome.
notes: Smith introduces a social contagion argument: the idleness of revenue-maintained populations corrupts the work ethic of those around them. -- This 'corruption of industry' thesis goes beyond simple resource allocation to include behavioral effects -- a proto-sociological argument. -- Edinburgh before the Union is used as a case study, setting up the dramatic contrast with post-Union Edinburgh and Glasgow. -- Cross-reference: 2.3.15 develops the Edinburgh-Glasgow comparison.

refashioned: When the Scottish Parliament was no longer assembled in Edinburgh, and the city ceased to be the necessary residence of Scotland's principal nobility and gentry, it became a city of some trade and industry. However, it still houses Scotland's principal courts of justice, the customs and excise boards, and other institutions, so considerable revenue continues to be spent there. In trade and industry, Edinburgh remains much inferior to Glasgow, whose inhabitants are primarily maintained by the employment of capital. It has sometimes been observed that the inhabitants of a large village, having made considerable progress in manufacturing, become idle and poor after a great lord takes up residence in their neighborhood.
elegant: After losing its parliament, Edinburgh gained some trade and industry but remains inferior to Glasgow, whose people are maintained by capital employment rather than revenue spending. Edinburgh retains courts and government boards that attract revenue spending. Even villages lose their industry when a great lord settles nearby.
summary: Edinburgh gained trade after losing its parliament but remains industrially inferior to Glasgow, which relies on capital employment rather than government revenue spending. Smith notes that even villages lose their manufacturing progress when a great lord's arrival introduces revenue-based idleness.
distilled: Edinburgh's shift from a parliamentary to a commercial city illustrates how the departure of revenue spending enables trade, though it still lags behind capital-driven Glasgow.
notes: The Edinburgh-Glasgow comparison is one of Smith's most telling examples: two major Scottish cities with different economic bases producing markedly different outcomes. -- The 'great lord' anecdote reinforces the social contagion thesis -- even a single source of revenue spending can corrupt an entire village's industry. -- Edinburgh's post-Union transformation anticipates modern debates about the economic impact of moving political capitals. -- Smith was personally familiar with both cities, having studied in Glasgow and lived in Edinburgh.

refashioned: The ratio between capital and revenue therefore seems everywhere to govern the ratio between industry and idleness. Wherever capital predominates, industry prevails; wherever revenue predominates, idleness prevails. Every increase or decrease in capital therefore naturally tends to increase or decrease the real quantity of industry, the number of productive workers, and consequently the exchangeable value of the annual produce of the country's land and labor -- the real wealth and revenue of all its inhabitants.
elegant: Capital-to-revenue ratios determine industry-to-idleness ratios everywhere. Where capital predominates, industry prevails; where revenue predominates, idleness prevails. Changes in capital therefore directly change the quantity of productive industry, the number of productive workers, and the real wealth of the country.
summary: The ratio of capital to revenue universally determines the ratio of industry to idleness. Increases in capital increase productive industry and national wealth; decreases have the opposite effect.
distilled: Capital begets industry; revenue begets idleness -- making capital accumulation the primary driver of a nation's productive capacity and real wealth.
notes: This is Smith's summary proposition for the chapter: capital accumulation is the engine of economic growth and the determinant of national character. -- The simplicity of the formulation (capital = industry, revenue = idleness) makes it one of Smith's most quotable conclusions. -- Modern economists would qualify this by noting that some revenue spending (education, health) enhances future productivity, but Smith's core insight about the importance of capital allocation remains valid. -- Cross-reference: 2.3.17 turns to the question of what increases and decreases capital.

refashioned:
Capitals are increased by frugality and diminished by extravagance and mismanagement.

Whatever a person saves from his revenue, he adds to his capital, and either employs it himself to maintain additional productive workers, or enables someone else to do so by lending it at interest -- that is, for a share of the profits. Just as an individual's capital can only grow through what he saves from his annual revenue or gains, so too can a society's capital -- which is simply the sum of its individuals' capital -- grow only in the same way.
elegant: Capital grows through frugality and shrinks through extravagance and mismanagement. Whatever is saved from revenue is added to capital and employed -- either directly or through lending -- to maintain productive workers. A society's capital, being the sum of all individual capitals, can grow only through the same individual saving.
