The 'Spanish West Indies' refers to Spain's American colonies as the source of the great silver influx. Sets up the detailed refutation in 2.4.12-2.4.13. Important for the history of monetary economics -- this debate shaped classical monetary theory.

refashioned:
Before the discovery of the Spanish West Indies, ten percent seems to have been the common rate of interest throughout most of Europe. It has since fallen in different countries to six, five, four, and even three percent. Let us suppose, as favorably as possible for the theory we are examining, that in every country the value of silver has fallen in exactly the same proportion as the interest rate -- that in countries where interest dropped from ten to five percent, the same quantity of silver now purchases exactly half the goods it could before.

Even on this most favorable assumption, the fall in silver's value could not possibly have caused the fall in interest rates. If 100 pounds is now worth no more than 50 pounds was then, 10 pounds must now be worth no more than 5 pounds was then. Whatever causes lowered the value of the capital must have lowered the value of the interest in exactly the same proportion. The ratio between capital and interest would have remained unchanged even if the interest rate had never been altered.

In fact, by reducing the rate from ten to five percent, we are paying for the use of a capital supposedly equal to half its former value an interest equal to only one quarter of the former interest. The rate of interest has clearly fallen by more than any depreciation in the value of money could explain.
elegant: Suppose silver's value fell in exactly the same proportion as interest rates -- from ten to five percent, with silver buying half as much. Even then, the fall in silver's value cannot explain falling interest. If 100 pounds is now worth what 50 was, then 10 pounds is worth what 5 was -- capital and interest depreciate equally, leaving their ratio unchanged. But at five percent instead of ten, we pay for capital worth half its former value an interest worth only one quarter of former interest. The ratio has changed independently of money's value.
summary: Even if silver depreciated in exactly the same proportion as interest rates fell, this cannot explain declining interest. If money loses value, both capital and interest lose value equally, leaving their ratio unchanged. The actual fall in interest rates exceeds anything money depreciation could account for.
distilled: Declining money value cannot explain falling interest rates because it reduces the value of both capital and interest equally, leaving their ratio unchanged.
notes: Elegant logical proof that monetary depreciation cannot explain falling interest rates. The proportionality argument is rigorous: if capital falls to half its real value and interest falls to one quarter, the ratio has changed for reasons independent of money. This distinguishes real from nominal interest rate changes. Builds on Hume's work cited in 2.4.11. Cf. 2.4.13 for the positive explanation of what does determine interest rates.

refashioned:
An increase in the quantity of silver, with the quantity of goods circulated remaining the same, could only diminish the value of silver itself. The nominal value of all goods would rise, but their real value would remain exactly the same. Goods would exchange for more pieces of silver, but the quantity of labor they could command -- the number of people they could maintain and employ -- would be unchanged. The country's capital would be the same, though more coins would be needed to transfer any given portion from one hand to another. The deeds of assignment, like the conveyances of a verbose lawyer, would be more cumbersome, but the thing assigned would be exactly the same and could produce only the same effects.

With productive funds unchanged, the demand for labor would be unchanged. Wages, though nominally higher, would really be the same -- paid in more silver but purchasing the same goods. Profits of capital would be the same both nominally and in reality. Wages are commonly calculated by the quantity of silver paid, so when silver increases, wages appear to rise even when they have not. But profits are calculated not by the number of silver pieces but by their proportion to the total capital employed. With the country's capital unchanged, competition among different capitals would be unchanged. The common ratio of capital to profit would remain the same, and consequently the common rate of interest -- since what can be paid for the use of money is necessarily regulated by what can be earned from its use.
elegant: More silver with the same goods only reduces silver's value. Nominal prices rise but real values -- the labor and goods they command -- stay the same. The capital is unchanged though more coins are needed to move it around. Labor demand, real wages, and real profits all remain the same. Wages appear higher because they are paid in more silver, but profits are measured as a proportion of capital, not in absolute silver. With the same real capital and the same competition, the ratio of profit to capital is unchanged, and interest -- which tracks profit -- must also be unchanged.
summary: Increasing the silver supply only raises nominal prices while leaving real values unchanged. Real wages, real profits, and the ratio of profit to capital all remain the same, so the interest rate -- determined by what capital can earn -- is unaffected by monetary inflation.
distilled: Monetary inflation raises nominal prices but leaves real capital, real profits, and therefore real interest rates unchanged -- interest depends on what capital earns, not on the money supply.
notes: Comprehensive statement of monetary neutrality -- perhaps the clearest in the Wealth of Nations. The 'verbose attorney' analogy is memorable: more money is just more paperwork for the same transaction. The key insight that profits are proportional (a rate) while wages are absolute (a sum) explains why nominal wage increases create an illusion that profit increases do not. Interest is determined by the real profit rate, not the money supply. This is a foundational passage for classical monetary theory.

refashioned:
If, on the other hand, the quantity of goods circulated annually increased while the money supply remained the same, many important effects would follow beyond simply raising the value of money. The country's real capital would be augmented, though its nominal value might stay the same. It would command a greater quantity of labor. Demand for labor would grow, and wages would naturally rise with it -- yet might appear to fall, since workers could be paid with less money that nonetheless purchased more goods.

Profits would decline both in reality and in appearance. With the country's real capital augmented, competition among capitals would intensify. Capital owners would have to accept a smaller share of the output produced by the labor their capital employed. Interest, always keeping pace with profits, might in this way be greatly reduced even as the value of money -- its purchasing power -- greatly increased.
elegant: If real output grew while the money supply stayed constant, the effects would be profound. Real capital would increase, commanding more labor. Wages would rise in purchasing power though paid in less money. But profits would decline both really and nominally as intensified competition among expanded capitals forced owners to accept smaller shares. Interest, tracking profits, would fall substantially -- even as money's purchasing power rose.
summary: When real output grows with a constant money supply, real capital expands, wages rise in purchasing power, but profit rates fall as competition among capitals intensifies. Interest rates decline because they track profit rates, not the money supply.
distilled: Real economic growth -- not monetary inflation -- drives interest rates down by expanding capital, intensifying competition, and reducing profit rates.
notes: The positive counterpart to 2.4.13's negative proof. Monetary changes do not affect interest; real growth does. This completes Smith's theory: interest falls because capital accumulation drives down profit rates through competition. The symmetry is elegant -- 2.4.13 shows money changes leave interest unchanged; 2.4.14 shows output changes move interest. Together they establish that interest is a real, not monetary, phenomenon. Links back to 2.4.10's competition mechanism.

refashioned: In some countries, charging interest on loans has been prohibited by law. But since money can always be put to some profitable use, something should always be paid for its use. This prohibition, experience has shown, does not prevent but actually increases the evil of usury. The borrower, forced to compensate the lender not only for the use of the money but also for the risk of penalties the lender faces by accepting that compensation, must effectively insure his creditor against the legal consequences of usury.
elegant: Prohibiting interest does not prevent lending but worsens usury. Since money can always earn a return, something must be paid for its use. Borrowers end up paying not only for the money's use but also a premium to compensate lenders for the legal risk -- effectively insuring their creditors against penalties.
summary: Banning interest on loans backfires by increasing the cost of borrowing, since borrowers must compensate lenders for both the use of the money and the legal risk of accepting that payment.
distilled: Interest prohibitions worsen usury by forcing borrowers to compensate lenders for the legal risk on top of the price of money's use.
notes: Classic unintended-consequences argument against prohibition. The logic is clean: banning a price that reflects real value does not eliminate the transaction but adds a risk premium. This reasoning applies broadly to price controls and prohibitions. Parallels modern arguments against banning or capping interest rates. Links to 2.4.16-2.4.17 on the proper regulation of interest.

refashioned:
In countries where interest is permitted, the law usually sets a maximum rate to prevent usury. This legal maximum should always be set somewhat above the lowest market rate -- the rate at which the most creditworthy borrowers can obtain funds.

If the legal rate is fixed below the lowest market rate, the effects are virtually the same as a total ban on interest: no creditor will lend for less than the money is worth, and borrowers must compensate for the legal risk. If it is fixed precisely at the lowest market rate, it destroys the credit of everyone except the most secure borrowers, forcing all others into the hands of extortionate usurers. In a country like Great Britain, where the government borrows at three percent and private borrowers with good security pay four to four and a half percent, the current legal rate of five percent is perhaps as appropriate as any.
elegant: Usury laws should set the maximum rate slightly above the lowest market rate. Set it too low and it effectively bans lending. Set it at exactly the market rate and only the best borrowers get credit, pushing everyone else to loan sharks. Britain's five percent legal maximum, above its three-to-four-and-a-half percent market range, seems about right.
summary: Interest rate caps should be set just above the lowest market rate. Too low, and lending effectively stops. At exactly the market rate, only prime borrowers get credit while others are forced to loan sharks. Britain's five percent cap above a three-to-four-and-a-half percent market range is well calibrated.
distilled: Usury laws work best when set slightly above the market rate -- too low destroys credit for all but the safest borrowers, pushing the rest to loan sharks.
notes: Practical policy prescription from Smith, who generally favors markets but accepts the need for usury regulation. The three-tier analysis (below market, at market, above market) is clear and systematic. The specific British rates provide empirical grounding. Jeremy Bentham later challenged Smith's support for usury laws in his 'Defence of Usury' (1787). Cf. 2.4.17 for the argument about why the cap should not be much above the market rate.

refashioned:
The legal interest rate, while it should be somewhat above, should not be much above the lowest market rate. If Britain's legal rate were set as high as eight or ten percent, most of the money available for lending would flow to spendthrifts and speculators, who alone would be willing to pay such high rates. Prudent businesspeople, who will only pay for money what they are likely to earn from its use, would not compete at those prices. A great part of the country's capital would thus be kept out of the hands most likely to use it profitably and thrown into the hands most likely to waste and destroy it.

When the legal rate is set only slightly above the market rate, however, prudent borrowers are universally preferred over spendthrifts and speculators. The lender gets nearly as much interest from the prudent as he dares to take from the reckless, and his money is far safer. A great part of the country's capital is thus directed into the hands most likely to employ it advantageously.
elegant: The legal rate should not be much above the market rate. At eight or ten percent, only spendthrifts and speculators would borrow, since prudent businesspeople refuse to pay more than they expect to earn. Capital would flow to those most likely to waste it. But at a rate just above the market, lenders prefer prudent borrowers -- they get nearly the same interest with far greater security, directing capital to its most productive users.
summary: A legal interest rate far above the market rate channels capital to reckless borrowers willing to pay high rates, while excluding prudent ones. A rate slightly above the market achieves the opposite, directing capital to its safest and most productive users.
distilled: Interest rate caps slightly above the market rate protect the allocation of capital to productive borrowers by preventing reckless speculators from outbidding prudent entrepreneurs.
notes: Remarkable argument for moderate usury regulation as a capital allocation mechanism. 'Prodigals and projectors' is a famous Smithian phrase. The logic is adverse selection: high caps attract the worst borrowers. This is one of the few places where Smith explicitly supports price regulation -- Bentham's critique focused on this passage. The reasoning anticipates modern concepts of adverse selection in credit markets (Stiglitz and Weiss). Links to 2.4.16 on the lower bound.

refashioned: No law can push the common rate of interest below the lowest ordinary market rate prevailing when the law is made. Despite the edict of 1766 by which the French king attempted to reduce the rate from five to four percent, money continued to be lent in France at five percent, with the law being evaded in various ways.
elegant: No law can force interest rates below the prevailing market rate. When the French king tried in 1766 to reduce rates from five to four percent, the law was simply evaded and lending continued at five percent.
summary: Laws cannot force interest rates below the market rate. The French king's 1766 attempt to mandate lower rates was simply circumvented, with lending continuing at the market rate.
distilled: Interest rate laws cannot force rates below the market -- the French edict of 1766 was simply evaded.
notes: Brief empirical illustration of the futility of price floors/ceilings when set against market forces. The French example (Louis XV's edict) provides concrete evidence. Complements 2.4.15 on the failure of prohibition and 2.4.16-2.4.17 on proper calibration. A concise statement of a principle central to classical economics: markets cannot be overridden by decree.

refashioned:
The ordinary market price of land everywhere depends on the ordinary market rate of interest. A person with capital who wishes to earn income without the trouble of employing it directly must choose between buying land and lending at interest. The superior security of land, together with various other advantages that nearly everywhere accompany this form of property, will generally lead him to accept a lower return from land than from lending. These advantages are enough to compensate for a certain difference in returns, but only up to a point. If land rents fall too far below the interest rate, no one will buy land, which will soon drive its price down. Conversely, if the advantages more than compensate for the difference, everyone will buy land, soon driving its price up.

When interest was at ten percent, land commonly sold at ten or twelve years' purchase. As interest fell to six, five, and four percent, land prices rose to twenty, twenty-five, and thirty years' purchase. The market rate of interest is higher in France than in England, and the price of land is correspondingly lower. In England it commonly sells at thirty years' purchase; in France at twenty.
elegant: Land prices depend inversely on interest rates. Investors choosing between land and lending accept lower returns from land because of its security and other advantages -- but only within limits. If land yields fall too far below interest, nobody buys; if the gap reverses, everybody buys. So land prices self-correct. When interest was ten percent, land sold at ten to twelve years' purchase; as rates fell to three to six percent, prices rose to twenty to thirty years' purchase. French interest rates are higher than English, and French land prices are correspondingly lower.
summary: Land prices move inversely with interest rates because investors compare land yields against lending returns, accepting a discount for land's superior security. As European interest rates fell from ten to three percent, land prices rose from ten to thirty years' purchase.
distilled: Land prices are inversely determined by interest rates, because investors accept lower land returns only up to the point where the security premium compensates for the gap.
notes: Establishes the inverse relationship between interest rates and asset prices -- a foundational principle of modern finance. 'Years' purchase' is the price-to-rent ratio, essentially a capitalization rate. The France-England comparison provides cross-sectional evidence alongside the time-series evidence. This relationship between interest rates and land values (and asset values generally) remains one of the most important in economics. Closes Chapter 4 by linking the interest rate to the broadest asset market.

refashioned:
Although all capitals are destined for maintaining productive labor, the quantity of labor that equal capitals can set in motion varies enormously depending on how they are employed. So does the value that their employment adds to the annual output of the country.

A capital may be employed in four different ways. First, in procuring the raw materials that the society annually needs for use and consumption. Second, in manufacturing and preparing those raw materials for immediate use. Third, in transporting either raw or manufactured goods from places of abundance to places of demand. Fourth, in dividing particular quantities of goods into the small portions that suit consumers' needs. The first employs the capitals of all who cultivate land, work mines, or operate fisheries. The second employs the capitals of all master manufacturers. The third employs the capitals of all wholesale merchants. The fourth employs the capitals of all retailers. It is difficult to conceive of any capital employment that does not fall under one of these four categories.
elegant: Equal capitals set very different quantities of productive labor in motion depending on their employment. Capital can be used in four ways: procuring raw materials (farmers, miners, fishers); manufacturing them for consumption (manufacturers); transporting goods from surplus to deficit areas (wholesale merchants); or dividing goods into retail quantities (retailers). Every capital employment falls under one of these four.
summary: Equal amounts of capital produce very different economic effects depending on deployment. Smith identifies four categories of capital employment: raw material extraction, manufacturing, wholesale transport, and retail distribution.
distilled: Capital can be employed in four ways -- extraction, manufacturing, wholesale trade, or retail -- each setting different quantities of productive labor in motion.
notes: Opens Chapter 5 (Different Employments of Capitals) with the four-fold classification that structures the entire chapter. This taxonomy covers the full supply chain from raw materials to final consumer. The key claim is that equal capitals are not equally productive -- deployment matters as much as quantity. Links to 2.5.8-2.5.13 where Smith ranks these four uses. Anticipates the agriculture-first argument in 2.5.11-2.5.13.

refashioned:
Each of these four methods of employing capital is essential either to the existence or expansion of the other three, or to the general convenience of society.

Without capital employed in producing raw materials to a certain degree of abundance, neither manufacturing nor trade of any kind could exist.
elegant: All four capital employments are mutually essential. Without capital producing raw materials in sufficient abundance, neither manufacturing nor trade could exist.
summary: The four types of capital employment are interdependent. Raw material production is the foundation without which manufacturing and trade cannot exist.
distilled: All four capital employments are mutually necessary, with raw material production as the essential foundation for manufacturing and trade.
notes: Begins the interdependence argument (2.5.2-2.5.5) showing each capital employment supports the others. Agriculture/extraction comes first in logical priority. This mutual dependence qualifies the ranking that follows in 2.5.8-2.5.13 -- all four are necessary even if not equally productive.

refashioned: Without capital employed in manufacturing the portion of raw materials that requires substantial preparation before it can be used or consumed, those materials would either never be produced -- because there would be no demand for them -- or, if they grew spontaneously, they would have no exchange value and could add nothing to the wealth of the society.
elegant: Without manufacturing capital, raw materials requiring significant processing would either go unproduced for lack of demand, or if naturally occurring, would have no exchange value and add nothing to national wealth.
summary: Manufacturing capital is essential because many raw materials require processing before they have value. Without it, these materials would either not be produced or would be worthless.
distilled: Manufacturing capital creates value from raw materials that would otherwise be worthless or unproduced.
notes: Second in the interdependence sequence. Manufacturing creates demand for raw materials by making them useful -- a derived demand argument. The 'produced spontaneously' point is subtle: nature provides many materials that only become valuable when human industry transforms them. Links to 2.5.10 on the productive superiority of manufacturing capital over merchant capital.

refashioned: Without capital employed in transporting either raw or manufactured goods from places where they are abundant to places where they are needed, no more of either could be produced than was necessary for local consumption. The merchant's capital exchanges the surplus produce of one place for that of another, thereby encouraging the industry of both places and increasing the enjoyments of both.
elegant: Without wholesale trade capital, production would be limited to local consumption needs. Merchants exchange the surplus of one place for that of another, encouraging industry and increasing enjoyments in both.
summary: Wholesale trade capital is essential because it enables production beyond local needs by exchanging surpluses between regions, encouraging industry and increasing consumption in both.
distilled: Wholesale trade capital enables production beyond local demand by exchanging regional surpluses, encouraging industry and expanding consumption.
notes: Third in the interdependence sequence. The merchant capital creates value by geographic arbitrage -- moving goods from low-value to high-value locations. Without trade, production is limited by local demand. The phrase 'encourages the industry, and increases the enjoyments of both' captures the mutual gains from trade. Links to 2.5.9 on the specific productive role of wholesale merchant capital.

refashioned:
Without capital employed in breaking and dividing goods into the small quantities that suit consumers' occasional needs, every person would be forced to buy far more than their immediate requirements demanded. Without butchers, for example, everyone would have to purchase a whole ox or sheep at a time. This would be inconvenient for the rich and far worse for the poor. If a poor worker had to buy a month's or six months' provisions at once, a large part of the capital he currently employs in the tools of his trade or the furnishings of his shop -- capital that yields him revenue -- would have to be redirected to the stock reserved for immediate consumption, which yields no revenue.

Nothing is more convenient for such a person than being able to purchase subsistence from day to day, or even hour to hour, as needed. This enables him to employ almost his entire stock as productive capital. He can thereby furnish work of greater value, and the profit he makes in this way more than compensates for the additional cost that the retailer's profit adds to the goods.
elegant: Without retail capital, everyone would have to buy in bulk far exceeding their needs. Without butchers, you would buy a whole ox. The poor would be forced to tie up productive capital in provisions instead of tools and inventory. Retail allows workers to buy subsistence daily, keeping almost all their stock employed as productive capital. The retailer's markup is more than offset by the greater value of work this enables.
summary: Retail capital is essential because it allows consumers, especially the poor, to buy in small quantities as needed rather than in costly bulk. This frees workers' capital for productive use, generating returns that more than compensate for the retailer's profit margin.
distilled: Retail trade frees workers' capital from unproductive stockpiling by enabling small purchases, and the productivity gain more than offsets the retailer's markup.
notes: Final entry in the interdependence sequence and perhaps the most insightful. The butcher example is vivid and practical. The key economic insight is that retail enables capital efficiency for the poor -- without it, workers would divert productive capital into consumption stockpiles. This is an early inventory management argument. The conclusion that the retailer's profit is more than compensated by the worker's productivity gain is a proto-efficiency argument. Links to 2.5.6 defending retailers against political prejudice.

refashioned:
The prejudices of some political writers against shopkeepers and tradesmen are entirely without foundation. Far from needing to be taxed or have their numbers restricted, shopkeepers can never multiply so as to harm the public, though they may multiply enough to harm one another. The quantity of grocery goods that can be sold in a particular town is limited by local demand. The capital that can be employed in the grocery trade therefore cannot exceed what is sufficient to purchase that quantity. If this capital is divided between two grocers, their competition will drive both to sell cheaper than if one had a monopoly. If divided among twenty, the competition would be that much greater and the chance of collusion to raise prices that much less.

Their competition might ruin some of them, but that is the concern of the parties involved and can safely be left to their discretion. Competition among retailers can never harm the consumer or the producer. On the contrary, it forces retailers to sell cheaper and buy dearer than under monopoly. Some retailers might occasionally entice a weak customer into buying something unnecessary, but this evil is too minor to deserve public attention and would not be prevented by restricting their numbers anyway.
elegant: Prejudice against shopkeepers is baseless. They need not be taxed or restricted -- they can never multiply enough to harm the public, only each other. More grocers mean more competition, lower prices, and less chance of collusion. Some may fail, but that is their concern. Retail competition always benefits consumers and producers by forcing lower selling prices and higher buying prices. The occasional decoying of a weak customer is too trivial to warrant regulation.
summary: Political prejudice against retailers is unfounded. Competition among shopkeepers benefits consumers through lower prices and cannot harm the public, only the retailers themselves. Restricting their numbers would reduce competition and serve no public purpose.
distilled: Retail competition benefits the public through lower prices and cannot be excessive -- restricting shopkeeper numbers would only reduce competition and harm consumers.
notes: Strong defense of free competition in retail markets. Anticipates modern antitrust thinking -- competition is self-regulating and benefits consumers. The 'weak customer' concession is honest but dismissed as trivial. The argument that competition harms only the competitors, never the public, is a core free-market principle. The anti-mercantilist stance is clear -- government should not regulate the number of traders. Links to 2.5.7 on alehouses as the strongest test case.

refashioned:
It is not the number of alehouses, to give the most suspicious example, that causes a general tendency toward drunkenness among ordinary people. Rather, that tendency, arising from other causes, naturally creates demand for many alehouses.

The people whose capitals are employed in any of these four ways are themselves productive workers. Their labor, when properly directed, is embodied in the goods they deal with and generally adds to those goods' price at least the value of their own maintenance and consumption. The profits of the farmer, the manufacturer, the merchant, and the retailer are all drawn from the price of the goods that the first two produce and the last two buy and sell. Equal capitals, however, employed in each of these four ways, will immediately set in motion very different quantities of productive labor and will augment in very different proportions the value of the society's annual output.
elegant: It is not the number of alehouses that causes drunkenness but drunkenness that creates demand for alehouses. All four types of capital users are themselves productive -- their labor adds value to goods at least equal to their own maintenance. But equal capitals in these four employments set very different quantities of labor in motion and add very different amounts to annual output.
summary: Demand causes supply, not the reverse -- drunkenness creates alehouses, not alehouses drunkenness. All four types of capital employment are productive, but equal amounts of capital in each produce very different quantities of labor and very different additions to national output.
distilled: Alehouses follow drunkenness, not the reverse -- and while all four capital employments are productive, equal capitals in each produce very different economic effects.
notes: The alehouse observation is a pithy illustration of the direction of causation -- supply follows demand, not vice versa. This transitions from the interdependence argument (all four are necessary) to the ranking argument (but they are not equally productive). The claim that all four operators are productive workers distinguishes them from the unproductive workers of Chapter 3. Sets up the detailed ranking in 2.5.8-2.5.13.

refashioned: The retailer's capital replaces, together with its profits, the capital of the merchant from whom he buys goods, thereby enabling the merchant to continue his business. The retailer himself is the only productive worker that this capital directly employs. His profit constitutes the entire value that his capital's employment adds to the society's annual output.
elegant: Retail capital replaces the wholesale merchant's capital with profit, enabling the merchant to continue. The retailer himself is the only productive worker it directly employs, and his profit is the total value it adds to annual output.
summary: Retail capital directly employs only the retailer himself and adds only his profit to annual output, though it also replaces the wholesale merchant's capital.
distilled: Retail capital directly employs only the retailer and adds only his profit to national output -- the least productive of the four capital employments.
notes: First in the ranking of four capital employments -- retail is least productive because it directly employs only one person (the retailer) and adds only one profit to output. Its primary function is replacing the merchant's capital. This is not a criticism -- 2.5.5-2.5.6 established retail's essential role -- but a comparative assessment. Cf. 2.5.9 for wholesale, which ranks higher.

refashioned: The wholesale merchant's capital replaces, together with their profits, the capitals of the farmers and manufacturers from whom he buys raw and manufactured goods, thereby enabling them to continue their trades. It is primarily through this service that he indirectly supports the productive labor of the society and increases the value of its annual output. His capital also employs the sailors and carriers who transport his goods, and it adds to the price of those goods not only his own profits but their wages as well. This is all the productive labor it directly sets in motion and all the value it directly adds to annual output. But in both respects, its operation considerably exceeds that of the retailer's capital.
elegant: Wholesale merchant capital replaces the capitals of farmers and manufacturers while employing sailors and carriers -- adding their wages plus merchant profits to annual output. Its direct productive effect substantially exceeds retail capital, and it indirectly supports all the productive labor of its suppliers.
summary: Wholesale merchant capital directly employs transporters as well as the merchant himself, adding both wages and profits to output. It also indirectly supports farmers and manufacturers by replacing their capitals, making it substantially more productive than retail capital.
distilled: Wholesale capital ranks above retail because it directly employs transport workers and indirectly sustains the productive labor of farmers and manufacturers.
notes: Second in the ranking -- wholesale exceeds retail by employing transport workers and indirectly supporting upstream producers. The 'service' of replacing suppliers' capital is the key mechanism through which trade supports production. This indirect support of productive labor is wholesale trade's primary economic contribution. Cf. 2.5.10 for manufacturing, which ranks still higher.

refashioned: Part of the master manufacturer's capital is employed as fixed capital in the tools of his trade, replacing with profits the capital of whatever craftsman made those tools. Part of his circulating capital purchases materials, replacing with profits the capitals of the farmers and miners who supplied them. But a large part is always -- either annually or in much shorter periods -- distributed among the workers he employs. It augments the value of those materials by their wages plus the master's profits on the whole stock of wages, materials, and tools used in the business. It therefore puts into motion a much greater quantity of productive labor and adds a much greater value to annual output than an equal capital in the hands of any wholesale merchant.
elegant: Manufacturing capital is deployed three ways: fixed capital for tools, circulating capital for materials, and -- the largest share -- wages paid to workers. It adds to output the workers' wages plus the master's profits on all inputs. It therefore sets far more productive labor in motion and adds far more value to annual output than an equal wholesale merchant's capital.
summary: Manufacturing capital directly employs many workers, pays for tools and materials, and adds both wages and profits to annual output. It sets far more productive labor in motion than equivalent merchant capital.
distilled: Manufacturing capital ranks above wholesale because it directly employs many workers and adds both their wages and the manufacturer's profits to national output.
notes: Third in the ranking -- manufacturing exceeds wholesale by directly employing many workers rather than just transport workers. The three-part deployment (fixed capital, materials, wages) gives a comprehensive picture of how manufacturing capital circulates. The key advantage is direct employment of productive labor. Only agriculture ranks higher -- cf. 2.5.11-2.5.13.

refashioned: No equal amount of capital puts more productive labor in motion than the farmer's. Not only his hired workers but his working animals are productive laborers. In agriculture, nature labors alongside human beings, and though her labor costs nothing, her output has value just as much as that of the most expensive worker. The most important operations of agriculture seem intended not so much to increase -- though they do that too -- as to direct nature's fertility toward producing the plants most profitable to people. A field overgrown with thorns and brambles may produce as great a quantity of vegetation as the best cultivated vineyard or grain field. Planting and tillage regulate nature's active fertility more than they create it, and after all their labor, much of the work always remains to be done by nature herself.
elegant: No equal capital employs more productive labor than agriculture. Not only workers but working animals are productive, and nature labors alongside them at no cost while still producing valuable output. Agriculture's main purpose is to direct nature's fertility toward useful plants rather than to create fertility. A wild field may produce as much vegetation as a cultivated one -- farming channels nature's energy more than it generates it.
summary: Agricultural capital employs more productive labor than any other because it harnesses not only human workers and draft animals but also nature's free labor. Farming directs natural fertility toward useful plants rather than creating productivity from scratch.
distilled: Agriculture employs the most productive labor of any capital use because it harnesses nature's free labor alongside human effort.
notes: Central to Smith's ranking -- agriculture tops all four capital employments because nature is a free co-producer. This is the physiocratic element in Smith's thought (Quesnay's influence). The observation that a wild field may produce as much vegetation as a cultivated one is striking -- farming redirects rather than creates. The inclusion of working cattle as 'productive labourers' extends the labor concept. Cf. 2.5.12-2.5.13 for the rent mechanism that captures nature's contribution.

refashioned: The workers and working animals employed in agriculture therefore produce not only a value equal to their own consumption -- or to the capital that employs them plus its owner's profits, as manufacturing workers do -- but a much greater value besides. Over and above the farmer's capital and all its profits, they regularly produce the landlord's rent. This rent may be considered the product of nature's powers, the use of which the landlord leases to the farmer. It is larger or smaller depending on the presumed extent of those powers -- in other words, depending on the land's natural or improved fertility.
elegant: Agricultural workers and animals reproduce not only their own consumption and the farmer's profits -- as in manufacturing -- but also generate the landlord's rent. This rent represents nature's contribution: the product of the land's natural powers that the landlord leases to the farmer, varying with the land's fertility.
summary: Agriculture uniquely produces a surplus beyond wages and profits -- the landlord's rent, which represents nature's free contribution to production. This makes agricultural capital more productive than any manufacturing capital.
distilled: Agricultural capital uniquely generates rent -- nature's surplus contribution -- on top of the wages and profits that all capital produces.
notes: The rent-as-nature's-gift argument is distinctly physiocratic. Rent is the return to natural fertility -- what remains after compensating labor and capital. This three-way distribution (wages, profits, rent) is the complete Smithian income distribution from Book I, Chapter 6. The idea that rent measures nature's contribution anticipates Ricardian rent theory, though Ricardo later reframed it as differential rather than absolute. Cf. 2.5.13 for the conclusion that agriculture is therefore the most advantageous capital employment.

refashioned:
It is nature's work that remains after deducting everything that can be attributed to human effort. This remainder is seldom less than a fourth and frequently more than a third of the total output. No equal amount of capital employed in manufacturing can ever produce so great a return. In manufacturing, nature does nothing; people do everything, and the output must always be proportional to the strength of the human agents involved.

Agricultural capital therefore not only puts more productive labor in motion than any equal amount of manufacturing capital, but in proportion to the labor it employs, it also adds a much greater value to the country's annual output -- to the real wealth and revenue of its inhabitants. Of all the ways a capital can be employed, agriculture is by far the most advantageous to society.
elegant: Nature's contribution to agriculture -- at least a quarter and often a third of total output -- has no equivalent in manufacturing, where people do everything and nature nothing. Agricultural capital therefore both employs more productive labor and adds more value per worker to annual output than any other capital employment. It is by far the most advantageous to society.
summary: Nature contributes at least a quarter of agricultural output for free, something manufacturing cannot match. Agricultural capital is therefore the most productive both in total labor employed and in value added per worker, making it the most beneficial capital employment for society.
distilled: Agriculture is the most advantageous capital employment because nature's free contribution -- a quarter to a third of output -- has no equivalent in manufacturing.
notes: Capstone of the ranking argument. Agriculture > manufacturing > wholesale > retail in productive impact. The one-quarter to one-third estimate of nature's contribution (captured as rent) is an early attempt at factor analysis. The claim that 'in manufactures, nature does nothing' would be challenged by later economists who recognized natural resources in manufacturing. This agriculture-first ranking influences Smith's critique of European policy in Books III-IV, where he argues that policy has distorted the natural order by favoring urban over rural capital.

refashioned:
The capitals employed in agriculture and retail trade must always reside within the country. Their employment is confined almost to a precise spot -- the farm and the shop. They must generally, with some exceptions, belong to resident members of the society.

The capital of a wholesale merchant, by contrast, seems to have no fixed or necessary residence. It may move from place to place, according to where it can buy cheaply or sell dearly.
elegant: Agricultural and retail capital must reside locally -- tied to farms and shops, generally owned by residents. Wholesale merchant capital, by contrast, has no fixed residence and moves freely to wherever it can buy cheap or sell dear.
summary: Agricultural and retail capital are geographically fixed and locally owned, while wholesale merchant capital is mobile and follows profit opportunities across locations.
distilled: Agricultural and retail capital are tied to local places; wholesale merchant capital is geographically mobile, following price differentials.
notes: Introduces the geographic mobility dimension of capital, which has important policy implications. Fixed capital (farm, shop) creates local commitment; mobile capital (trade) creates no such ties. This distinction matters for Smith's later arguments about the natural preference for domestic investment (cf. Book IV's invisible hand passage). The merchant's mobility anticipates modern concerns about capital flight and globalization.

refashioned: The manufacturer's capital must, of course, reside where the manufacturing is carried on, but the location of manufacturing is not always fixed. It may be at a great distance both from the source of its raw materials and from the market for its finished goods. Lyons, for example, is far from both the sources of its materials and the consumers of its products. The fashionable people of Sicily wear silks made in other countries from materials their own island produces. Part of Spain's wool is manufactured in Great Britain, and some of that cloth is then sent back to Spain.
elegant: Manufacturing capital must reside where production occurs, but that location need not be near either raw materials or final markets. Lyons manufactures far from both its material sources and consumers. Sicily's materials are manufactured abroad and sold back. Spanish wool is processed in Britain and partly returned to Spain.
summary: Manufacturing capital is tied to its production location but that location can be distant from both raw material sources and end markets, as illustrated by Lyons, Sicilian silk, and Spanish wool processed in Britain.
distilled: Manufacturing capital is locationally fixed at the factory but the factory itself can be far from both material sources and end markets.
notes: Qualifies 2.5.14 -- manufacturing capital is less mobile than merchant capital but more mobile than agricultural or retail capital. The examples illustrate early globalization of supply chains: raw materials from one country, manufacturing in another, consumption in a third. The Lyons, Sicily, and Spain examples show how comparative advantage drives geographic specialization. Foreshadows Book IV's discussion of natural versus artificial advantages in trade.

refashioned: Whether the merchant whose capital exports a society's surplus produce is a native or a foreigner matters very little. If he is a foreigner, the number of the country's productive workers is reduced by exactly one person, and the value of annual output is reduced only by that one person's profits. The sailors or carriers he employs may belong to his own country, to theirs, or to some third country, just as if he were a native. A foreigner's capital gives value to a country's surplus produce just as effectively as a native's, by exchanging it for something in demand at home. It replaces the capital of the domestic producer just as effectively and enables him to continue his business just as well -- the primary service through which a wholesale merchant's capital supports productive labor and augments the value of a society's annual output.
elegant: Whether the exporting merchant is a native or foreigner matters little. A foreign merchant reduces the country's productive workers by exactly one and its annual output by just one person's profits. His capital still gives value to surplus produce by exchanging it for goods in demand at home, and still replaces domestic producers' capital just as effectively as a native merchant's would.
summary: The nationality of an exporting merchant matters little economically. A foreign merchant's capital serves the domestic economy almost as well as a native's, differing only by one person's employment and profits.
distilled: A foreign merchant's capital serves a country's export needs almost as effectively as a native's, reducing domestic benefit by only one person's employment and profits.
notes: Remarkably cosmopolitan argument for the era -- nationality of capital matters little for economic welfare. This directly challenges mercantilist preferences for native over foreign traders. The 'one man only' difference is deliberately minimized. The argument that foreign capital replaces domestic producers' capital just as effectively is key to Smith's case for open trade. Links to 2.5.17 on the greater importance of manufacturing capital residing domestically.

refashioned: It matters more that the manufacturer's capital should reside within the country, because it necessarily puts a greater quantity of productive labor in motion and adds greater value to annual output. It may, however, still be very useful to a country even when it does not reside there. The capitals of British manufacturers who work up flax and hemp imported annually from the Baltic coast are certainly very useful to the countries that produce those materials. Those materials are part of the surplus produce of the Baltic countries, which, if not annually exchanged for something in demand there, would have no value and would soon cease to be produced. The merchants who export them replace the capitals of the Baltic producers and thereby encourage continued production, and the British manufacturers in turn replace the capitals of those merchants.
elegant: Manufacturing capital matters more domestically because it employs more labor, but foreign manufacturing capital still benefits producing countries. British manufacturers working up Baltic flax and hemp give value to what would otherwise be worthless surplus, encouraging Baltic producers to continue by replacing their capitals through the merchant chain.
summary: Domestic manufacturing capital is more important than foreign merchant capital because it employs more labor, but even foreign manufacturing capital benefits the producing country by creating demand for its surplus output that would otherwise be worthless.
distilled: While domestic manufacturing capital is most productive, foreign manufacturing capital still benefits producing countries by giving value to surplus materials that would otherwise go unproduced.
notes: Balances the general cosmopolitanism of 2.5.16 with the practical observation that manufacturing capital matters more domestically. The Baltic flax example shows how international trade creates value through interdependence -- British manufacturers, exporting merchants, and Baltic producers all benefit. The capital replacement chain (producer > merchant > manufacturer) illustrates how capital circulates through the international division of labor.

refashioned: A particular country, like a particular person, may frequently lack sufficient capital to simultaneously improve and cultivate all its lands, manufacture and prepare all its raw output for consumption, and transport its surplus to distant markets. The inhabitants of many parts of Great Britain do not have enough capital to improve and cultivate all their lands. The wool of the southern Scottish counties is, for the most part, transported over long distances on bad roads to be manufactured in Yorkshire, for want of local manufacturing capital. There are many small manufacturing towns in Britain whose inhabitants lack the capital to transport their products to distant markets where demand exists. If there are any merchants among them, they are really just agents of wealthier merchants who reside in the great commercial cities.
elegant: A country, like a person, may lack capital for all three purposes simultaneously -- cultivation, manufacturing, and trade. Many parts of Britain cannot improve all their lands. Scottish wool travels to Yorkshire for processing because Scotland lacks manufacturing capital. Small manufacturing towns lack trading capital and depend on agents of distant merchants.
summary: Most countries lack sufficient capital to fully develop agriculture, manufacturing, and trade simultaneously. Even in Britain, many regions cannot cultivate all their land, must send raw materials elsewhere for processing, or depend on distant merchants to market their products.
distilled: Countries typically lack capital for all three productive stages simultaneously, forcing regions to specialize in whichever stage their scarce capital can best serve.
notes: Applies the individual-budget-constraint analogy to nations -- capital scarcity forces prioritization. The Scottish wool example shows how capital scarcity drives geographic specialization and interregional trade. The 'agents of wealthier merchants' observation captures the hierarchy of commercial centers in 18th-century Britain. Links to 2.5.19's argument about the optimal sequence of capital deployment.

refashioned: When a country's capital is not sufficient for all three purposes, the greater the share employed in agriculture, the greater the quantity of productive labor it will set in motion domestically, and the greater the value it will add to annual output. After agriculture, manufacturing capital puts the most productive labor in motion and adds the most value to annual output. Capital employed in export trade has the least effect of the three.
elegant: When capital is scarce, agriculture employs the most domestic productive labor, manufacturing the second most, and export trade the least. The priority order for deploying limited capital is therefore agriculture first, manufacturing second, and trade third.
summary: With limited capital, the optimal deployment order is agriculture first (most domestic labor and value added), manufacturing second, and export trade third.
distilled: Scarce capital should flow first to agriculture, then manufacturing, then export trade -- in order of diminishing domestic productive impact.
notes: Direct policy implication of the ranking from 2.5.8-2.5.13 combined with the capital scarcity of 2.5.18. This agriculture-first sequence is the 'natural progress of opulence' that Smith develops in Book III. It also grounds his critique of European mercantilism -- policies that favored trade and manufacturing over agriculture inverted the natural order. Cf. 2.5.20-2.5.21 for the application to development strategy.

refashioned: A country that lacks sufficient capital for all three purposes has not yet reached the level of prosperity for which it seems naturally destined. To attempt prematurely, with insufficient capital, to pursue all three simultaneously is certainly not the fastest way for a society -- any more than for an individual -- to acquire the capital it needs. A nation's total capital has limits, just as an individual's does, and can accomplish only certain purposes. A nation's capital increases in the same way as an individual's: by continually accumulating and adding to it whatever is saved from revenue. It is likely to increase fastest when employed in the way that affords the greatest revenue to all the country's inhabitants, since they will then be able to make the greatest savings. But the revenue of all inhabitants is necessarily proportional to the value of the annual output of their land and labor.
elegant: A country lacking capital for all three purposes has not reached its natural level of prosperity. Trying to do everything at once with insufficient capital is not the fastest path to growth -- for a nation any more than an individual. National capital grows through saving, and saving is greatest when capital is employed where it generates the most revenue, which is proportional to the value of annual output.
summary: Attempting all three capital-intensive activities simultaneously with insufficient resources slows growth. National capital grows fastest when deployed where it generates the most revenue, enabling the greatest savings and fastest accumulation.
distilled: Nations grow fastest by concentrating scarce capital where it generates the most revenue, not by prematurely spreading it across agriculture, manufacturing, and trade simultaneously.
notes: Development economics in embryonic form -- the sequencing argument against premature diversification. Capital-constrained economies should prioritize high-return employment. The national-individual analogy reinforces the intuition. The savings-growth feedback loop (higher revenue > more savings > more capital > higher revenue) is a virtuous circle. Links to 2.5.21 on the American colonies as a successful case study.

refashioned:
It has been the principal cause of the rapid progress of our American colonies toward wealth and greatness that almost all their capital has so far been employed in agriculture. They have no manufactures except the household and coarser kinds that necessarily accompany agricultural progress and are the work of women and children in every family. The greater part of both their export and coastal trade is carried on by the capitals of merchants who reside in Great Britain. Even the stores and warehouses from which goods are retailed in some provinces, particularly Virginia and Maryland, belong in many cases to merchants in the mother country -- one of the few instances of a society's retail trade being conducted by the capitals of non-residents.

Were the Americans, whether by combination or any other form of coercion, to block the import of European manufactures and thereby grant a monopoly to domestic manufacturers -- diverting a considerable portion of their capital into this employment -- they would retard rather than accelerate the growth of their annual output, and would obstruct rather than promote their country's progress toward real wealth and greatness. This would be even more true if they attempted to monopolize their entire export trade as well.
elegant: The American colonies grew rapidly precisely because nearly all their capital went to agriculture, with manufacturing and trade handled by British capital. If the Americans were to block European imports and force capital into domestic manufacturing, they would slow their own growth -- diverting capital from its most productive use. Monopolizing their export trade would be even more damaging.
summary: The American colonies prospered by concentrating capital in agriculture while relying on British capital for manufacturing and trade. Diverting capital into domestic manufacturing through import restrictions would slow growth, not accelerate it.
distilled: The American colonies grew rapidly by concentrating capital in agriculture -- protectionist manufacturing policies would have diverted capital from its highest use and slowed growth.
notes: Remarkable passage written on the eve of American independence (1776). Smith argues against American protectionism using his capital-sequencing theory. The fact that British capital ran American retail and trade illustrates colonial economic dependency. The warning against forced industrialization anticipates debates about import substitution that dominated 20th-century development economics. The irony is that Hamilton's infant industry argument would soon challenge Smith's position. Cf. Book IV on mercantilism and colonial policy.

refashioned: The course of human prosperity has perhaps never lasted long enough to enable any great country to acquire capital sufficient for all three purposes -- unless we credit the remarkable accounts of the wealth and cultivation of China, ancient Egypt, and ancient India. Even those three countries, the wealthiest according to all accounts that the world has ever seen, are chiefly renowned for their superiority in agriculture and manufacturing. They do not appear to have been notable for foreign trade. The ancient Egyptians had a superstitious aversion to the sea; a similar superstition prevails among the Indians; and the Chinese have never excelled in foreign commerce. The greater part of the surplus produce of all three countries seems always to have been exported by foreigners who gave in exchange whatever was in demand there, frequently gold and silver.
elegant: Perhaps no great nation has ever accumulated enough capital for all three purposes. Even the wealthiest civilizations -- China, ancient Egypt, ancient India -- were renowned for agriculture and manufacturing, not foreign trade. Egyptians feared the sea, Indians shared this aversion, and the Chinese never excelled at foreign commerce. Their surplus was mostly exported by foreigners, often in exchange for gold and silver.
summary: Even history's wealthiest civilizations -- China, Egypt, and India -- concentrated on agriculture and manufacturing rather than developing their own foreign trade. Their surpluses were exported by foreign merchants, suggesting that no nation has ever fully developed all three capital employments.
distilled: Even the wealthiest civilizations in history -- China, Egypt, India -- excelled in agriculture and manufacturing but relied on foreigners for their export trade.
notes: Remarkable comparative history across civilizations. The agriculture-manufacturing-trade sequence as a development pattern is treated as universal. The observation that the three wealthiest ancient civilizations did not develop foreign trade supports Smith's ranking -- trade comes last in the natural order. The cultural explanations (Egyptian superstition, Chinese introversion) are crude by modern standards but reflect available knowledge. Foreshadows Book III's historical narrative of European development.

refashioned: It is in this way that the same capital, in any country, will put into motion a greater or smaller quantity of productive labor and add a greater or smaller value to annual output, depending on the proportions in which it is employed in agriculture, manufacturing, and wholesale trade. The difference is also very great depending on the particular kind of wholesale trade in which any part of it is employed.
elegant: The same capital produces very different economic effects depending on its distribution among agriculture, manufacturing, and wholesale trade -- and within wholesale trade, the particular type matters greatly as well.
summary: A country's productive output depends not just on its total capital but on how that capital is distributed among agriculture, manufacturing, and different types of wholesale trade.
distilled: The productive impact of capital depends on its allocation across agriculture, manufacturing, and different types of trade -- not merely on its total quantity.
notes: Transitional passage from the general ranking (2.5.8-2.5.13) to the detailed analysis of different types of wholesale trade (2.5.24-2.5.39). Signals that the wholesale trade category needs further subdivision. The key insight is that capital allocation matters as much as capital quantity -- a principle central to development economics.

refashioned: All wholesale trade -- all buying to sell again in bulk -- can be reduced to three types: the home trade, the foreign trade of consumption, and the carrying trade. The home trade buys goods in one part of the same country and sells them in another, encompassing both inland and coastal commerce. The foreign trade of consumption buys foreign goods for domestic use. The carrying trade transacts the commerce of foreign countries, carrying the surplus produce of one country to another.
elegant: Wholesale trade has three types: home trade (buying and selling within the same country, including coastal trade), the foreign trade of consumption (importing foreign goods for domestic use), and the carrying trade (shipping goods between foreign countries).
summary: Smith divides wholesale trade into three categories: domestic home trade, the foreign trade of consumption (importing for domestic use), and the carrying trade (transporting goods between other countries).
distilled: Wholesale trade divides into home trade, foreign trade of consumption, and carrying trade -- each with different effects on domestic productive labor.
notes: Important taxonomy that structures the rest of Chapter 5. The three-way division reflects how capital circulates: home trade keeps both ends domestic, foreign consumption trade has one domestic and one foreign end, and carrying trade has both ends foreign. Each has different implications for domestic capital replacement and productive labor. Cf. 2.5.25-2.5.32 for the detailed analysis of each type.

refashioned: Capital employed in buying goods in one part of the country to sell in another generally replaces, with each such transaction, two distinct capitals that had both been employed in the country's agriculture or manufacturing, thereby enabling them to continue that employment. When the merchant sends a certain value of goods from his base, he generally brings back at least an equal value of other goods. When both are products of domestic industry, each transaction necessarily replaces two distinct domestic capitals that had both been supporting productive labor. The capital that sends Scottish manufactures to London and brings back English grain and manufactures to Edinburgh necessarily replaces, with every such transaction, two British capitals that had both been employed in British agriculture or manufacturing.
elegant: Home trade capital replaces two domestic capitals with every transaction -- buying domestic goods in one place and selling them in another. The capital sending Scottish manufactures to London and returning English goods to Edinburgh replaces two British capitals that had both supported British productive labor.
summary: Home trade replaces two domestic capitals with every transaction, because both the goods sent and those received are products of domestic industry. Each round trip sustains two streams of productive labor within the country.
distilled: Home trade replaces two domestic capitals per transaction because both legs of the trade involve domestic production, doubling its support for domestic productive labor.
notes: Establishes the benchmark: home trade replaces two domestic capitals per round trip. This is the standard against which foreign trade and carrying trade will be measured. The Scotland-England example makes the abstract point concrete. The 'two distinct capitals' concept is central to the comparative analysis in 2.5.26-2.5.32.

refashioned: Capital employed in purchasing foreign goods for domestic consumption, when those foreign goods are purchased with domestic products, also replaces two distinct capitals with every transaction -- but only one of them is employed in supporting domestic industry. The capital that sends British goods to Portugal and brings back Portuguese goods to Britain replaces only one British capital; the other is Portuguese. Although the returns of foreign trade may be as quick as those of home trade, the capital employed in it provides only half the encouragement to the country's industry and productive labor.
elegant: Foreign trade of consumption replaces two capitals per transaction, but only one is domestic. Sending British goods to Portugal and returning Portuguese goods replaces one British and one Portuguese capital. Even with equal speed of return, foreign trade gives only half the domestic encouragement of home trade.
summary: The foreign trade of consumption replaces one domestic and one foreign capital per transaction, providing only half the support for domestic productive labor that home trade provides.
distilled: Foreign trade of consumption replaces only one domestic capital per transaction versus home trade's two, giving half the support to domestic industry.
notes: Key comparison: home trade replaces two domestic capitals, foreign consumption trade replaces only one. This is Smith's argument for the natural superiority of home trade -- not an argument for restricting foreign trade, but an explanation of why capital naturally gravitates homeward. Cf. 2.5.27 for the further disadvantage of slower returns. The Portugal-Britain example is apt given the Methuen Treaty's role in Anglo-Portuguese trade.

refashioned: But the returns of foreign trade are very seldom as quick as those of home trade. Home trade returns generally come in before the end of the year, and sometimes three or four times per year. Foreign trade returns seldom arrive before the end of the year, and sometimes not for two or three years. A capital employed in home trade can therefore sometimes make twelve round trips -- being sent out and returned twelve times -- before a capital employed in foreign trade completes one. If the capitals are equal, the home-trade capital will provide twenty-four times more encouragement and support to domestic industry than the foreign-trade capital.
elegant: Home trade returns come in multiple times per year -- perhaps twelve times -- while foreign trade may take one to three years for a single return. An equal capital in home trade can therefore provide twenty-four times more support to domestic industry: twelve turnovers replacing two domestic capitals each, versus one turnover replacing one.
summary: Home trade capital turns over far faster than foreign trade capital -- potentially twelve times per year versus once. Combined with replacing two domestic capitals per turn versus one, equal home trade capital can provide twenty-four times more support to domestic industry.
distilled: Home trade capital supports domestic industry up to twenty-four times more than equal foreign trade capital, due to faster turnover and double domestic capital replacement.
notes: The speed-of-return argument magnifies the advantage from 2.5.26. The 24x multiplier (12 turnovers x 2 domestic capitals vs. 1 turnover x 1 domestic capital) is striking but somewhat theoretical -- Smith is showing the maximum possible advantage. This is not an argument for trade restrictions but explains capital's natural preference for domestic employment. Anticipates the invisible hand passage in Book IV, Chapter 2.

refashioned: The foreign goods purchased for domestic consumption may sometimes be bought not with domestic products but with other foreign goods. These other foreign goods, however, must originally have been purchased with domestic products, or with something purchased with domestic products -- because, except through war and conquest, foreign goods can only be acquired in exchange for something produced at home, whether directly or after several intermediate exchanges. The effects of capital employed in such a roundabout foreign trade of consumption are therefore the same as those of the most direct version, except that the final returns are likely to be even more delayed, since they depend on the completion of two or three separate foreign trades.
elegant: Foreign goods may be purchased with other foreign goods rather than domestic products, but those intermediate goods must ultimately trace back to domestic production. The roundabout foreign trade of consumption has the same effects as the direct version, except its returns are even slower because they depend on completing multiple separate foreign trades.
summary: Roundabout foreign trade -- where domestic goods are exchanged for foreign goods which are then exchanged for other foreign goods -- has the same basic effects as direct foreign trade but with even longer delays in returns.
distilled: Roundabout foreign trade produces the same effects as direct foreign trade but with slower returns, since each intermediate exchange adds delay.
notes: Extends the foreign trade analysis to multi-stage transactions. The key insight is that all foreign goods ultimately trace back to domestic production (except through conquest) -- a proto-balance-of-payments identity. The 'roundabout' concept captures the complexity of real-world trade chains. Cf. 2.5.29 for a specific example and 2.5.30 for why breaking the chain among multiple merchants does not change the national effect.

refashioned:
If the hemp and flax of Riga are purchased with the tobacco of Virginia, which had been purchased with British manufactures, the merchant must wait for the returns of two distinct foreign trades before he can employ the same capital in purchasing more British manufactures. If the Virginia tobacco had been purchased not with British manufactures but with the sugar and rum of Jamaica, which had themselves been purchased with British manufactures, he must wait for the returns of three distinct foreign trades.

If these two or three trades happen to be carried on by two or three separate merchants -- the second buying what the first imported, the third buying what the second imported, in order to export again -- each individual merchant will receive his own returns more quickly. But the final returns of the whole capital employed in the trade will be just as slow as ever.
elegant: If Baltic hemp is bought with Virginia tobacco, bought with British goods, the merchant waits on two foreign trades. If Jamaican sugar is added to the chain, he waits on three. Splitting the chain among multiple merchants speeds each individual's returns but does not speed the overall capital turnover -- the total return time remains the same.
summary: Multi-step trade chains -- British goods for Virginia tobacco for Baltic hemp -- multiply the delay before capital returns. Splitting the chain among multiple merchants speeds individual returns but not the total capital cycle.
distilled: Trade chains through multiple countries multiply return times, and splitting the chain among different merchants speeds individual but not total capital turnover.
notes: Concrete illustration of the roundabout trade from 2.5.28 using the Atlantic trade triangle (Britain-Virginia-Baltic). The three-stage version adds Jamaica, showing how complex colonial trade really was. The crucial insight that splitting among merchants changes private but not national outcomes illustrates the difference between microeconomic and macroeconomic perspectives. Links to 2.5.30 for the formal statement of this principle.

refashioned: Whether the whole capital employed in such a roundabout trade belongs to one merchant or to three makes no difference to the country, though it may matter to the individual merchants. In either case, three times as much capital must be employed to exchange a certain value of British manufactures for a certain quantity of flax and hemp as would be needed if the manufactures and the flax and hemp were exchanged directly. The entire capital employed in such roundabout foreign trade will therefore generally provide less encouragement and support to domestic productive labor than an equal capital employed in more direct trade of the same kind.
elegant: Whether the roundabout trade is run by one merchant or three makes no national difference -- three times more capital is tied up than in direct trade. Roundabout foreign trade therefore provides less support to domestic productive labor than an equal capital in more direct trade.
summary: Roundabout foreign trade ties up three times more capital than direct trade for the same final exchange, regardless of how many merchants are involved. It therefore gives less support to domestic productive labor per unit of capital.
distilled: Roundabout foreign trade requires more capital and provides less domestic productive support per unit than direct trade, regardless of how many merchants participate.
notes: Formal conclusion from the examples in 2.5.28-2.5.29. The national-vs-individual distinction is important: private efficiency (multiple merchants, faster individual returns) does not change the aggregate capital requirement. Three times the capital for the same real exchange is a significant inefficiency. This supports the natural preference for direct trade but is not an argument for government intervention -- Smith is explaining natural market forces, not prescribing policy.

refashioned:
Whatever foreign commodity is used to purchase the foreign goods destined for domestic consumption, it makes no essential difference to the nature of the trade or its support for domestic productive labor. If those goods are purchased with the gold of Brazil or the silver of Peru, this gold and silver, like the tobacco of Virginia, must have been purchased with domestic produce or with something acquired through domestic produce. As far as domestic productive labor is concerned, foreign trade conducted through gold and silver has all the advantages and disadvantages of any other equally roundabout foreign trade, and will replace the capital supporting that labor just as fast or just as slow.

It does, however, seem to have one advantage over other equally roundabout trades. Because of the small bulk and great value of precious metals, their transportation costs are lower than for almost any other foreign goods of equal value. Their freight is much less, their insurance no greater, and no goods are less liable to damage in transit. An equal quantity of foreign goods may therefore frequently be purchased with less domestic produce through the intermediation of gold and silver than through any other foreign commodity. Domestic demand may thus be supplied more completely and cheaply. Whether the continual export of these metals tends to impoverish the exporting country in any other way is a question I shall examine at length later.
elegant: Using gold and silver as the intermediate commodity in roundabout trade makes no essential difference to its effects on domestic labor -- the metals must still be purchased with domestic produce. However, precious metals have one practical advantage: their high value-to-bulk ratio makes them cheaper to transport than almost any other goods, allowing domestic demand to be supplied more cheaply. Whether continual export of gold and silver impoverishes a country is a question for later.
summary: Foreign trade conducted through gold and silver follows the same economic logic as any roundabout trade, but precious metals' high value-to-bulk ratio makes them cheaper to transport, offering a practical efficiency advantage. Whether exporting them causes impoverishment is addressed later.
distilled: Gold and silver in roundabout trade follow the same rules as any commodity but have a transport cost advantage due to their high value relative to bulk.
notes: Important bridge passage that partly defuses mercantilist anxiety about gold outflows while reserving the full argument for Book IV. The transport cost advantage of precious metals is a genuine economic insight. The 'I shall have occasion to examine at great length hereafter' signals that the bullion debate is too important to settle in passing -- it gets full treatment in Book IV, Chapters 1-8. The distinction between real effects (same as any roundabout trade) and transport efficiency (genuine advantage) is analytically clean.

refashioned: That part of any country's capital employed in the carrying trade is entirely withdrawn from supporting the productive labor of that particular country, to support instead the productive labor of some foreign countries. Though it may replace two distinct capitals with every transaction, neither of those capitals belongs to the carrying country.
