The capital of the Dutch merchant who carries Polish corn to Portugal and brings back Portuguese wines and fruits to Poland replaces two capitals with every such transaction -- but neither had been supporting Dutch productive labor. One had been supporting Polish productive labor, the other Portuguese.
elegant: Carrying trade capital is entirely withdrawn from domestic productive labor, supporting only foreign production. Though it replaces two capitals per transaction, neither belongs to the carrying country. A Dutch merchant shipping Polish corn to Portugal and returning with Portuguese wine replaces Polish and Portuguese capital, not Dutch.
summary: The carrying trade withdraws capital entirely from domestic productive labor, replacing only foreign capitals. A Dutch merchant carrying Polish goods to Portugal and back supports Polish and Portuguese production but not Dutch.
distilled: Carrying trade capital supports only foreign productive labor, replacing two foreign capitals per transaction while contributing nothing to domestic production.
notes: The carrying trade is the least domestically productive form of wholesale trade -- it replaces zero domestic capitals (vs. one for foreign consumption trade and two for home trade). The Dutch example is apt -- the Netherlands was Europe's premier carrying-trade nation. This ranking (home > foreign consumption > carrying) completes the wholesale trade hierarchy. Cf. 2.5.33-2.5.34 for qualifications about profits and shipping.

refashioned:
Only the profits return regularly to the carrying country, constituting the entire addition that the carrying trade makes to that country's annual output. When, however, the carrying trade is conducted with the ships and sailors of the carrying country, the portion of capital that pays freight is distributed among and puts into motion a certain number of that country's productive workers. Almost all nations that have had a significant share of the carrying trade have in fact carried it on this way. The trade itself probably derives its name from this fact, the people of such countries being the carriers for other nations.

This is not, however, essential to the nature of the carrying trade. A Dutch merchant may, for example, employ his capital in carrying goods between Poland and Portugal not in Dutch ships but in British ones. It may be presumed that he actually does so on some occasions.
elegant: Only the carrying merchant's profits return to his home country. But when the trade uses domestic ships and sailors, the freight payments also support domestic productive workers -- which is how most carrying-trade nations have operated, earning them the name 'carriers.' This is not essential, however; a Dutch merchant could use British ships, and sometimes probably does.
summary: The carrying trade returns only the merchant's profits to his country, unless domestic ships and sailors are used, in which case freight payments also support domestic workers. Most carrying-trade nations have used their own ships, but this is not inherent to the trade.
distilled: The carrying trade benefits the carrier nation mainly through profits, plus wages to domestic sailors if domestic ships are used -- but using foreign ships is possible and sometimes occurs.
notes: Important qualification to 2.5.32 -- the carrying trade does benefit the home country through profits and, usually, freight wages. The derivation of the term 'carrying trade' from the carriers themselves is an etymological note. The Dutch-British bottoms example shows that even the most basic carrying-trade assumptions can be violated. Links to 2.5.34's argument about shipping and national defense.

refashioned: It is because of this shipping connection that the carrying trade has been considered particularly advantageous for a country like Great Britain, whose defense and security depend on the number of its sailors and ships. But the same capital could employ just as many sailors and ships in the foreign trade of consumption, or even in the home trade when carried on by coastal vessels, as in the carrying trade. The number of sailors and ships that any particular capital can employ depends not on the nature of the trade but partly on the bulk of goods relative to their value, and partly on the distance between ports -- chiefly on the first of these two factors.
elegant: The carrying trade is thought to benefit Britain's defense by employing sailors and ships. But the same capital could employ equally many in the foreign consumption trade or in coastal home trade. Shipping employment depends on the bulk-to-value ratio of goods and the distance between ports, not on the type of trade.
summary: The supposed military advantage of the carrying trade -- employing many sailors -- is illusory, because the same capital employed in foreign consumption trade or coastal trade could employ just as many, since shipping needs depend on cargo bulk and distance, not trade type.
distilled: The carrying trade's supposed advantage for naval defense is false -- the same capital in any trade employing bulky goods over long distances would employ equally many sailors.
notes: Challenges the mercantilist argument that the carrying trade should be favored for national security. The rebuttal is elegant: what determines shipping employment is the physical nature of goods and distance, not the commercial category of trade. The Newcastle-London coal trade example in 2.5.35 drives this home. This anticipates Smith's general skepticism of commercial policy justified by defense arguments (cf. Book IV on the Navigation Acts).

refashioned: The coal trade from Newcastle to London, for example, employs more shipping than all the carrying trade of England combined, even though the ports are at no great distance. To force, therefore, by extraordinary encouragements, a larger share of a country's capital into the carrying trade than would naturally flow there will not always increase the country's shipping.
elegant: The Newcastle-London coal trade alone employs more shipping than all of England's carrying trade combined, despite the short distance. Subsidizing the carrying trade to increase shipping is therefore misguided.
summary: The Newcastle-London coal trade employs more ships than all of England's carrying trade, proving that cargo bulk matters more than trade type for shipping employment. Subsidizing the carrying trade to boost the navy is pointless.
distilled: The coal trade between Newcastle and London employs more shipping than all of England's carrying trade, proving subsidies for carrying trade cannot be justified on naval grounds.
notes: Devastating empirical counterexample to the naval argument for the carrying trade. The coal trade's enormous shipping requirements arise from the sheer bulk of coal, not from any special commercial category. This is one of Smith's most effective empirical arguments -- a single domestic trade route outweighs an entire category of international trade. Links to 2.5.34's theoretical point about bulk-to-value ratios.

refashioned:
Capital employed in a country's home trade will therefore generally provide greater encouragement and support to domestic productive labor, and increase the value of annual output, more than an equal capital in the foreign trade of consumption. Capital in the foreign trade of consumption has, in both these respects, a still greater advantage over an equal capital in the carrying trade. The wealth and power of every country must always be proportional to the value of its annual output, the fund from which all taxes must ultimately be paid.

The great object of every country's political economy is to increase its wealth and power. It should therefore give no preference or superior encouragement to the foreign trade of consumption over the home trade, nor to the carrying trade over either of the other two. It should neither force nor lure into either of those two channels a greater share of the country's capital than would naturally flow there on its own.
elegant: Home trade supports domestic labor and output most, foreign consumption trade next, carrying trade least. Since national wealth and power depend on annual output (the ultimate tax base), political economy should not favor foreign over home trade, or carrying over either. No capital should be forced or lured away from its natural course.
summary: Home trade best supports domestic prosperity, followed by the foreign consumption trade and then the carrying trade. Since national power depends on output, governments should not divert capital from its natural channels by favoring foreign trade or the carrying trade.
distilled: Political economy should not favor foreign or carrying trade over home trade, because domestic output -- the source of all wealth and power -- is best served when capital flows naturally.
notes: Grand policy conclusion of the ranking analysis. The hierarchy is complete: agriculture > manufacturing > home trade > foreign consumption trade > carrying trade. The 'fund from which all taxes must ultimately be paid' connects economic output to state power. The policy prescription -- no artificial encouragement -- is quintessential Smith: let capital find its own most productive use. This is the argumentative foundation for Book IV's critique of mercantilist trade policy. 'Neither force nor allure' captures Smith's opposition to both prohibitions and subsidies.

refashioned:
Each of these different branches of trade, however, is not only advantageous but necessary and unavoidable when the natural course of things introduces it without any constraint or coercion.

When the output of any particular industry exceeds domestic demand, the surplus must be sent abroad and exchanged for something in demand at home. Without such exports, part of the country's productive labor would cease, and the value of annual output would fall. Great Britain generally produces more grain, woolens, and hardware than the home market requires. The surplus must therefore be exported and exchanged for goods in demand domestically. Only through such exports can the surplus acquire a value sufficient to compensate the labor and expense of producing it. Proximity to the sea coast and to navigable rivers is advantageous for industry only because it facilitates the export and exchange of surplus production.
elegant: Every branch of trade becomes necessary when the natural course of things demands it. When domestic production exceeds home demand, the surplus must be exported or productive labor will cease and output will fall. Britain produces more grain, wool, and hardware than it consumes -- only export gives the surplus enough value to justify producing it. Coastal and river locations are advantageous precisely because they facilitate this essential export.
summary: Each type of trade becomes necessary when domestic production naturally exceeds home demand. Without exports, surplus production would lose value, productive labor would cease, and output would decline. Geographic access to shipping routes is valuable because it enables this essential exchange.
distilled: Foreign trade becomes necessary when domestic production exceeds home demand -- without it, surplus output loses value and productive labor ceases.
notes: Critical qualification to the home-trade-first argument -- Smith is not a protectionist. Foreign trade is necessary and beneficial when it arises naturally from surplus production. The vent-for-surplus theory of trade: exports solve the problem of production exceeding domestic demand. The coastal/river advantage explains why trading centers develop near water. This balances the pro-agriculture ranking with a practical recognition that trade is essential for specialization.

refashioned:
When the foreign goods purchased with surplus domestic produce exceed domestic demand, the excess must be re-exported and exchanged for something the home market actually wants. About 96,000 hogsheads of tobacco are purchased annually in Virginia and Maryland with part of the surplus produce of British industry. But British demand requires perhaps no more than 14,000. If the remaining 82,000 could not be sent abroad and exchanged for something more in demand domestically, their importation would have to cease entirely, and with it all the productive labor of the British workers currently employed in preparing the goods used to purchase those 82,000 hogsheads. Those goods, being part of British output with no domestic market and now deprived of their foreign market, would simply cease to be produced.

The most roundabout foreign trade of consumption may therefore, on some occasions, be just as necessary for supporting domestic productive labor and the value of annual output as the most direct trade.
elegant: When imported goods exceed domestic demand, the surplus must be re-exported. Britain imports 96,000 hogsheads of Virginia tobacco annually but consumes only 14,000. Without re-exporting the remaining 82,000, the British workers producing goods to buy that tobacco would lose their livelihoods. Even the most roundabout trade may therefore be as necessary as the most direct for sustaining domestic productive labor.
summary: Re-export trade is sometimes essential: Britain imports far more Virginia tobacco than it consumes and must re-export the surplus or lose the productive labor that manufactures goods to buy it. Even roundabout trade can be as necessary as direct trade.
distilled: Even roundabout re-export trade can be essential for domestic employment when imports vastly exceed domestic consumption and must be re-exported to sustain the original production chain.
notes: Powerful empirical example: Britain re-exports 82,000 of 96,000 hogsheads of Virginia tobacco -- over 85%. Without re-export, British manufacturing workers would be unemployed. This is Smith at his most practical -- theory says roundabout trade is inferior, but real-world necessity can make it essential. The tobacco trade was one of the most important Atlantic commerce flows of the 18th century. Links to 2.5.37's point that trade becomes necessary when it arises naturally.

refashioned:
When a country's capital grows to such a degree that it cannot all be employed in supplying domestic consumption and supporting domestic productive labor, the surplus naturally overflows into the carrying trade and performs the same services for other countries. The carrying trade is the natural effect and symptom of great national wealth, but it does not seem to be its cause. Those statesmen who have tried to encourage it with special subsidies seem to have mistaken the effect for the cause.

Holland, by far the richest country in Europe in proportion to its land area and population, accordingly has the greatest share of Europe's carrying trade. England, perhaps the second richest, is likewise believed to have a considerable share -- though what commonly passes for England's carrying trade will often, on closer examination, prove to be merely a roundabout foreign trade of consumption. Such are, in great measure, the trades that bring East Indian, West Indian, and American goods to various European markets. Those goods are generally purchased with British produce or something acquired through it, and the final returns are generally used or consumed in Britain. The trade carried on in British ships between Mediterranean ports, and some similar trade between Indian ports, are perhaps the principal branches of Britain's genuine carrying trade.
elegant: When a country's capital exceeds domestic needs, the surplus naturally flows into the carrying trade. This trade is a symptom and effect of wealth, not its cause -- statesmen who subsidize it mistake effect for cause. Holland, Europe's richest per capita, dominates the carrying trade. England's supposed carrying trade is mostly roundabout foreign consumption trade -- goods from the East and West Indies purchased with British products and ultimately consumed in Britain. Only Mediterranean and Indian inter-port trade is truly English carrying trade.
summary: The carrying trade naturally absorbs surplus capital that exceeds domestic needs, making it a symptom rather than a cause of national wealth. Much of what appears to be England's carrying trade is actually roundabout foreign consumption trade, since the goods are ultimately purchased with and consumed by British production.
distilled: The carrying trade is a symptom of surplus national capital, not a cause of wealth -- and much of what passes for England's carrying trade is really roundabout foreign consumption trade.
notes: Major distinction between symptom and cause -- a recurring Smithian analytical move (cf. 2.3.24-2.3.25 on gold flows). The correction of England's supposed carrying trade is empirically important -- Smith shows that most East/West India trade is really consumption trade because British produce starts and finishes the chain. Holland as the carrying-trade exemplar reflects its unique position: small territory, enormous capital, limited domestic absorption capacity. Directly challenges mercantilist encouragement of carrying trade.

refashioned: The extent of the home trade, and the capital it can absorb, is necessarily limited by the value of surplus produce that different places within the country need to exchange with one another. The extent of the foreign trade of consumption is limited by the value of the whole country's surplus produce and what can be purchased with it. The extent of the carrying trade is limited by the value of the surplus produce of all the different countries in the world. Its potential extent is therefore virtually infinite compared to the other two, and it is capable of absorbing the greatest capitals.
elegant: Home trade is limited by domestic surplus exchanges. Foreign consumption trade is limited by the country's total surplus. The carrying trade is limited only by the surplus of all the world's countries -- its potential extent is virtually infinite and can absorb the greatest capitals.
summary: Each type of trade has a natural limit: home trade by domestic surpluses, foreign consumption trade by national surplus, and carrying trade by global surplus. The carrying trade therefore has virtually unlimited capacity to absorb capital.
distilled: The carrying trade can absorb virtually unlimited capital because its scope encompasses the surplus production of the entire world, not just one country.
notes: Explains why great accumulations of capital naturally flow into the carrying trade -- it is the only channel with effectively unlimited capacity. This resolves an apparent tension: the carrying trade is least productive domestically but has the greatest capacity, so very wealthy nations naturally engage in it. Holland's dominance of the carrying trade follows logically from its capital surplus. This is an early statement of the idea that global markets can absorb capital that domestic markets cannot.

refashioned: The consideration of private profit is the sole motive that determines where any capital owner employs his capital -- whether in agriculture, manufacturing, or some branch of wholesale or retail trade. The different quantities of productive labor that his capital might set in motion, and the different values it might add to the society's annual output depending on its employment, never enter his thoughts. In countries, therefore, where agriculture is the most profitable of all employments, and farming and improving land the most direct roads to a splendid fortune, the capitals of individuals will naturally be employed in the manner most advantageous to the whole society.
elegant: Capital owners are guided solely by private profit, never thinking about how much productive labor their capital sets in motion or how much it adds to national output. But in countries where agriculture is the most profitable employment, private profit-seeking naturally directs capital to society's greatest advantage.
summary: Private profit alone guides capital allocation. Individuals never consider the social productivity of their investments. But where agriculture is most profitable, the pursuit of private gain naturally channels capital to its most socially productive use.
distilled: Private profit-seeking naturally directs capital to society's benefit when agriculture -- the most socially productive employment -- is also the most privately profitable.
notes: This passage foreshadows the famous invisible hand argument of Book IV, Chapter 2. The gap between private motivation (profit) and social outcome (productive labor) is bridged when the most profitable private use happens to be the most socially productive. The 'never enter his thoughts' phrase anticipates 'he intends only his own gain.' The qualification 'where agriculture is the most profitable' is crucial -- Smith will argue in Books III-IV that European policy has distorted this natural alignment. Links to 2.5.42 for the observation that in practice agriculture is not the most profitable in Europe.

refashioned:
Agricultural profits, however, do not appear to exceed those of other employments anywhere in Europe. Indeed, promoters in every corner of Europe have in recent years entertained the public with magnificent claims about the profits to be made from cultivating and improving land. Without examining their calculations in detail, a very simple observation shows their conclusions must be false. We see every day the most splendid fortunes acquired in a single lifetime through trade and manufacturing, frequently from very small capital and sometimes from none at all. A single instance of such a fortune made through agriculture, in the same time and from such a starting point, has perhaps not occurred anywhere in Europe during the present century.

In all the great countries of Europe, however, much good land remains uncultivated, and the greater part of what is cultivated is far from being improved to the degree of which it is capable. Agriculture is therefore nearly everywhere capable of absorbing far more capital than has ever yet been employed in it. What circumstances in European policy have given urban trades so great an advantage over rural industry that private individuals frequently find it more profitable to invest their capital in the most distant carrying trades of Asia and America than in improving the most fertile fields in their own neighborhood -- this I shall endeavor to explain fully in the two following books.
elegant: Agricultural profits do not exceed those of other employments in Europe, despite promoters' claims. The proof is simple: great fortunes are made in trade and manufacturing from tiny starting capital, but not in agriculture. Yet much European land remains uncultivated or underimproved -- agriculture could absorb far more capital. The question of why European policy favors distant carrying trades over improving nearby fertile fields will be examined in Books III and IV.
summary: Despite claims about agricultural profitability, no European fortunes have been made from farming comparable to those from trade and manufacturing. Yet abundant land remains underutilized. Smith promises that Books III and IV will explain why European policy has distorted capital away from agriculture toward distant trade.
distilled: European fortunes are made in trade and manufacturing, not agriculture, despite vast uncultivated land -- Books III and IV will explain the policy distortions responsible.
notes: Closes Book II by setting up the central puzzle of Books III and IV: if agriculture is the most socially productive use of capital, why does European policy make urban and distant trade more privately profitable? The empirical observation -- no agricultural fortunes comparable to trading ones -- is a powerful reality check against physiocratic idealism. The 'two following books' promise connects Book II's theoretical framework to Book III's historical narrative and Book IV's policy critique. This is one of the most important transitional passages in the entire Wealth of Nations.
